PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 10.00 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (SEARCH WARRANTS AND POWERS OF ARREST) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 1 February, on motion by Mr Kerr:
That the bill be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Mr Williams had moved by way of amendment:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for review".

TALK.START.PARA: —Before my comments were interrupted last evening, I indicated that I would return to a number of the points raised by speakers on both sides on the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Bill. A large thrust of the comments of the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams), dealt with why we might not simply be better placed picking up state laws. The question asked was whether it would not be easier for state police, who are responsible for policing federal laws, to also be subject to the provisions of the bill.

PARA.TAB: The government has acted as it has to codify federal law for precisely the same reason it acted as it did some time ago to codify those laws relating to interviews for federal offences. It is anxious to avoid injustice, whereby those who are accused of federal offences are treated differently in different jurisdictions. That, of course, was the fundamental principle underlying the whole approach taken by the Gibbs committee and is reflected in the detention before charge recommendations which we enacted some time ago.

In short, we are not prepared to accept the lowest common denominator approach. We are not prepared to accept provisions which have been roundly criticised in relation to civil liberties in a number of states in relation to their procedures. We think it far better to codify the law and to protect the interests of individuals, subject to law enforcement, by making sure that we have a well researched and well thought out Commonwealth code that applies across the board to all who are subject to Commonwealth offences.

There are provisions that can apply if difficulties arise. State police have been trained very successfully in the part 1C requirements and have been successfully using them for two years. State police are familiar, as they have had to become over a long period, with the differences between state and federal laws on drug law enforcement where, depending on the facts of the case, they have had the option of using powers under section 10 of the Customs Act or state law. The police are not as ignorant of these differences as the honourable member for Tangney suggests.

Furthermore, any national policing enforcement agency, such as the Australian Federal Police, has to be able to transfer its personnel and resources from state to state. Its personnel are confronted with training and mobility problems if they have to deal with different procedural laws in different jurisdictions. The federal government has recognised its prime responsibility is to ensure that the Federal Police operates efficiently and under a clear and uniform scheme.

One other point that the shadow Attorney-General raised was on proposed new section 3ZV, which deals with forensic samples. That provision provides that, for this purpose, the Commonwealth will continue to rely on state law. This is only because I am still waiting on the results of an attempt by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General to settle on an agreed national approach in relation to forensic samples.

As I indicated on page 5 of the second reading speech, this arrangement is for bridging purposes. I expect that I will soon be in a position to present a bill on that subject. I think it is the responsibility of the federal parliament to tackle such fundamental issues, rather than hiding behind state laws, which in some cases may be quite unacceptable. In that regard I instance the very strong criticisms that have been made by a number of commentators in relation to recent Victorian provisions.

If I can turn to the contribution from the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), he commenced by indicating that on a personal basis he would wish that the matter be referred to the House of Representatives standing committee as he had not yet had the opportunity to peruse the bill and to consider its contents. The submission might be honest but certainly it is novel. This legislation has been 18 years in the gestation. It arose out of the Gibbs committee report, which has been public for a substantial period. The Gibbs committee report was the subject of extensive submissions by law societies throughout Australia and was probably one of the most widely canvassed pieces of preparatory work for legislation.

In addition, the bill was first in caucus committee's hands in November of 1992, some 12 months ago. Its actual passage through caucus was on 26 October 1993, which preceded the much canvassed overseas trip of the honourable member for Banks. Since then, there has been 2 1/2 months during which this bill has been available for comment. Some of those in the community concerned about this matter, principally Mr Sides and others, have taken the opportunity to write to the government to express their views on some of the clauses. Where that has been done, there has been an extensive correspondence between me and those who have made the submissions. Indeed, the government has responded positively and, in the committee stage, will put forward some amendments which have originated out of that correspondence.

Practice at the New South Wales bar may have changed since the time I was briefly there, but I would have thought that on a most important matter such as this, which the honourable member for Banks has indicated is perhaps the most basic and fundamental of legislation, a barrister who received a brief so well notified in advance and who then came before a tribunal saying that a further adjournment was required before one could read it or make submissions on its merits might find it difficult to get too much sympathy.

I reject entirely any inference or implication that the Attorney-General's Department or I, as Minister for Justice, have a mentality that is all one-way, eroding individuals' rights in favour of securing convictions. Indeed, the very provisions that I referred to earlier, part 1C of the Crimes Act, reflect a very strong determination to move to ensure that abuses of civil rights are prevented from occurring under federal law enforcement. I think everybody who has been concerned about police-citizen relations would say that one of the most odious of alleged abuses is that of verballing. The present requirements to videotape confessional materials and to limit the time in which people are subject to interview have been enormously positive in ensuring that the appearance of propriety and the actuality of propriety coincide. This government has been acutely interested in ensuring the protection of civil liberties.

I defer to no-one in my record as a person who has worked for Aboriginal legal services and various other organisations on the ground in relation to those who are subject most to the sharp edge of law enforcement in my commitment to civil liberties. I do not think the implication was directly made, but nonetheless there may have been some who thought that there was an inference that this government has less than a full commitment to civil liberties. I reject that entirely on behalf of myself, the Attorney-General and the department.

In the few minutes that remain I turn to the comments made by other speakers in the debate. With no offence to them, I will not mention them each by name because many of the matters they raised canvassed or traversed similar ground. There was reference to clause 3E(2), which provides that a search warrant may be issued to search people. The important point about clause 3E(2) is that it provides for judicial supervision and recognises the facts of criminal behaviour—that criminals are mobile. The main thing about the warrant is that it is judicially supervised, no way arbitrarily, and is fundamentally no different from a search warrant of premises.

The extension of the search warrant to cover the search of persons on the premises is supported by strict requirements on the issuing officer at proposed subparagraphs 3E(5) and 3E(6) to state in the warrant the grounds for the search—such as the concealment of evidence or the use of the thing to commit an offence which is the subject of the search—and the kind of search authorised. Under clause 3E(4) there is also a requirement to state the description of the premises and the times at which the warrant may be executed. Again, that makes the matter entirely the subject of judicial supervision.

There are criticisms about clause 3E(4)(d) in relation to the naming of persons to be responsible for executing warrants. It was decided in the legislation that only one person should be responsible for the warrant; that is, a named person. But the definition of the executing officer provides that the police may change the named person. That sheets home the responsibility to the named person so that there can be no defence that he thought another person was taking responsibility. I think that is a very important provision and is entirely consistent with the government's defence of civil liberties, and to ensure that where the execution of a warrant in these circumstances is carried out the person who does take charge of the operation cannot evade responsibility for it.

There were also some comments made in relation to the matter of name and address. Certainly, I think there is no doubt in the community that, in practice, this does occur. The Law Reform Commission in its earlier report many years ago pointed out that there was a need for the police to be able to exercise the right to ask witnesses, and those who are suspected of engagement in some crime, of their name and address to help the police to investigate a matter and to locate people, thus reducing time and costs. But, more than that, the Australian Law Reform Commission pointed out that in practice this power is exercised often abusively. Because the police know they have to exercise that power, they in fact arrest people or do things which are not necessarily strictly permitted by the legal framework in order to exercise a right which all of us concede should be exercised and which, in broad terms, the general community concedes to the police.

So what we have done in this provision is to square up practice with law and to surround it with appropriate safeguards and guarantees for the personal rights of the individual. It is far better to establish legal controls over justifiable use of police powers than to turn a blind eye to abuse because the controls have not been formally recognised by the common law or because there may be some potential for misuse. It is entirely consistent, also, with the principle that underlies the legislation that greater emphasis should be placed by proceeding by way of summons as distinct from arrest. Unnecessary arrest is to be avoided. Part of that of course is that a person who might otherwise be arrested will be asked for his or her name and address and then proceeded against summarily.

A number of other points were raised in this debate. I will only have time to raise quickly the last of those points, in relation to arrest without warrant to arrest. There is nothing new about this provision except that we have provided for greater certainty by defining the exact circumstances as to when such arrest should occur. The police have always been able to enter premises without a warrant where it is absolutely necessary, such as when in pursuit of a person whom they need to arrest.

Previously, this power has depended largely on the common law, which is well described in the New South Wales Supreme Court case Lippl v. Hines, at page 620 18 New South Wales Law Reports No. 620 (1989). In that case at page 630 Mr Justice Hope lamented that there was no statute which deals with these matters in a comprehensive way and the resolution of the position under general law imposed no little difficulty. The bill does precisely that. It spells out in clause 3ZA the limited circumstances in which the power can be exercised. I believe it is entirely consistent with the commitment of this government to codify the law to protect civil liberties of the individual and to ensure that it responds constructively to the Gibbs committee and the work of the Australian Law Reform Commission. I commend the bill to the House.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr The Hon D.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 4, page 3, after proposed subsection 3D(1) insert the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "`(1A) To avoid any doubt, it is declared that even though another law of the Commonwealth provides power to do one or more of the things referred to in subsection (1), a similar power conferred by this Part may be used despite the existence of the power under the other law.".

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 4, page 8, lines 5 to 17, omit proposed section 3G.
(3)Clause 4, page 30, after proposed section 3ZP, insert the following section:

PARA.TAB: "`3ZPA.(1) The executing officer or a constable assisting must, before any person enters premises under a warrant or to arrest a person:

TAB.TAB: (a)announce that he or she is authorised to enter the premises; and
(b)give any person at the premises an opportunity to allow entry to the premises.

PARA.TAB: "`(2) The executing officer or a constable assisting is not required to comply with subsection (1) if he or she believes on reasonable grounds that immediate entry to the premises is required to ensure:

TAB.TAB: (a)the safety of a person (including the executing officer and the constable assisting); or
(b)that the effective execution of the warrant or the arrest is not frustrated.".

SPEECH.PARA: (4)Clause 4, page 32, line 24, omit "3ZH", substitute "3ZI".

The amendments are quite brief in scope. I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum which sets out the amendments and the reasons why they have been moved. There are two provisions that are included, one of which has been dealt with following correspondence discussed in the second reading speech between Mr Sides and myself. It deals with the question of when a police officer is not executing a warrant but exercising the powers of entry.

PARA.TAB: The bill had provided that where police officers in the execution of a warrant came to the door of a household they had to announce their presence unless there were certain limited circumstances whereby their own safety or the safety of those inside was thought to be at jeopardy. However, by omission that provision had not been included in those circumstances where entry without a warrant was facilitated by this bill. This amendment tidies up an omission, which was also made in the recommendations to us by the former chief justice Sir Harry Gibbs in his bill, to ensure that there is a consistency of approach.

That is again consistent with the government trying to avoid the sort of instances that arose in the Gundy case such as where without notice a door is broken down, the police enter a house, the inhabitants are naturally frightened and possibly likely to panic and do untoward things, and where violence is potentially aggravated. The bill does provide for appropriate exceptions so that police are not placed in jeopardy or in any harm's way. As the committee would expect, the exceptions are common sense ones and protect the interests of both those who are involved in the enforcement of the law and those who are its potential victims.

The other provision is to enable the police to exercise the powers in this bill where other Commonwealth legislation also provides for enforcement mechanisms. The shadow Attorney-General in his comments earlier pointed out that there are different enforcement mechanisms provided for under other Commonwealth law. This, I believe, will eventually become a codification of the way in which the Commonwealth will proceed. But, whatever the case, we want to make sure that the police have available to them the measures under this bill.

Rather than being a lowest common denominator, this really is, I think, a high watermark or a highest common denominator. But, of course, by its application and practice I think it will benchmark new standards which will become applicable to the investigation of offences across the board, at both a Commonwealth and state level. One certainly hopes that is the effect of it. With those brief remarks, I commend the government amendments.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report—by leave—adopted.
Bill (on motion by Mr Kerr)—by leave—read a third time.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 17 November, on motion by Mr Kerr:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea was signed by Australia on 10 December 1982. Negotiation of the convention involved extraordinary time and effort. Negotiations took place over a period of nine years and involved approximately 160 countries. The convention is very broad in scope and virtually codifies human use of the oceans. It contains provisions governing the limits of national jurisdiction over ocean space, access to the seas, navigation, protection and preservation of the marine environment, exploitation of living resources and conservation, scientific research, seabed mining and other exploitation of non-living resources and the settlement of disputes.

PARA.TAB: Australia has not yet ratified the convention. The government has stated that consultations are taking place with a view to overcoming difficulties that have arisen in relation to the convention provisions dealing with deep seabed mining. If those difficulties can be overcome, the government says that it will be in a position to give serious consideration to ratifying the convention.

In any event, the convention is likely to enter into force in the near future. There have been 59 ratifications to date and 60 ratifications are required for the convention to enter into force. Additionally, many of the obligations contained in the convention are the subject of such widespread usage and practice by the international community that they have formed part of customary international law and are binding on Australia irrespective of the force of the convention.

In anticipation of ratification and in recognition of potential existing obligations, this bill seeks to give effect in Australian law to those provisions of the convention dealing with maritime zones. Specifically, it seeks to implement parts II, V and VI of the convention which deal respectively with the territorial sea and contiguous zone, the exclusive economic zone and the continental shelf.

The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), in his second reading speech on this bill, has outlined the effect that the bill will have in relation to these matters. In short, the determination of the territorial sea is not to be inconsistent with the requirements laid down in the convention. The current adoption in Australia of a 12 nautical mile territorial sea accords with the limit prescribed by the convention.

A contiguous zone of no greater than 24 nautical miles from the territorial sea baselines is provided for in the bill. Within that zone Australia will be able to exercise rights of control in relation to breaches of laws committed on Australian territory or on its territorial sea. The bill provides for a 200 nautical mile exclusive economic zone which allows, amongst other things, sovereign and other rights over both living and non-living resources.

The bill standardises the definition of the continental shelf in terms of the convention. At minimum, the continental shelf is deemed to extend 200 nautical miles. Where the physical configuration of the shelf allows, in certain instances that distance may be extended but with maximum limits being applicable. The bill makes consequential amendments to a number of other acts, principally incorporating reference to the convention and deleting reference to the 1958 Geneva conventions on territorial sea and the continental shelf which previously governed maritime zones.

The bill incorporates as a schedule the full text of parts II, V and VI of the convention. This serves to emphasise the importance of the principles contained in the convention in the subsequent application and interpretation of the legislation. Successive Australian governments approached the United Nations conferences on the law of the sea, which resulted in the 1982 convention, in a bipartisan spirit. It was considered that as Australia is an island continent with extensive offshore areas and heavily dependent on international trade, it had a vital interest in the issues before the conferences on the law of the sea. In 1981 it was stated that it was an objective of the coalition government that the international law of the sea should be cleared of the doubts and uncertainties regarded as existing.

In a speech to this House in 1981, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, stated that to this end successive governments of Australia, on both sides of politics, had taken the view that Australia's substantial interests in the law of the sea would best be protected by the early adoption of a comprehensive and widely accepted convention. The passage of this bill, in enshrining into Australian law major aspects of the convention, is a major step from Australia's perspective—and subject to my comments to follow—in ensuring clarity and uniformity in the international laws governing the use of our oceans. For that reason, the coalition does not oppose this bill.

I do wish, however, to make comments on three specific matters. The first concerns undertakings given by the government when this bill was debated in the Senate. The second concerns the position of the states and the offshore constitutional settlement. The third raises a question that Australia may technically be breaching obligations at international law when this bill is passed.

As to the first matter, I wish to place on the record and clarify what may appear to be undertakings and commitments given in the Senate by the government in response to assurances sought by Senators Coulter and Chamarette. The concerns raised by Senators Coulter and Chamarette arise from articles 61 to 73 inclusive of the convention which are contained within part 5 of the convention dealing with the exclusive economic zone. Those articles are concerned with conservation and utilisation of living resources within the exclusive economic zone by states—states in the international legal sense—as well as rights of land locked and geographically disadvantaged states. The difficulties result from terminology that is used to describe the extent to which states may utilise living resources.

For example, article 61, which is headed `Conservation of living resources', deals with the need for states to implement measures to ensure that living resources are not endangered by over-exploitation. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Such measures shall also be designed to maintain or restore populations of harvested species at levels which can produce the maximum sustainable yield—
The use of the expression `maximum sustainable yield' is objected to by the two senators. Similarly, article 62, which is headed `Utilisation of living resources', states:
The coastal State shall promote the optimum utilisation of the living resources in the exclusive economic zone—

The expression `optimum utilisation' is objected to by the senators. The problem is that these are no longer considered appropriate expressions when dealing with conservation and environmental protection. Since 1982 there have been considerable developments and changes of thinking in the international environmental law field. Utilisation of natural resources is now considered to be governed by principles of ecologically sustainable development. The expression objected to places insignificant emphasis on the ecological considerations.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette expressed the view that the term `optimum utilisation' has set the basic framework for over-exploitation of coastal waters around the world. The senator states that this is particularly the case in the context of article 62(2) which provides that countries that do not have the capacity to exploit their resources must allow other countries to exploit their waters to the optimum utilisation level.

With the difficulties in mind, Senator Coulter, during the Senate committee stage of this bill, sought certain assurances from Senator Collins. They were, first, that passage of the bill will not result in the application of articles 61 to 72 inclusive to the fisheries management regime in Australia and that fisheries management will continue to be consistent with the approach adopted in the national strategy for ecologically sustainable development, namely, that fisheries be managed within an ecosystem management framework; second, that the government will take up issues relating to conservation and utilisation of living resources in a range of international fora; and, third, that the government will call for the convention to be made consistent with the approach adopted in the national strategy for ecologically sustainable development. In particular, Senator Coulter stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a fisheries ecosystem management framework which will provide a more holistic and sustainable approach to management of aquatic resources.

While Senator Collins agrees that some of the language used in the convention is outdated, he says that the government's view is that the principles of the convention are not inconsistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development. He goes further in saying that the provisions should be implemented in a manner which is consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development.

PARA.TAB: To support this view Senator Collins notes that agenda 21, which was adopted at the United Nations conference on environment and development in 1992—the so-called Earth Summit—provides that marine resources should be managed in accordance with the provisions of the Law of the Sea Convention. Given that the tenor of agenda 21 is to endorse the principle of ecologically sustainable development, it follows that the law of the sea provisions can be interpreted consistently with the principle. Applying that comment to Senator Coulter's third request, Senator Collins is effectively saying that there is no need to call for the convention to be made consistent with the principle, as it is already consistent.

As to the first request, Senator Collins states that the Fisheries Management Act, which is the primary Australian legislation governing the use of marine living resources, requires, in its application, consistency with the principles of ecologically sustainable development. The act also requires regard to be had to proper conservation and optimum utilisation in accordance with the provisions set out in articles 61 and 62 of the convention. This emphasises, according to Senator Collins, that there is no inconsistency. He states that not only can those principles of ecologically sustainable development be implemented in Australia in our fisheries reserves but they should be. Thus no allowance is given that passage of the bill would not result in the application of articles 61 to 73 inclusive to the fisheries management regime in Australia because, in the government's view, those principles are not inconsistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development.

In relation to the second requested assurance that the government will take up issues of ecologically sustainable development in international fora, Senator Collins states that these are the subject of debate and negotiation in various international fora, including: a conference organised by the United Nations on straddling stocks and highly migratory fish stocks; the United Nations sustainable development commission which is implementing agenda 21; the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations, which is developing an international code of conduct on responsible fishing. According to Senator Collins, Australia is actively involved in all these processes and will wish to see results in accordance with the principles of ecologically sustainable development.

Senator Chamarette sought assurances of her own during the second reading debate. First, the senator called for notice to be given that the government believes that certain provisions of the convention do not form part of customary international law. Second was a call for the government to review the convention so that it is consistent with the International Convention on Biological Diversity and with the language found in agenda 21. Third was the call for the establishment of a national marine environment management authority to be responsible for Australia's progress in this regard.

No specific response was given to these requested assurances, although the statements made by Senator Collins in relation to Senator Coulter's requests deal with the first two matters. The response by the government would be that as the provisions in the convention are not inconsistent with the principle of ecologically sustainable development, there is no reason why the provisions may not form part of customary international law, nor is there any reason to review the convention. There is no response to the request for the establishment of a national marine environment management authority.

Despite the minister's assurances that the principles of the convention are not inconsistent with the principle of ecologically sustainable development, that is not borne out by the language of the provisions referred to. Accepting that the issue is being hedged and hemmed by other activities, the government would still be well advised to take any opportunity that arises to have the convention amended. Serious consideration should also be given to an appropriate qualification or interpretation in any instrument of ratification.

I now turn to the second matter which concerns the impact of the bill on the Offshore Constitutional Settlement. The Offshore Constitutional Settlement constitutes an agreement reached in 1979 between the Commonwealth and the states that gives states legislative competence in respect of their territorial sea. At the time the agreement was reached the territorial sea was limited to three miles in breadth. It was accepted that the territorial limit of the grant of legislative competence to the states would remain at three miles, even if Australia subsequently moved to a territorial sea of 12 miles, which has since happened. The settlement also gives each state powers outside the territorial sea in respect of port-type facilities, underground mining extending from land within a state, and fisheries. The explanatory memorandum and the second reading speech both state that the bill does not affect the Offshore Constitutional Settlement.

The Western Australian Attorney-General has drawn my attention to clause 10A of the bill which, but for the assurances given, might raise a question concerning the applicability of the Offshore Constitutional Settlement to the exclusive economic zone. Clause 10A states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is declared and enacted that the rights and jurisdiction of Australia in its exclusive economic zone are vested in and exercisable by the Crown in the right of the Commonwealth.

The clause notes that this is equivalent to the existing section 11 of the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973 in relation to the continental shelf. The important difference is that section 11 refers to the sovereign rights over the continental shelf and section 10A refers to the rights and jurisdiction over the exclusive economic zone. It is important to emphasise that the difference in wording seems to be the result of the wording of the convention and cannot be significant in relation to the states' extraterritorial legislative competence. By conferring jurisdiction over the exclusive economic zone, section 10A does not create an area over which the Commonwealth has exclusive jurisdiction to legislate inconsistent with the Offshore Constitutional Settlement.

PARA.TAB: I now turn to the third point, which concerns a possibility that Australia is breaching its obligations at international law by the passage of this bill. The 1958 Geneva Convention on the Continental Shelf is the predecessor to the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. As already noted, the 1982 convention has not entered into force; nor has it been ratified. The government has simply stated that if certain negotiations relating to deep seabed mining are successful it will give consideration to ratifying the convention. That means that there is no guarantee that Australia will ratify the convention in the near future.

In relation to the continental shelf, until the 1982 convention is ratified by Australia and enters into force, Australia will be bound at international law to comply with the provisions of the 1958 convention. Given that this bill incorporates a definition of the continental shelf that is different from that contained in the 1958 convention, my concern is that, if the resulting act comes into operation prior to the operation of the 1982 convention, duly ratified by Australia, Australia may be breaching its obligations at international law. The only circumstances in which that conclusion would not follow are where all the parties to the 1958 convention agreed to its termination, where specific provision was made in the 1958 convention, or where principles of customary international law superseded provisions contained in the convention. The first two matters are not applicable. As to the third, I am not convinced that the provisions of the 1982 convention relating to the continental shelf have formed part of customary international law.

I mentioned at the beginning of this speech that many of the obligations contained in the 1982 convention are the subject of such wide-spread usage and practice by the international community that they have formed part of customary international law. That certainly is likely to be the case in relation to the territorial sea and the exclusive economic zone. It is not nearly as clear in relation to the determination of the continental shelf. Custom is developed where a rule is so widely applied as to suggest general recognition of the broad principle of law.

One essential criterion to establish custom is widespread state practice. I use `state' in the international legal sense. The difficulty is that the definition of continental shelf is so complex in the 1982 convention that it has not as yet become a matter of wide state practice. That may be contrasted with the determination of the territorial sea, which is a relatively simple matter. As at February 1992, 113 countries had claimed a 12-mile territorial limit. Given the number of landlocked countries, the practice is almost universal. Only a few countries, however, have adopted in their own legislation the complex definition of continental shelf contained in the 1982 convention. A number more have adopted the broader definition contained in article 76(1).

A majority of countries still determine their continental shelf by reference to the 1958 convention. In my view that in itself would rule out any possibility that the provisions of the 1982 convention relating to the continental shelf have formed part of international law. I do not wish to overplay this point. Australia can hardly be criticised for seeking to bring itself into line with future obligations. It is further unlikely that, if a breach of international obligations does exist, anyone will complain loudly about it. I ask, however, whether any thought has been given to making the operation of the act conditional upon the entering into force of the 1982 convention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the Maritime Legislation Amendment Bill. As has been outlined, the purpose of this bill is to complete the process of bringing Australia's maritime zones into line with those to which Australia is entitled under the international law as reflected in the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.

PARA.TAB: The bill makes changes to existing law in four principal areas: the establishment of rights in an exclusive economic zone, adoption of a revised definition of the continental shelf, assertion of rights in a contiguous zone, and adoption of new international legal provisions for the drawing of territorial sea baselines. It is claimed that the convention is reflective of customary international law.

I listened with interest and noted the comments of the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) in relation to the continental shelf. He raised some interesting and very technical points in relation to the previous convention. I do not know the answer to those questions that he raised. However, given the long discussion period leading up to the signing of the 1982 convention, given the number of ratifications of which Australia unfortunately was not a member and, as mentioned by the honourable member for Tangney, given the number of states which are adopting this convention, I believe it should be accepted now as part of customary international law.

As an island continent, it is important that Australia's maritime zones are in line with those to which Australia is entitled under international law. Although these amendments will bring Australia into line with the 1982 convention, and the government considers that in relation to maritime zones the convention should govern Australian practice, Australia has not ratified the convention; we have signed it. Indeed, we did so in 1982 but, like many conventions, Australia is lagging in ratification. The difficulty, as I understand it, lies in relation to the mining of the deep seabed and whether the resources there are to be defined as—and was defined by some countries leading up to the conference and discussions on the law on the sea—the common heritage of mankind, or humankind I suppose we should say these days, or whether they should come under a national jurisdiction.

At present, consultations are taking place under the auspices of the Secretary-General of the United Nations with a view to overcoming some of the difficulties that have arisen under the convention in relation to the provisions dealing with deep seabed mining. I hope Australia and other developed states will be in a position to give serious consideration to ratifying the convention and hence ensuring that it is universally accepted as law on the subject.

The convention deals with almost every human use of the oceans. It contains provisions governing the limits of national jurisdiction over ocean space; access to the seas; navigation, protection and preservation of the marine environment; exploitation of living resources and conservation; scientific research; seabed mining and other exploitation of non-living resources; and the settlement of disputes.

Part II of the convention contains provisions relating to a coastal state's jurisdictions over its territorial sea. Article 3 allows for the establishment of a territorial sea up to 12nautical miles in breadth. Under article 17 ships of all states are allowed innocent passage through a state's territorial sea. The term `innocent passage' is defined generally in articles 18 and 19. Passage is defined to be the continuous and expeditious navigation through a territorial sea for the purpose of traversing that sea without entering internal waters or calling at a port facility outside internal waters or proceeding to or from internal waters or a call at such port facility.

Passage is defined to be innocent if it is not prejudicial to the peace, good order or security of the coastal state and conforms with the convention and other rules of international law. Article 17 prevents a coastal state from hampering the innocent passage of foreign vessels in its territorial sea.

Article 21 allows a coastal state to pass legislation consistent with the provisions of the convention and other rules of international law on a number of issues including: the safety of navigation and regulation of maritime traffic; the conservation of the living resources of the sea; prevention, reduction and control of pollution; and the prevention of infringement on the customs, fiscal immigration or sanitary laws and regulation of the coastal state.

The concept of innocent passage is interesting and, in maritime terms, longstanding. But what if that innocent passage results in pollution? For example, the Braer was on innocent passage from Norway to Canada when it went aground near the Shetland Islands early last year with potentially disastrous environmental and economic results.

Innocent passage cannot cover poor seamanship or lack of crew competence. Crew competence, or the lack of it, is a growing international problem as greedy shipowners and agents choose the cheapest crewing. First it was India and Pakistan, then the Philippines and now Burma.

It is interesting that the British report on the Braer incident recommends a fresh international effort to raise standards of practical seamanship. This was an issue raised in the Ships of shame report presented to the parliament in December 1992. The committee members were appalled at the lack of practical seamanship evidenced in many flags of convenience ships coming to Australia. Senator Collins, in his second reading speech on this legislation, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It will be for future legislation to deal expressly with matters such as pollution control in the exclusive economic zone.

I hope this promised legislation is not too far in the future. The international maritime law concerning pollution needs to be rigorously enforced and strengthened, as do the inspections of ships traversing the waters around Australia. With the growth of shipping registers around the world, an ageing world fleet, increasingly greedy owners and pressure from vested interests to lower freight rates, the waters around Australia, whether they be our territorial sea or the exclusive economic zone, are being littered with ships waiting to give us an environmental disaster.

PARA.TAB: There must be a considerable tightening up of shipping around Australia and regulations regarding the issue of single voyage permits must be enforced and not have a blind eye turned to them as was the usual practice of the Department of Transport in the past. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority has increased the level of inspection and detention since the Ships of shame report, but the Department of Transport needs the broom well and truly put through it.

If we had an expanding Australian fleet there would not be a worry about the condition of shipping within territorial waters or the exclusive economic zone. It is a matter of regret, indeed of shame, that so little produce is carried in Australian ships. We do not have these ships and we will pay a price for this in years to come. It is economic folly of the worst kind that we are not embarking on a massive shipbuilding program. Australia is so dependent on trade and we will be at the mercy of foreign owners of a diminishing fleet in a few years time. By the time we realise our folly, it will be too late. There should be an expansion of the Australian shipping industry.

As an aside, I was disappointed that the report, Developing Australia: a regional perspective, better known as the Kelty report, did not take up the challenge of shipping or shipbuilding in Australia. In my view, it is also economic lunacy to talk about the opening of the Australian coast to foreign flagged and crewed vessels. We must maintain cabotage for our economic survival.

This legislation is to be welcomed. It reflects the need for Australia, with its significant interests as both a coastal and a maritime state, to position itself to take advantage of developments in the law of the sea. Australia's actions in this regard will promote the further consolidation of coastal and maritime state rights and obligations as set out in the 1982 convention. But we as a government put so much store on the 1982 convention that perhaps we should now ratify it. I know that 12 years between signing and ratification is not a record for us in Australia, but we should really move in this direction. I support the legislation. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason we are discussing the Maritime Legislation Amendment Bill this morning is to bring into line Australia's maritime zones in accordance with our entitlements under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea 1992. We have adopted that convention and signed it, but we have not yet ratified it. In reference to that, I can do no better than refer to the words of the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, when he said in the other place last year while introducing the Maritime Legislation Amendment Bill 1993:

SPEECH.PARA: It is, apart from the provisions relating to mining of the deep seabed, generally reflective of international law. The Government considers that in relation to maritime zones the Convention should govern Australian practice.

We are a maritime nation. We depend upon the sea for the transport of almost all of our trade. We have a very large coastline, which we are responsible for protecting and managing. What changes are brought about by the legislation that is before us? Those changes are in four major areas: the establishment of rights in an exclusive economic zone; the adoption of a revised definition of the continental shelf; the assertion of rights in any nearby zone; and the adoption of new international legal provisions for the drawing of territorial sea zones.

PARA.TAB: Why should changes be made? There is not any hidden agenda or any other set of objectives to pursue this legislation. The last international convention with regard to territorial marine zones and continental shelves was the 1958 Geneva convention. The amendments will merely replace the operative provisions in Commonwealth legislation which refer to the 1958 convention with references to the 1982 convention. I believe that is the sensible thing to do. It will update domestic laws in line with international agreements. I welcome the support for this legislation from the other side of the chamber.

In addition to that, the changes should assist in bettering our international relationships. Australia has been ahead of most of the world in this respect. Australia has come to realise that our marine resources are a precious national resource. They are also a precious international resource. We have had disputes in the past with some of our neighbours, such as Indonesia. It is possible that in the future there may be others—maybe Indonesia again or Papua New Guinea. So it makes good sense that we conduct our international relationships and we assert our rights within agreed international bounds of conduct.

The changes have taken considerable time to come about. As a nation we have only gradually asserted our various maritime entitlements under international law. In 1979 a 200 nautical mile fishing zone was established. In 1983 certain territorial sea baselines were proclaimed. In 1990 the 12 nautical mile territorial sea was proclaimed in place of the previous three nautical mile territorial sea. We have really had only two areas of dispute in the past, but they have been resolved through cordial discussion and over time they have developed into mature relationships.

Why make the changes now? In areas such as the Pacific Ocean we have never been faced with such strong environmental and commercial pressures as we face today. Those pressures arise through the practice of driftnet fishing, deep sea mining, the possible disclosure of nuclear and industrial waste, the safety of the vessels that traverse those waters, and the potential for damage to the Australian maritime environment and Australian facilities.

There is no doubt that the 1982 convention will provide a sounder basis for Australia to protect its economic interests in environment, fisheries and mineral resources. The convention will give added weight to Australia's various attempts to safeguard Australia's coastal and marine environment from unsafe ships or accidents at sea by application of the 200 nautical mile exclusive economic zone. Article 73(1) of the convention, in part, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The coastal State may, in the exercise of its sovereign rights to explore, exploit, conserve and manage the living resources in the exclusive economic zone, take such measures, including boarding, inspection, arrest and judicial proceedings, as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the laws and regulation adopted by it in conformity with this Convention.
Article 21(1), in relation to the laws and regulations of the coastal state relating to innocent passage, reads:
The coastal State may adopt laws and regulations, in conformity with the provisions of the Convention and other rules of international law—
and it is implied that they relate to the following—
(d) the conservation of the living resources of the sea;
(e) the prevention of infringement of the fisheries laws and regulations of the coastal State;
(f) the preservation of the environment of the coastal State and the prevention, reduction and control of pollution thereof . . .
(h) the prevention of infringement of the customs, fiscal, immigration or sanitary laws and regulations of the coastal State.
Article 21(4) reads:

Foreign ships exercising the right of innocent passage through the territorial sea shall comply with all such laws and regulations and all generally accepted international regulations relating to the prevention of collisions at sea.

Laws relating to incidents such as oil spills and the discharge of ballast water—that is, water that contains exotic species that are a threat to both our coastal and marine environments—could therefore be better enforced than they presently are, because the convention allows application of a state's laws within the exclusive economic zone. It is not unreasonable to say that unsafe ships could be seen as a threat to the environment of a coastal state and a threat to the sanitary laws of a state, accepting that any action taken against a ship would not contravene other international conventions.

PARA.TAB: In this respect, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure has played a very important part. The report about ship safety that was tabled in this House in December 1992 has had a major impact on international action in this respect. The response to that report and its recommendations from across the world has been very positive. For the remainder of the life of this parliament, the committee is inquiring into a reference given by Senator Collins a few months ago. The task before the committee has the support of both sides of the House. It has the support of all of the industry, the trade unions and the people using those services within Australia, and it also has extensive support internationally. It is to Australia's credit that the Australian government has responded very positively to the recommendations of that inquiry. The response from abroad from all of the major players has been a very positive one.

The current edition of the International Bulk Journal, which is dated January 1994, reports upon the work of the committee and its continuing inquiry for the remainder of the life of this parliament. It notes that the committee will be writing to all those who made submissions to the previous inquiry, and we have done that. We have received an excellent response from most of those parties. The article reports that practice, operation, standard of safety on ships, training and all those other aspects that relate to ensuring the safe and innocent passage of ships through Australian waters will be covered by the committee. It also notes that, at my request, the International Bulk Journal will be contributing to the ongoing review. It is a great feather in the cap of Australia to have a major international journal covering all of those bulk carriers. It is those bulk carriers that we are essentially looking at and that have brought about many of the problems that have arisen.

Earlier I mentioned ballast water. The impact of ballast water on the seabed environment in Australia's bulk ports is a matter of serious concern. Australian authorities were quite slow to recognise and realise its potential for damage and what arises from the introduction of alien organisms. I first raised this issue in the House in a question on notice in 1979—some 15 years ago. The response I received at the time virtually brushed it aside. As is recorded on page 2620 of the Hansard dated 29 and 30 May 1979, I asked:
What specific precautions are taken to prevent any imbalance or contamination of marine ecology in Australia by the discharge of ships' ballast water taken on at foreign ports?

SPEECH.PARA: The answer that came back from Minister Nixon read:

PARA.TAB: Following investigation of this matter in 1975 by a Committee convened by my Department, the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account made funds available to NSW State Fisheries to investigate the effect of exotic organisms in ship's ballast water on the Australian marine environment. This investigation has been completed and a report is to be made to the Fishing Industry Research Committee. Further action will depend on the findings of that report.

SPEECH.PARA: When we raised that issue—and there was evidence of alien organisms in some of the major bulk ports in north-west Australia even at that time—it was brushed off as being some sort of fishing industry problem and it did not really matter.

PARA.TAB: It has taken a long time to get to the position where the industry has issued guidelines for the management of vessels. The industry, in consultation with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and the shipping, trading and fishing communities, has introduced its own voluntary guidelines for the discharge of ballast water. Those guidelines provide ship owners with a range of options to minimise the possibility of ballast water containing exotic species.

The guidelines apply to international ships arriving in Australia in ballast and seek to reduce the possibility of the introduction of alien species by encouraging a range of practices, including reballasting at sea, ballasting in deep water, disposal of sediments outside Australian ports, the non-discharge of water in Australian ports, participation in compliance arrangements and taking on ballast in agreed `clean' overseas ports. That has to be put into effect universally. There are ways and means of discharging water when the ships are well away from Australian waters or in waters where the temperature of the water and the organisms in the water are similar to what exists in Australian ports. Those actions could have been taken a long time ago had we been more alert to the nature of the problem.

I turn to the problems that exist with the passage of ships through Australian waters. The Australian government, through the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, is taking a much more effective role—arising from our committee's recommendations and report and from the minister's concern at the time—in respect of ships visiting Australian ports. In Australia in 1993, some 1,956 vessels were inspected. Of those 1,956 vessels, 1,350 had some form of defect. The range of defects varies from faulty fire appliances, faulty safety appliances and faulty lifesaving appliances to things such as rusted bulkheads, side shells of ships that have holes in them, faulty pumps, leakage, discharges and lifeboats that do not work. All of those defects are covered in those 1,350 ships. Of those 1,350 ships, some 75 were detained because their defects were of such a serious nature they could not be allowed to put to sea.

On top of that, Australia has been very much to the fore in the establishment of the Asia-Pacific port state inspection group. That group has met. We hosted the secretariat last year in Melbourne. The group met again in Tokyo in early December. Some 17 of the 18 Asia-Pacific nations signed up and the 18th country is expected to sign. We expect the formal ratification of the formation of the group to occur in April and services then to commence. Those Asia-Pacific group countries will share and exchange information electronically on ship defects, ship performance and all of the factors that contribute to the level of ship safety attaching to vessels and the manner in which that safety is practised.

We need to bear in mind, to get some sort of dimension on the potential for damage to Australian waters and Australia's environment, that in 1992 some 15,000 ships were operating in the Asia-Pacific region. By the year 2000—some six years hence—the new regional port state inspection service seeks to have 75 per cent of ships operating in the Asia-Pacific area inspected each year. They are the major steps flowing from the legislation before us. The legislation is extremely important, but the protection of the Australian maritime zones is even more important.

I am very pleased to see that the legislation before us has the support of both sides of the chamber. It recognises the problems in regard to ship safety and the point that I have been stressing about the discharge of ballast waters as an example of the damage that can be done to the Australian environment. Overriding that is the potential for catastrophe and major damage, as we saw with the near disaster of the Kirki in July of 1991 and the six iron ore ships that sank.

The provisions in this legislation were all advised to the state governments. Those who wanted to pursue the matters further have had meetings with our government. So there is no adverse comment about the legislation before us from the states. It is truly national legislation dealing with an international problem. In effect, the new maritime zones that are being provided for will bring Australia into line with its entitlements under international law. So we are not seeking something to which we are not entitled. The legislation brings us up to date, it brings us properly within the purview of international law and means that we will be able to manage and ensure our entitlements much better.

Potential economic advantage to Australia arises from this legislation, particularly with the adoption of the enhanced definition of the continental shelf. That and the development of the contiguous zone will ensure that we have sovereignty and control over that precious asset, our marine environment and the seabed. This legislation is the important tool to enable us to carry that out. I am pleased to support the legislation. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the debate on this important legislation, the Maritime Legislation Amendment Bill, I want to thank all those who have taken part in it. The bill has received support from both sides of the parliament, which I certainly appreciate. The bill probably has not had the amount of publicity and public interest that it deserves. Bipartisan support inevitably lowers the temperature of debate and, as such, the media is less likely to concentrate on it. In terms of Australia's national and commercial interests and of maritime safety, as the previous speaker, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), has said, this is important legislation.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to delay the House for a considerable period this morning, but a couple of matters have been raised by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams), the shadow Attorney-General, to which I want to respond. In a thoughtful and sensitive contribution, he raised three issues on which he sought a response and clarification from me. Those matters are as follows. Firstly, there were the issues raised by Senator Coulter and Senator Margetts in the Senate debate concerning this legislation and the effect of the international convention of 1982 on Australia's policies of ecologically sustainable development. I can but give him the same response and assurances that Senator Collins gave on those issues in the Senate, and that is that the government believes that the convention is not in contradiction of Australia's policies of ecologically sustainable development and, as such, there is no point of conflict. Therefore, the basic premise of those issues raised in the Senate by those two senators is not valid.

The honourable member for Tangney then raised concerns that he had about the position of the states arising out of the constitutional agreement of 1979 in relation to the rights of the states vis-a-vis the seas and submerged lands, et cetera. I can simply say to him in response, as probably one of only two people still in this parliament now who were actively involved in the negotiations over those agreements between the states and the Commonwealth, that it is certainly not the intention of the Commonwealth that those agreements should be abrogated by this legislation in any way. I can give him an assurance that, if any problems of that sort emerge, the Commonwealth would certainly move to resolve any difficulties that arose.

The final point that the honourable member for Tangney raised was a concern about the possibility that Australian law, once this bill becomes an act, would be in breach of international law. He made that comment on the basis of his knowledge that the 1982 Convention on the Law of the Sea had not yet come into effect because only 59 countries had ratified it. I can now tell him that, following the deposit of the 60th instrument of ratification of the convention by Guyana on 16 November 1993, the convention will come into effect one year from that date—on 16 November 1994. As such, our prospects of being in technical breach of international law should be removed as a real issue.

The only other matters that I want to address which have been raised by some honourable members are concerns as to why Australia has not at this stage ratified the 1982 convention. Of course, the coming into force of the convention will be a step in the direction of Australia ultimately ratifying the convention and this bill represents a significant further step in that direction. Nevertheless, there are issues to be resolved before Australia will be in a position to ratify the convention. The major issue is that relating to part 11 of the convention—that is the part relating to the deep seabed mining regime. That part of the convention, unlike most other parts, does not represent customary international law and it has been the source of continuing disagreement between developing and developed countries.

However, there has been a series of negotiations conducted under the auspices of the Secretary-General of the United Nations aimed at reaching a resolution to the impasse over part 11. The latest round of those negotiations is taking place in New York right now. Australia has played a key role in these negotiations and progress to date has been good. A satisfactory outcome to those negotiations will encourage developed countries to become parties to the convention and thus achieve a convention of more universal application. On the domestic front, the government is examining whether any further action needs to be taken before Australia is in a position to become a party to the convention. As I indicated earlier, the adoption of this legislation represents a major step in that direction.

This legislation will reap benefits for Australia. These will not only be in the form of potential resources of the exclusive economic zone and of an enlarged continental shelf, but also be in the form of increased enforcement rights. These enforcement rights will be available to be used to protect Australia's marine environment and our marine resources. I am sure that point is of interest to the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris).

In conclusion, I say to the House that this is an important piece of legislation; one which I am sure that in future years will be a matter referred to not infrequently. I believe that when this legislation comes into effect, Australia's continental shelf and contiguous zone will be better protected. We will have taken the full available strength of international law and that is certainly what we as a government should be doing in the interests of protecting Australian rights.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Duncan) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 15 December, on motion by Mr Tickner:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The future of higher education in Australia, as is post-secondary education generally, is a matter of great significance for all Australians. I welcome the opportunity this debate gives to consider some of the future directions for Australia's university system. The coalition will not oppose the provisions of this bill. We do not oppose legislation just for the sake of doing so. A number of the provisions in this bill make sense, particularly those relating to better tax file number administration in respect of the higher education contribution system and the removal of the HECS liability for some AIDAB sponsored students from overseas. These are sensible and equitable refinements of legislation passed previously by this parliament.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, the bill translates into legislation elements of the government's higher education policy agenda. I must say that some of these elements give us some cause for concern. While not opposing the passage of this bill, I cannot let these concerns go unremarked. My concerns include aspects of the government's provision for future growth in the higher education system, the allocation of new undergraduate places in 1996 and the need to top up university funding to make allowance for the financially detrimental effect of the government's superannuation guarantee levy. In relation to the motion that this bill be read a second time, I take this opportunity to move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)expresses its concern that no provision has been made in the amended operating grant amount for 1996 for the allocation of new undergraduate places in Victoria; and
(2)calls on the Government to ensure that the criteria underlying the allocation of new funded student places are applied consistently and equitably across the States and Territories".

Clause 6 of the bill amends the total operating grants available under section 17 of the Higher Education Funding Act to tertiary institutions in 1994, 1995 and 1996. The total grant for 1996 as provided in the bill includes the provision of $13.1 million for the creation of around 1,500 new undergraduate places in that year. I note the overall number of Commonwealth funded student load targets will, according to the report Higher education funding for the 1994-1996 triennium, rise from a total of 403,290 effective full-time student units in 1994 to 415,850 units in 1996. These totals include both undergraduate and postgraduate places.

PARA.TAB: I also note the government's view is that the university sector has reached or is reaching the limits of its growth. I will return to that point later. In November 1993, the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training, now the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), announced on behalf of the Commonwealth new criteria for the allocation of Commonwealth funded places. It is worth noting that this announcement was not made in this parliament, although very few announcements are now made in this parliament; it was made to a gathering at the University of Melbourne. The minister announced a principal criterion and a number of secondary criteria.

The principal criterion is that the funded places should be directed to areas of high population growth and low tertiary education participation. The secondary criteria include links with industry, innovation in modes of delivery, the extent to which agreed school leaver targets and undergraduate targets have been met, equity group success rates, graduate employment outcomes and the quality of higher education provision.

These criteria at first glance look innocent enough, but in reality they are a recipe for expanded Commonwealth government control over the direction of Australian higher education and they are another stick to force or compel universities into producing not diversity but a certain sameness. It looks to the performance of universities and it looks to intrude into the ability of universities to manage their own destinies. These criteria favour those institutions which toe the Commonwealth policy line.

The potential for intrusion is increased by the very vagueness of some of these criteria. What do we mean, for example, by `quality of higher education provision'? Does it mean good teaching, outstanding research or effective service to the community? What role will the government's university watchdog, the Committee for Quality Assurance in Higher Education, have in relation to the exercise of this criterion?

What of `graduate employment outcomes'? What is a satisfactory employment outcome for the purpose of allocating funding and growth amongst universities? Research into unemployment shows that graduates as a whole group do have a better chance of being in employment than other groups in the community. But in the current economic times we have the phenomenon of graduate garbage collectors, highly trained men and women—often with high expectations—who simply are not able to get work in an area that their training has prepared them for. Can it seriously be argued by the government that a university which simply turns out graduates who get jobs, regardless of what those jobs are, can in fact be doing well enough to earn it brownie points which can be used by the government to determine that it, university A, gets another 100 places while university B does not? My feeling is that such outcomes are the responsibility not of the universities that produce the graduates but of the economic circumstances into which they graduate.

My overall point about these allocative criteria which influence provisions of this bill and the government's future funding directions is that the minister, in exercising his powers of determination under the Higher Education Funding Act, will have a greater capacity for arbitrary decision making than previously. This does not seem to me to be a prescription for consistent and equitable allocation of resources under the present funding model; nor will it give our universities the confidence to make long-term plans for their future growth, which I thought was the very premise of the government's triennium based funding.

The government will argue that it is the source of most university funding and as such these criteria are eminently justifiable, but this is also a government which has made much out of the desirability of fostering diversity in the higher education system. To quote the government's own 1993 higher education budget statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The government has put in place a funding and accountability framework which has increased institutional autonomy by providing maximum scope for each institution to allocate resources in accordance with its role and mission.
How things can change between August and January! Does the government not believe its own rhetoric or is it simply trying to exert greater control over the higher education system?

PARA.TAB: These allocation criteria fly in the face of the government's own lip-service to diversity and autonomy. Who is ultimately responsible for determining whether these criteria have been satisfied? The answer is simple: the central funding authority; that is, the minister and the department. Clearly, the government does not trust, nor will it allow, our universities to make the right decisions when it comes to their own allocation of resources. I would have to say that, on the other hand, I do not trust DEET to make the same decisions either.

Through a succession of ministers since the 1988 white paper, the government has developed a planned approach to higher education that runs completely contrary to local flexibility and autonomy. The annual profiles process where load targets and the government's priorities are put to the universities typify this centrally driven approach. This so-called negotiation involves universities going up or down five places in any faculty and in the end being told what they are allowed to do. There is no diversity there whatsoever.

I am particularly concerned about the government's criterion for the meeting of school leaver and postgraduate enrolment targets. The imposition of school leaver quotas is a short-sighted and cynical attempt by the government to manipulate enrolment outcomes to hide the failure of its own policy. Throughout its term in office, it has encouraged an expectation of higher education amongst young Australians which the system cannot meet effectively under the present constraints imposed by the government. Rather than reap the whirlwind of its own up-beat rhetoric, the government is now seeking to force universities to set a proportion of school leavers or accept the financial consequences of not doing so, while at the same time actively discouraging as many school leavers as possible from pursuing the university option.

In imposing this quota, the government is denying effective equality of access to higher education for the very large group of mature age applicants. This particularly affects older women in our community. It obviously has not learnt the lesson of its rightly failed attempt to discourage mature age students from participating by imposing double HECS on those wishing to undertake a second undergraduate qualification.

In 1994, and I expect for the remainder of the life of this government, universities will be compelled to give priority treatment to school leavers even if their tertiary entrance scores may not necessarily be as good as those of mature age applicants who are competing for the same places. This seems especially absurd, as the evidence of 1994 first round offers indicates a drop in demand for undergraduate places across Australian higher education. This so-called affirmative action for school leavers runs counter to the government's own established principle of—to use the title of its 1990 discussion paper on higher education equity—a fair chance for all. It is not a fair chance for mature age students. It is also not a fair chance for kids who make a mistake.

I notice that the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the National Union of Students, two organisations that often do not share a common view, have come out and criticised the school leaver quota and its effect upon the prospects of mature age applicants for university places. Unlike the government, the coalition sees academic merit alone as the basis for university entrance. All Australians, regardless of age or experience, who can satisfy requirements should have a chance to compete on equal terms for places available. As the government's higher education budget statement argues, there should be a balance between the autonomy of our universities in respect of their own affairs and the public's expectation that the taxpayers' dollar is spent effectively. It is clear that the government has yet to find the balance.

As well as mature age students, the second group that will be disadvantaged by this legislation are students who make a mistake and who wish to seek to transfer between faculties. They will be caught up in this as well. It will be much more difficult for a student who wishes to move from one faculty to another. This will mean that people will be locked into degrees that, after some experience, they may find themselves not suited to. It is contrary to logic and many will find it unfair.

As I mentioned at the outset, the bill provides funding for around 1,500 new undergraduate intakes in 1996, the final year for the 1994-96 funding triennium. These places represent the first application of the government's new allocative criteria. In this respect, the government report entitled Higher education funding for the 1994-96 triennium makes interesting reading. The report, which I stress is separate from the bill, presumes to allocate these places between the states as follows: Queensland, 370; New South Wales, 350; Western Australia, 200; Australian Capital Territory, 30; and Victoria, none. The Australian Catholic University, which has campuses in New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria and the ACT, will receive 50 new undergraduate places for its New South Wales and Queensland campuses. Frankly, it amazes me that Victoria has done so badly in this carve-up.

The Higher education funding for the 1994-96 triennium report states that the growth of funded intakes, undergraduate and postgraduate, plus funding for continuing students in the triennium for the two biggest states, New South Wales and Victoria, will be 2,020 and 995 places respectively, or a ratio of more than two to one. To add insult to the Victorian injury, the government proposes to make no new additional undergraduate places available to Victorian universities in 1996, compared to 350 for New South Wales, and has frozen Commonwealth funding support for new campus development at Berwick, for Monash University, and Lilydale, for Swinburne University. On the other hand, substantial new developments are being funded at Coffs Harbour, for Southern Cross University; and Albury, for Charles Sturt University.

If the government's principal allocation criteria for supporting new growth is based on regions which have high population growth and low higher education participation, I find it hard to fathom why New South Wales has received a larger share of new places, largely directed to the University of Western Sydney and these new campus developments, while Victoria, which also has a rapidly developing outer suburban region, has scored no new places in 1996 whatsoever. My colleague the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) will have more to say about this later. I know that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean), who is at the table, does know where Berwick is, so I cannot suggest he does not.
