But if he goes out there and has a look at the rapidly changing population, the expansion and the demand he cannot help but think the outer eastern metropolitan region of Melbourne has some of the most educationally disadvantaged areas in Australia. Yet Victoria gets nothing.

It is also interesting to observe that in the period 1986 and 1991, between two censuses, the rate of population growth in Victoria was 6.1 per cent. It outstripped that of New South Wales, which was 5.6 per cent. Could it possibly be that the University of Western Sydney, if I may use an example, just happens to serve an area that has been of more than considerable political importance to the government of late? The government's stark denial of any additional new undergraduate places to Victoria, a state which the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee has demonstrated to have the highest level of unmet demand in 1993, seems to me to have a certain political dimension about it. The Kennett government is no friend of the Keating government and, unlike its New South Wales counterpart, is not facing an election until the end of 1996. At any rate, Labor's treatment of the Victorian electorate, which gave it such generous support last March, seems cavalier and fickle—and we will certainly be making this point many times subsequently.

One is tempted to ask whether the government has developed another funding formula whereby the number of university places to be allocated to a state or region are indirectly proportional to the short-term political benefit of the government. I know the minister keeps better records than the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly), but we would certainly like to know the exact basis on which these allocations were made.

In the Melbourne University speech of the former minister, he indicated the government's belief that the limits of Commonwealth funded growth in the higher education system are being reached. It seems that it is time to turn the government's attention to developing opportunities in the TAFE sector. The implication of the minister's speech at the time for this bill and for future funding decisions is that the government can fund no more and, therefore, the university system can grow no more. That is a false premise.

There is still the capacity for provision of further university places, particularly undergraduate places, regardless of the government's capacity or willingness to fund them. The government should look at a fair and efficient way of giving universities the maximum opportunity to deliver as many undergraduate places as their resources permit them to offer, whether or not these places are funded by the Commonwealth. The coalition believes that using this capacity is an essential part of maximising access to higher education opportunities for all Australians.

To this end, I call on the government to review its knee-jerk opposition to the practical and sensible measure of allowing universities to charge Australian residents who are willing and able to pay full fees for available undergraduate places on campus and thereby allowing universities to use that revenue to improve the quality of their facilities and services. The government has allowed a measure of freedom for universities to charge for a range of postgraduate courses; it allows vice-chancellors to charge non-sponsored overseas students full fees. It now allows Australian students open learning and permits the Open Learning Agency, to charge fees for the courses offered under its umbrella. Quite frankly, it is hard to see the logical distinction between opening learning and university campuses or between overseas students buying an additional place and Australian students buying an additional place. This has been in the too-hard basket.

The other aspect of the bill on which I wish to comment briefly is the provision—clause 7—of an additional $51.7 million over the next three years to universities to assist them to meet their obligations under the government's superannuation guarantee levy. I draw attention to this provision as an illustration of the cost burden imposed on employers by the levy. It is fortunate for the universities that they have the government handy to pick up the tab for their additional expenses after 1 July. Many thousands of small business employers around Australia do not have the same luxury. We have been told by the government that this is not an impost on business; we have a bill here putting the lie to that.

As I stated at the outset, the coalition does not oppose the financial and procedural provisions of this bill. This does not, however, remove our concern about the increasing centralism of the government's administration of higher education funding and resource allocation. I certainly call on the new Minister for Employment, Education and Training to take the opportunity to ask some very pointed questions of his portfolio advisers about the operation of the government's higher education funding mechanisms, and to consider the full consequences of the aspects of the government's policy which underlie this bill. I particularly invite the minister to provide to this parliament full details of the new decision making process which led to the somewhat baffling allocation of the new undergraduate places in 1996.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

—The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1993 seeks to amend the Higher Education Amendment Act 1988. It will increase student places and amend the act to promote greater efficiency and effectiveness in higher education and improve the operation and administration of the higher education contribution scheme.

PARA.TAB: When we look at the history of the higher education sector in this country, we see some great contrasts between the major parties in the ways in which they have been able to promote and develop the sector. The 1983 election of this government marked the beginning of the most significant reform and expansion of higher education in Australian history. The system has become accessible to more Australians from a wider variety of backgrounds and more effective in meeting Australia's changing social and economic needs. The main thrust of the structural reform that has been instigated by the government has been to provide a national integrated and accountable higher education sector.

The record of the government as opposed to the coalition could not be more different. Between 1976 and 1981, while the coalition was in government, the total resources available to higher education institutions fell every year, whereas every year since our election we have increased the total resources available to the sector from just over $3 billion in 1983 to around $4 1/2 billion this year. Over the period 1983 to 1992, higher education enrolments increased by 60 per cent. We now have the second highest expenditure per student relative to per capita GDP in the OECD.

The equivalent of 12 new universities have been created since we came to office. Our tertiary education sector now has the highest share of total education expenditure in the OECD, some 36 per cent, compared with the OECD average of about 28 per cent. We now have some 580,000 people studying in our higher education institutions out of a population of 17.6 million people, giving a total population ratio of about 3.3 per cent. If we compare this with the United Kingdom where the percentage of population in higher education is 1.28 per cent, we can begin to see the level of commitment of this government to the education of its people.

However, not only has the size of the sector radically increased but also the way in which these resources have been deployed could not be more different than that advocated by the coalition prior to the last election. Money has not simply been thrown at the sector in the hope that it will do the right thing of its own volition. The creation of the unified national system by the government has opened up social and economic opportunities that the system could never have done in an integrated, accountable and accessible way if left to its own devices.

The government has and will continue to set and implement agendas within our education system and will continue to take responsibility for this—one of the most fundamental areas of social policy. This bill builds on that record by increasing funding, providing more student places and with justified amendments to existing programs.

I want to deal with several amendments to this bill. First of all, there are more student places—an additional 1,500 undergraduate student places—requiring $12.9 million in 1996, increasing to $35.2 million in 1999. Five hundred places will be jointly funded with industry. This will bring the total of new places from 1989 to 1998 to over 100,000.

The amendments also provide for supplementary superannuation grants to ensure that money is available to honour superannuation guarantee levy commitments. This will lead to $23.276 million being required in 1994, $12.931 million in 1995 and $15.518 million in 1996. The superannuation guarantee is a key part of the government's broader social policy in relation to the aged and the longer term commitment to ensure that our society provides for retired people in a way which will not severely impact on the taxpayers of the next century.

Redundancy payments are also covered in the amendments. As the sector becomes more efficient and outcome oriented, institutions have identified excess staff. Assistance with redundancy payments is necessary to ensure that the changes that must be made are properly funded. This is essential to ensure that the workers affected by these changes, often through no fault of their own, are taken care of in a compassionate and understanding fashion.

The open learning initiative, OLI, is also covered in the amendments. The open learning initiative will provide choice, flexibility and a previously unachievable economic and social freedom to many thousands of Australians. One of the more important things about the funding of OLI and the infrastructure it requires is that the nature of OLI means that there are few of the geographical constraints associated with conventional campus based education. There are many people within the electorate of Corinella who, as a result of this important initiative, will now have access to an education that otherwise would never have been possible.

The government has already committed itself to support the OLI by spending over $52 million in the 1993-95 period. These adjustments are required due to unforseen minor problems in the implementation stage. This bill will adjust the original funding estimates for each year while maintaining the overall funding commitment. I lived in country Victoria as a kid. If one lived at home in the country there was absolutely no access to higher education. Many people in the electorates represented by honourable members in this chamber will now have the potential, unheard of in the past, to access higher education and to improve their skills and employability.

Another amendment relates to the non-inclusion in a student's course load of work experience in industry. The Higher Education Funding Act 1988, as currently drafted, has led to differing interpretations as to what is encompassed in work experience in industry. Some more unscrupulous institutions have charged HECS to students when there was little or no cost to the institution in administering a work experience program. This has the effect of not only charging students for a service they have not received but also, by tying up student places, denying places to others who deserve them. This basically provides an unjustifiable windfall to the institution.

The amended section clarifies the situation. If work outside the institution is deemed to be work experience in industry, it is not considered to be part of the student's course load and, therefore, not subject to HECS. When institutions do not provide or pay for supervision of a student's work in industry, that work is not counted as part of a student's load. The amendment provides for guidelines to further assist institutions to classify work experience units.

Another amendment covers the question of overseas aid students with New Zealand citizenship. Some overseas students from Pacific island countries are entitled to New Zealand citizenship and, therefore, are liable to pay HECS under the act. An administrative difficulty arises when such students are fully funded under an Australian International Development Assistance Bureau program. As AIDAB pays tuition fees on behalf of these students, it is agreed that such students should be treated as HECS exempt. This amendment exempts these students from HECS.

Another amendment relates to certain information being provided to students on enrolment. This amendment will tighten up the administration of the HECS scheme so that the risk to Commonwealth revenue is reduced. Requiring students to be provided with information will also reduce the risk of students who may have little experience with the tax system inadvertently avoiding tax. OLI students will be on the same footing as conventional students in terms of HECS payments.

As a result of changes to the publication of guidelines in the Gazette, rather than the full guidelines being published, copies of the guidelines will now be provided to institutions and peak bodies, and notification will occur in the Gazette as to where any guideline alterations can be accessed. I want to contrast these changes, which are about finetuning a system which is working, to the situation of the Liberal Party. As I understand it at the moment, the Liberal Party has no policy—Fightback is gone; the voucher system is up in the air—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait till I talk. You will get some policies.

—I am sure I will. The fact is that those opposite do not have a policy at the moment, and I await with interest the contribution of the honourable member for La Trobe. But the Liberal Party's voucher system would have no doubt led to everyone paying fees. It would have been a version of market madness. Social policy would have been in the hands of vice-chancellors and we would have been leaping into the unknown in the higher education sector. Again, I contrast what we have done while in government with the record of the Liberal Party when it was in government. Under the Liberals there was stagnation in the sector and there were difficulties with outcomes. We had planned to be the clever country but in fact we were not clever at all. As I said, we await further developments as to the Liberal Party's policy.

PARA.TAB: I raise another issue regarding the future of the sector. As Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley)—speaking about access to courses across Australia and the allocation of places—said that we had historically high levels of participation and that we needed to ensure equity throughout Australia. He contrasted the situation of Victoria, which has the highest participation rate in higher education but the lowest population growth, with Queensland, which has a low participation rate and the highest population growth. I am sure that the shadow parliamentary secretary, the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), would be concerned about access to higher education in Queensland.

This issue must be addressed, but the question of access and equity must also be addressed within the states. In growth areas such as mine and that of the honourable member for La Trobe many young people deserve access to higher education, but we represent areas where that has not been the case. There have been developments on that front, and I note the work of the honourable member for La Trobe on the Berwick campus for Monash University. There will be a campus for Monash University there. New technology will be used to open up access to, and to extend the existing boundaries of, that institution. We are making a start on ensuring that our region has access to higher education in the area. That is essential.

The question of equity within the states is a key issue. Notwithstanding the start of the Berwick campus, more has to be done to ensure access and equity in growth areas. In looking at growth we have to make comparisons not only between the states but also between areas within states. Demographic changes and population growth in places such as Melbourne need to be taken into account when places are allocated within the system.

As I said before, the higher education sector in this country has expanded massively under a Labor government. It moved forward over the 1980s to confront the needs and aspirations of the Australian community. That, in itself, has brought problems. The unprecedented levels of growth have led to demand increasing at an even greater rate. We have to face that problem, but this government is eminently more capable of facing that problem than are those opposite. Our record in higher education, regardless of some of the problems that have occurred, is far superior to theirs. Over the last 10 years we have expanded the sector, set guidelines and produced outcomes which are in line with the needs of country. I feel that we are much better able to face the challenges of the 1990s. I am confident that we will face them and meet them.

This bill is part of a revision of aspects of the legislation as it presently operates which will improve the legislation so that it is more able to meet the needs of the community in relation to higher education in a fair and more justifiable way. Our commitment in this area is clear; the neglect of those opposite in this area is also clear. I believe that as we move forward with an improved system and with the increase in places outlined in this bill we will be better placed to march up to the year 2000 with a better, competitive higher education sector. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a pretty dry old argument so far in the debate on the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill. Let us see if we can liven it up a bit. I welcome the new Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) into his portfolio. I acknowledge the fact that he is in the House participating in and listening to this debate. I hope he takes cognisance of a few of my remarks.

PARA.TAB: The bill makes adjustments to HECS. I have no problems with the adjustments to HECS. I note that HECS was an ALP government initiative; it was not an opposition initiative. It imposes charges on students and the object of the exercise is to shift some of the public funding of university places to private individuals.

We all know that the benefits of education really serve us in three ways. Firstly, they serve to benefit the individual undertaking the education. Secondly, they serve to benefit the nation overall in that a higher educated and more literate population is better able to participate in today's society. Thirdly, they serve to benefit industry, business and commerce throughout the nation. All three factors should contribute to some extent. HECS makes that possible.

The issue I want to talk about in this bill is not explicit but rather implicit; that is, the division of funding from 1996 onwards to the various states. I have to say that Victoria has been well and truly raped. The honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin) talked broadly and widely about the terrific job this government has done in funding higher education places, yet he has abrogated his responsibility today to his constituents. They are the ones that are going to suffer as a result of the cut in growth to new funded places and the absolute cut to Victoria from 1996 onwards.

The fact is that the statement the former Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) made in November at the University of Melbourne means that from 1996 to the year 2000—or to the year 3000; who knows—there will be no growth funding for new places for higher education students in Victoria. That is an absolute nonsense. It is inequitable, it is unfair and it is discriminatory.

Victoria is a proud state and has a proud history. Part of that pride derives from the fact that, over many years, long before the Commonwealth took over funding of tertiary education, Victorians spent their money privately and through state taxes to develop a substantial university network and a system of colleges of advanced education throughout the state of Victoria. They may not all have been put in exactly the right places and they may not all have been designed to do exactly the right things, but, by golly, Victorians put their money where their mouths were. They devoted money and assets to the higher education sector.

But now this government is going to make Victoria pay because it was successful in the past in building a university sector. That is not very fair. The shift by this government into technical and vocational education and training is appropriate. I have said that many times in this place and out of it. I have steadfastly fought for an increasing place in the sun for that sector of advanced education and that sector even within our school system because I believe we will be best served by concentrating resources in that area.

But what this government fails to recognise is that all of the funding for higher education need not come from the public purse. It can come from private individuals. It can come from industry. It can come from all sorts of sources. But because this government so

SPEECH.PARA: tightly controls the education sector through the profiling process and through the massive Department of Employment, Education and Training, we have a few people in Canberra determining whether or not students on the ground in my electorate will have access to university places.

PARA.TAB: We are shifting funds to technical and vocational education. The government is now saying—or at least the former Minister for Employment, Education and Training said—that we cannot afford many more additional new places in the tertiary sector. The problem is that Australians still want more places. Every year there are more Australians who want to go to university than there are places available. In 1993, approximately 35,000 young Australians were denied a place at university despite the fact that they had finished their schooling with qualifications that should have given them a place.

Why were they denied that place? Government funds are limited. I accept that we cannot keep asking taxpayers to fund students' university education forever. But we allow the universities some flexibility to charge full fees to overseas students. The rules as they stand at the moment say that a person who is born in Australia is disadvantaged. If you are one of the 35,000 who is unable to find a place, you do not go, that is it. You are out; you are finished; no university degree for you. There is no access to university for you to try to improve your education. You cannot even pay for the place. Even if you are willing to go out and work part time, if your parents have the money to support you, if you are willing to go to the bank and borrow the money, if you are willing to use HECS entitlements and turn that into students loans, you are unable to do that because the federal government says you cannot.

You are disadvantaged because you are an Australian. Because you were born here and you hold an Australian passport you are discriminated against. If you were born in Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan, China, the United States, England or Germany, you can go to university in Australia, but not if you are an Australian, not if you are one of 35,000 who missed out.

Is that fair or equitable? The government has got to be kidding. The honourable member for Corinella talked about equity and access. There is no equity without access. How can there be? The government brought in HECS. It allows the overseas students to pay full fees and requires Australian students to pay part fees but then stops at that point and says, `No more'.

Let us look at Victoria because that is really what this issue is all about. Historically Victoria has supported the higher education sector. Now we are being discriminated against because we built universities and we built up university places. There are a number of significant points that relate to Victoria and relate to this issue that I hope the minister will take away from this debate and take into account when reconsidering the decisions made by the prior minister.

Firstly, unmet demand is higher in Victoria than it is in other states. But the former minister said that, notwithstanding that there was unmet demand, other states had priority because their participation rates were lower. I do not see the sense in that at all. In 1993 the unmet demand in Victoria represented approximately 15,000 of the 35,000 or 36,000 students who could not find places. Not quite half of the total number of students in Australia who wanted university places and could not get them were from Victoria. How are we going to fix that problem? We are going to say, `In 1996, there will be no more new places whatsoever'. All that will do is exacerbate the problem. We cannot legislate to tell people that they do not want to go to university. This is a free market, free enterprise democracy.

It is true that the participation rate is higher in Victoria than it is in other states. That is largely due to history. But that trend has continued. For decades, the participation rate in Victoria has been the highest. We are now, by government fiat, going to attempt to modify that. We are going to attempt to lower the participation rate in Victoria, artificially, by withdrawing funding. That is brilliant; there is no equity in it whatsoever. It makes absolutely no sense.

I would maintain that the higher participation rate in Victoria reflects the occupational aspirations of Victorians. It reflects the fact that our young people have been brought up with the expectation that, if there is any opportunity to do so, they should make an attempt to go to university; they should make an attempt to further their education. Also, the range of occupations that is available in Victoria is different from what it is in New South Wales, Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania and South Australia. DEET in Canberra cannot determine by fiat that it will socially engineer Victoria to, all of a sudden, have a different range of occupations that does not require higher education degrees as qualifications for entry into the labour market.

Victoria pays more HECS so, on average, students in Victoria are paying more private fees to the federal government for university education than corresponding students throughout the nation. Victoria accounts for approximately 25 per cent of the national enrolments, which means that it pays approximately 25 per cent of the HECS fees; but only 21 per cent of the growth is funded to Victoria by the Commonwealth. That is inequitable.

I draw the attention of the House to the fact that, since October 1982, the Victorian government has been prepared to put Victorian money into the growth of new places. In 1993, the Victorian government committed approximately $30 million and over the next five years it has committed approximately $120 million to state funded places in tertiary institutions. It is the only state in Australia to do that. How does the Commonwealth respond to that? It says that Victoria will have no new places.

The area covered by the electorates of Corinella and La Trobe has the lowest participation rate of tertiary students of any higher education district in Victoria. That has been true for some time. For the past 3 1/2 years, I have participated in a major battle to try to get a university campus in that area.

One reason why students from this area are disadvantaged is that the location of existing universities results in transportation problems. It is very difficult to get to Monash or to the University of Melbourne or to La Trobe or to Swinburne from Cranbourne, represented by the honourable member for Corinella; from Berwick, which I represent; from the Dandenongs. Heaven help those trying to get to Deakin in Geelong! It is a long and difficult two-way trip every day. That is one of the proven reasons why people in these areas do not participate as fully in higher education as those from other educational regions in the state.

We fought to have a new campus built in the centre of the growth region which students could get access to. In terms of the rate of growth in Australia, that growth corridor in the south-east of Melbourne is second only to that in the Gold Coast in Queensland. After a long and arduous battle, the federal government has agreed to have this new campus built; the state government has bought the land and it is under way. That is being done with capital funding of only $11 million, which has been capped by the previous minister.

I do not know whether the minister at the table knows what $11 million will buy today in terms of a school building, but I can tell him that three years ago the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, now the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin), opened the third stage of the library at the Burwood campus of Deakin University. I happen to have built the third stage of that library, which was worth $4.3 million. So $11 million will not get us very far with new campus infrastructure.

Monash is willing to spend part of its capital funding which is rolled in as part of its regular receipts from the Commonwealth. We are making every attempt to get industry to participate in that decision, to put in industry funds. Nonetheless, we desperately need reasonable amounts of starter capital. Monash has estimated that, to build a reasonable core for the university, with a library, administration building and enough classrooms and lecture theatres to make a decent start, it needs to invest about $30 million.

The location of this facility at Berwick is absolutely first-class. It represents a real first for Australia. The campus is adjacent to the brand new Dandenong College of TAFE which opened its doors late last year. Its first full year starts on 1 February. Eleven million dollars is only about a third of the total capital that we really need to make it work. Not only is this campus next to a TAFE college, but it is on a major national arterial road which has a set-down area right at the front of the campus. It is set on 158 prime acres in a beautiful location. Also, it is on the rail head. Students can get off at the Berwick rail station and walk directly to the campus in about five minutes. It is an excellent location which has everything going for it. It is in the centre of the second fastest growing region in Australia.

We will have no equity in the growth corridor to the south-east of Melbourne, centred on Berwick, until we have access. We need more capital funding and we definitely need to have reversed the dictum of last November by the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) that there will be no new growth places in Victoria from 1996 onwards. We need to have that reversed because we expect that 1996 will be the first year of operation of the Monash campus at Berwick. There are many plans for a broad range of courses at that campus and there are many students looking forward to that opening day, but we need reasonable facilities and we need the growth places. Monash is willing to transfer student load from its other campuses to Berwick in order to make this new enterprise work. I commend Monash for that.

I ask the federal government and DEET to take that carefully into account, because that shift of full-time student load places from Clayton, Caulfield and Frankston is important. If Monash is willing to shift places to Berwick, we need a bit of Commonwealth help. Putting all of the growth funding in Queensland might serve some political end but it serves no practical end, no equity end, for disadvantaged students in the south-east of Victoria.

To sum up, the problem I have with this bill today lies in what it does not say. I implore the minister to listen to my remarks and to make some response at some future time in the positive manner of which I know he, as a good Victorian, is capable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Deahm Ms M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to speak to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1993. I will particularly address myself to the additional 1,500 undergraduate student places created for the years 1996 to 1999. At a cost of $12.9 million in 1996, rising to $35.2 million in 1999, these additional places are a recognition by the government of continuing high demand for higher education places and significant regional shortages in the provision of higher education opportunities. This increase raises the total number of new places created by this government between 1989 and 1998 to over 100,000.

PARA.TAB: In recognition of the continuing success of the joint Commonwealth-industry additional funded places scheme, the growth funding for 1996 includes funds for the Commonwealth to contribute to the cost of providing 500 additional places under this scheme. The Commonwealth contribution for 1996 will be dedicated essentially to places for which industry support is drawn from the private sector.

The increased funding for higher education allocated by this bill brings the total higher education funding allocation for the 1994 to 1996 triennium to $14.8 billion. In 1996 the total annual funding for higher education will be over $5 billion, which represents an increase of 46 per cent in funding in real terms since the establishment of a unified national system of higher education in 1988. This level of spending is a clear indication of the government's ongoing commitment to the provision of higher education opportunities.

As I have said, this bill provides 1,500 additional student places for regions of high population growth and low tertiary education participation. Over the 1994-96 triennium, the Commonwealth will provide funding for 2,020 additional intakes and associated pipeline in New South Wales. In particular, growth will be directed to institutions that have a capacity and need to expand or that are developing new campuses. One such institution is the University of Western Sydney, part of which is located in my electorate. Growth in New South Wales, I am pleased to say, will be allocated primarily to the University of Western Sydney and other regional institutions with significant new campus developments.

In New South Wales, only the University of New South Wales and the University of Sydney have higher student loads than the University of Western Sydney. Even that gap is narrowing each year as government funded growth in student numbers at UWS continues to outstrip that of any other New South Wales institution.In 1996, 150 new intakes will be allocated to the University of Western Sydney. This is the highest allocation of places to any university and will bring the total of new intakes by the University of Western Sydney's total new intakes for the 1994-1996 triennium to 700. For 1996, the university will receive $154 million in operating grant funding for a total of 17,355 places.

The University of Western Sydney is in the greater western region of Sydney—and, more importantly, for the greater western Sydney region. It is rapidly becoming an integral part of the western Sydney community. It has made and continues to make significant contributions to that community, not just through access to higher education but also through community education and cultural interaction, as well as partnerships with the business community, industry and community organisations.

I am pleased to have a good working relationship with the University of Western Sydney. Since 1991 I have been a member of the university's community affairs committee, now the community affairs panel. Through that involvement and through regular campus visits I keep in close contact with the university.

As I mentioned before, one of the network members of the university is in my electorate. The University of Western Sydney, Hawkesbury, is based at Richmond. It was established in 1891 as the Hawkesbury Agricultural College and has a long and illustrious history. Hawkesbury still has a strong agricultural focus but, since becoming a college of advanced education in 1972 and then a founding member of the University of Western Sydney in 1988, Hawkesbury has dramatically expanded.

At the time of the establishment of the university, Hawkesbury had just under 2,000 enrolled students. It now has more than 4,000 undergraduate and postgraduate students. In 1993 its first PhD students graduated, both of whom were young women graduating in scientific subjects—a significant landmark. The expansion of which I speak, however, is much more than an increase in numbers and the introduction of postgraduate studies. More importantly, there has been a huge increase in the number of courses on offer, as well as significant research advances.

In the early 1970s, Hawkesbury offered only subdegree diplomas in agriculture, food technology and dairy technology to about 250 students, who were mostly male and all residential. In 1993 the 3,500 undergraduate and 500 postgraduate students were enrolled in courses such as agriculture, horticulture, social ecology, commerce, accounting and marketing, hospitality management, land economy, nursing, food science, food and nutrition, environmental health, biological and chemical sciences, and building. A Bachelor of Arts degree is being introduced to further broaden the academic profile.

Hawkesbury has also been actively involved in the recruitment of overseas full fee paying students. The number of international students now exceeds 230. In 1993 international student fees generated $2.8 million for UWS, Hawkesbury. It is estimated that these students injected a further $1.4 million into the local community. Hawkesbury's international students come from South-East Asia, Europe, north Asia, the Middle East, India, the Pacific islands, Africa and North America. The intellectual and cultural contributions to our community by these students are significant.

There has been rapid change and development at Hawkesbury in terms of research. External research funds received in 1993 totalled nearly $2.8 million. These funds are made up of Commonwealth competitive grants, research scholarships, money from the Cooperative Research Centre for Waste Management and Pollution Control, industry bodies, state and local governments and philanthropic foundations.

The highlights of Hawkesbury's research programs in 1993 included the awarding of the inaugural UWS Foundation Research Award to two Hawkesbury academics; the appointment of the first Foundation Professor of Agriculture, Farming Systems, Dr Peter Cornish; Australian Research Council funding to the School of Social Ecology to carry out a national study of EEO in public and private sector organisations; and funding from AIDAB's women in development fund small grants scheme.

The new college of technical and further education at Richmond will provide a new and exciting opportunity for UWS, Hawkesbury. Hawkesbury will be working closely with the TAFE at all levels and clearly will be a model for cooperation between educational institutions.

Hawkesbury's expansion is the result of this government's higher education initiatives. This bill is a part of the government's commitment to quality, diversity and broadening of access to higher education. The government is particularly concerned to ensure that funding is directed towards institutions such as the University of Western Sydney in regions such as the greater western region of Sydney.

Mr Deputy Speaker, 9.85 per cent of Australia's population resides in the greater western region of Sydney; that is 1.6 million people. It is expected that the population will exceed 2.06 million by the year 2001. By 1996 the greater western region of Sydney will have approximately 30 per cent of the population of New South Wales and 40 per cent of Sydney's population. Nearly one-third of New South Wales school students attend schools in the greater west. Yet the people of the greater western region of Sydney still only have access to eight university places per 1,000 people compared to 32 places per 1,000 in the rest of Sydney.

This government is doing something about this situation. This government established the University of Western Sydney in 1988 and since then has funded capital expenditure at the institution at much higher levels than funding for other institutions. We are now funding expansion of student numbers at UWS at an unprecedented level.

It must be said, however, that the needs of a growing university are substantially greater than those of the well-established older institutions. As I have mentioned, this government, in recognition of these needs, has provided funding for very significant capital development of all campuses of the university under the previous project based capital funding of higher education.

The new system of allocating capital funding as a component of the operating grant is logical and sensible. It will enhance institutional autonomy and place the responsibility for institutional resource management decisions more fully in the hands of the institutions.

For UWS there is a danger that capital allocation based on student load could halt that capital expansion of which we have been so proud. Under the roll-in system of capital grants, the University of Western Sydney will receive significantly less funding for capital development than it has received from the submission based, project by project funding over the last few years.

However, the government understands the concern of new, growing institutions and has established the capital development pool, the CDP. The University of Western Sydney will be allocated $2 million from the CDP in 1996 as part of a $6 million package from 1996 to 1998 in recognition of the continued high growth in enrolments.

In addition, the Commonwealth will allocate over $4 million over 1995-96 to the university if the proposed multi-sectoral education facility at the former HMAS Nirimba goes ahead. Continued commitments such as these and continued recognition of the special needs of new, growing universities by this government will ensure that the University of Western Sydney continues to meet the needs of the people of the greater western region of Sydney.
The mission statement of the university explains its role in the community. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The mission of the University is to provide excellence in higher education, research and associated community service within Greater Western Sydney.
The university's goals state:
The University will pursue its mission by:-
.Providing educational opportunities which enable students and staff to develop their potential as scholars, professionals and people
.Preserving, extending and applying knowledge through teaching, scholarship, research and practice
.Contributing to the scholarly, intellectual, cultural, social and economic development of the nation
.Interacting closely with and being accessible to the people, institutions, organisation and business of Western and South Western Sydney.

The university has gone a long way towards achieving that mission and meeting these goals. With the continued support from this government's programs, I have no doubt that this university will be universally recognised as the world class institution it already is.

PARA.TAB: I would like to conclude by referring to the speech given earlier by the opposition spokesman on education, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Dr Wooldridge). He made an allegation that the funding levels for the University of Western Sydney were politically based because this was Labor's heartland. I find this rather amazing because the University of Western Sydney, Hawkesbury, is based right in the state electorate of Hawkesbury which is held by the Liberal state government by about 20 per cent. He also stated that Victoria would have got more funding than western Sydney if Victoria had an election pending, as New South Wales has. I think what I have said already shows quite clearly the special needs of the University of Western Sydney. It has grown from nothing only a few years ago and is now serving the people of that area who had a very low participation in tertiary education. It is also working very closely with the community at all levels and at all political levels as well. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I applaud the vigour with which the honourable member for Macquarie (Ms Deahm) defends and advocates the interests of her own constituents, I have to take her to task for her criticism of the comments earlier in this debate by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge). The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) made a very full and good explanation of the reasons for the disquiet of the honourable member for Chisholm in relation to Victoria's tertiary education funding. Clearly, when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was referring to the funding of the University of Western Sydney, he was not referring only to the Hawkesbury campus.

PARA.TAB: From the time of the mooting of a University of Western Sydney quite some years ago, we have heard the arguments of disadvantage and access. That is a matter about which I shall say some more a little later in my speech. As well as supporting the opposition's point of view, I will take the opportunity to draw attention to the situation in my own electorate, which includes the Gold Coast campus of Griffith University. It is one of those amalgamation situations. If the honourable member for Macquarie would care to compare the number of places in tertiary education per head of population in her electorate with the number in mine, she would find that her electorate is indeed very advantaged. But I shall come to that later because I want to deal with it properly.

There are some aspects of controversy about this bill and there are some other aspects that are less controversial. I want to say at the outset that I welcome the appointment of the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) as the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. He was until recently in the chamber and I had indicated to him that I was going to comment on that in my speech. He then informed me that the MPI immediately after question time today deals with his portfolio so he has to be absent for a little while. The honourable member for Hotham has distinguished himself amongst the ministers of this government as being the only one who sits through debate on his bills—the only one who sits and listens to the second reading debate—whatever his portfolio has been.As somebody who has been involved in the education debate in this institution, both in this chamber and in the other place, for 20 years, I want to welcome the fact that we will have a minister who sits and listens to what is said.

There was a time when we had a debate about education in this parliament, where there was some to and fro, where there was not just a reading of set piece speeches and talking about parish pump issues, but that has long since gone. It died about the time of the appointment of the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) as the minister responsible for education. It has been a pretty sad debate in this chamber ever since; which is a pity.

My background was education. It was all education, one way or another, before I came into this place. I have been interested in pursuing the issue as a member of parliament, both as a senator and as a member of this chamber because, in my view, there is nothing more important once one has addressed issues of national security and economic wellbeing than education. I can give lots of reasons for that.

Events throughout the world in very recent years—the movement towards democracy by previously heavily suppressed people, a movement that I certainly would not have foreseen in its rapidity—have come about by making people literate. I believe that if people are allowed to read and write, to get access to information, the human spirit cannot be suppressed. I know both the honourable member for Macquarie and the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh), who is at the table, will not disagree with my next comment either. I think the biggest mistake men ever made in the suppression of women was allowing them to become literate—it is a mistake that certain other countries are not making yet, but the time will come—because education really is the key to the expression of the human spirit.

The terribly depressing aspect of what has happened both in education and in the education debate in this country in recent years, first under the Hawke government and now under the Keating government, has been the fettering of education and the moving towards suppression in an area that should be fraught of vitality. It was very depressing when the honourable member for Fremantle moved towards prescribing what universities should teach, when he as minister made certain value judgments in relation to where resources should be going, when he indicated a very strong preference for those who were concerned with technical aspects of solutions rather than theoretical aspects. I remember well that Vice-Chancellor Pennington, then chairman of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, had to point out to him that, for example, the cure for AIDS will be found through some very theoretical research of the very type that Minister Dawkins was then damning, not through technical devices. The attempt to fetter and direct universities in what is important, the limiting of access by students to post-secondary education in this country is a tragedy for such a young country.

The reason this country's economy has done as well as it has in the world, and the reason therefore its citizens have done as well as they have, is that we have had—compared with other countries—through our history a reasonably literate and highly skilled population. It is nonsense to say that we cannot compete with countries with cheap labour when we have workers who, because they are skilled and literate and can therefore pick up skills more easily, can produce much more effectively and efficiently than uneducated `coolie' labour—no racist overtones intended—of other countries.

Education is the key to so much in this country. I am of the generation which saw the education boom start, when tertiary education was no longer the preserve of just the rich—certainly my parents were not in that category; we were very ordinary folk indeed—when aspiration was what took you forward. The stifling of aspiration, the move to control in a variety of ways—including amalgamations, which particularly affected my own electorate—is a legacy we will live with for a long time. On another occasion—I could raise this matter under this bill because we are talking about tertiary funding—I shall say more about the subject of the structure we are stuck with at the moment and the problems that will inevitably come in the years ahead of us for educational output as a result.
The then minister, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), when presenting this bill to the House, made the statement on the HECS issue:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the measures relating to the amount of contributions stressed that as many Australians as possible should have access to higher education.

That is a very misleading statement. It should have been that as many Australians as is possible under this government's restrictive policies should have access to higher education. If as many Australians as is possible had access to higher education, we would have tens of thousands more in the system right now. The words he left out are `as economically possible under this government's restricted access'.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the record of education in Australia and the matter of access. Pre-1972, the system under which I was educated, we had a dual system—some free, some fee paying. We had Commonwealth scholarships, which paid all fees, and if people did not get a Commonwealth scholarship they could pay fees and attend university, with the possibility always that if their academic achievements were sufficiently good they could pick up one of those free places. In 1972 the Whitlam government was elected, not least on the promise of free education for everyone who was qualified.

The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) referred in his speech to the situation that used to obtain in Victoria and obtains now. The situation that obtained at the University of Queensland in 1972—Griffith University had just commenced at that time—was that any Queensland resident who qualified for entry to the university, or in other words had matriculated, could attend. There were no quotas on entry to the University of Queensland or to Griffith University. That was in distinction to a number of other Australian universities.

As soon as the free system came in, the University of Queensland was forced to introduce first year quotas. It had never had any under the previous system. It had burst at the seams, but Vice-Chancellor Schonell had a policy that those Queensland residents who qualified could apply to enrol and would be accepted. However, the free education system led directly to the imposition of quotas and restriction of entry for first year students into the University of Queensland.

In 1989 we not only got HECS fees, but we were still lumbered with the restrictions on numbers. The honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin) talked about the Liberal Party's policies and said, quite wrongly and incorrectly, how the Liberal Party was going to make all students fee-paying students. It is this Labor government which has made every tertiary student a fee-paying student. That is the simple situation, so the Labor government can no longer claim to be the government of free education.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member for Moncrieff will have leave to continue her speech when the debate is resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to today's balance of payments figures, which show a current account deficit of $1.7 billion for the month of December. The worst recession in 60 years was brought about by the government in order to solve the current account deficit problem. It put one million people out of work and reduced real wages and standards of living. How does the Treasurer intend to fix the current account problem without causing another interest rate driven recession?

—We get a one-month figure that is at the upper end of market expectations and the opposition calls on calamity. It is certainly true that the $1.7 billion figure for the month of December is at the upper end of market expectations, but that came after a series of figures which were running well below the levels for last year. One cannot just take one month's figures; they have to be looked at over a period. If we take the half year for this year against the half year for last year, we can see that we are doing slightly better than last year. The accumulated deficit for the six months to December 1992 was $8.86 billion. For the last six months to December 1993 it was $8.7 billion. So it is slightly less than it was last year. That is in a situation where the economy is growing faster.

PARA.TAB: As I said yesterday, the economy is expected to grow at 3 1/2 per cent per annum this year. Last year it grew at 2 1/2 per cent. We are looking at a slightly lesser current account deficit in the context of better growth performance by the economy.

So, in those circumstances, the figures on the current account are not cause for alarm. They should be a cause for some satisfaction in that we have been able to do better this year in absolute money terms, despite the fact that we have had faster growth of the economy. We have done better because we have had a 50 per cent fall in the net services deficit, which largely reflects increased tourism, and a fall in the net income deficit because of lower world interest rates.

This outcome is also very respectable in the circumstances that we face—that is, we have been growing at 3 1/2 per cent and the rest of the OECD area is growing at about one per cent. That is the comparison.

We are also trading with the Asian region, which is doing better than the OECD, and that is obviously a considerable help to us. But we have faced subdued world economic activity, and that is not a plus for exports. As a consequence of that, we have also had weak commodity prices. They are worse this year than last year. So, in those circumstances of reduced commodity prices, which are so important to our overall export performance, despite the ongoing broadening of our exports, we obviously face some problems. To have done better in those circumstances is commendable.

An important factor in our continuing overall growth of merchandise exports has been the fact that our elaborately transformed manufactures are continuing to grow strongly. A feature of the export scene in the last half a dozen years has been the growth of elaborately transformed manufactures. They have grown at 17 per cent in the last six months compared with the same six months of the previous year.

Despite all these points, the questions which have been raised by the honourable member for Mayo are: does a number like this mean that we may find some constraint on growth because of the balance of payments factor and will the current account deficit prevent us from having the kind of growth which will get us to much lower levels of unemployment? It is certainly true to say that, as we continue to grow, we must expect that imports will increase. A faster rate of economic growth will give us a faster rate of growth of imports, particularly as business investment picks up because that is more import intensive. So we must expect that.

On the other hand, there is reason for optimism on the export side. We are looking at a world which is expected to increase its level of economic activity considerably in the next couple of years. The OECD forecasts are for growth in the OECD region to grow from 1.1 per cent in 1993 to 2.1 per cent in 1994 and 2.7 per cent in 1995. That is obviously helpful to our export performance. In this morning's newspapers, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics forecasts that commodity prices will increase over the next few years by some 17 per cent between 1993-94 and 1998-99. If that were to take place, just with the same volume, that would increase the value of commodity exports by some $8 1/2 billion.
We are also much more internationally competitive now than we were a few years ago. We improved by over 20 per cent compared with 1989-90.

TALK.START.PARA: —The dollar is rising. When the commodity price is high the dollar goes up.
—Despite the fact that there has been some appreciation of the dollar recently, that remains the case. The competitiveness is not all driven by depreciation of the dollar.
—It is a real depreciation.

—It is a real depreciation because we have had reductions in our relative unit labour costs. Our labour costs relative to those of other countries have been falling. That has given us a real depreciation and, therefore, a real increase in our competitiveness.

PARA.TAB: We have also had rapidly growing exports of manufactured goods, as I have mentioned. It is also important to realise that our debt servicing ratio—that is, our capacity to service our debt—has been improving quite rapidly in recent times. In 1989-90 that ratio—that is, the interest on foreign debt compared with total exports—was 21 per cent. In September 1993, which was the last figure I could find, it was 11.9 per cent. So the figure has almost halved in that time. That reflects lower interest rates here and elsewhere. It also reflects our improved export performance. So our capacity to service our debt has increased considerably.

In short, there are lots of reasons for optimism. Whether the balance of payments becomes a constraint will depend very much on us. If we pursue the right policies, we can ensure that it does not. The right policies mean that we have to maintain a low level of inflation; we have to maintain our improved international competitiveness and, if we can, improve on it; we have to improve productivity by a continued vigorous pursuit of micro-economic reform; we also have to improve our national savings performance and, if we do not do that, then, as investment grows and a savings investment gap opens up, we will be increasingly calling upon the savings of other nations, which will mean that we will be blowing out our current account deficit.

So we have to improve our savings performance. That means we have to reduce the Commonwealth and overall public sector deficit so that we do not have so much public dissaving. We also need to improve private sector saving performance. I assure the House that the government will be working diligently to achieve all those objectives.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Given the strength of the economic recovery, as outlined by the Treasurer, can the Prime Minister say what implications this has for government policy more generally? Does he believe the government's existing policy structure is appropriate? If not, is he aware of any alternative policy direction currently proposed for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. I do believe that the policy structure is appropriate, and my friend and colleague the Treasurer just went over some of the rudiments of that. In terms of the increase in competitiveness which the Australian economy now has, and the change in the savings balance, which a change in public and fiscal policy has brought about, we have now a much more modern, open and sophisticated economy. Exports have trebled since 1983. Manufacturing production has doubled. Exports of elaborately transformed manufactures have more than trebled; they are the fastest growing component of exports.

PARA.TAB: We have a very large improvement in competitiveness. The shadow Treasurer, in his ignorance or otherwise, yelled out a moment ago `Oh, it is because of commodity prices'. Anyone can have a nominal depreciation in the exchange rate but not everyone can have a real depreciation, that is, taking the inflationary surge out of a depreciation so that you have an effective depreciation with a 1.9 per cent inflation rate—not a 10 per cent inflation rate coming off such a depreciation, but a real depreciation, and that competitiveness coming not just from that but from an enlightened attitude in business, from gains in productivity, from a whole cultural change in the way in which Australian business is managed. That is the approach the government has taken in giving Australia a modern, outward looking, competitive economy over the last 10 years. We are seeing those policies bearing fruit very obviously at the moment.
But the Leader of the Opposition said we had betrayed the people of Australia. He said we had betrayed our election commitments.

TALK.START.PARA: —You lied to them.

—He said we lied to them—he has just repeated it. That is totally untrue. He said we have not done what we said we would do. Let me make a few points and give a few examples. We said we would give legislative effect to the High Court's decision on native title, and we did that last year. We said we would create greater flexibility in the labour market while preserving the wages and conditions and standard of living of all Australians, and we have certainly done that. We said we would preserve and improve Medicare. This week, the 10th anniversary of Medicare, we are working on proposals to ensure that Medicare remains an open, accessible and efficient system of health care insurance and delivery into the next century.

PARA.TAB: We said we would deliver a home child-care allowance to be paid directly to the parent caring full time for children at home and a new child-care rebate in recognition of the fact that child care is a necessary expense for many working parents. We said we would also add more child-care places to the system. We have done all those things. This year, we are looking at fulfilling a commitment we also made in the election context, and that was not leaving the long-term unemployed behind, that is, by considering the long-term unemployed in terms of the way in which the labour market operates with the most far reaching review, the Green Paper into the labour market, which we are now considering. And we have kept our tax cut commitments.
Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —You go and tell that to the people who picked up the $10 a week before Christmas and see what they say. What have we had from the Leader of the Opposition? Despite that record of commitment and achievement over the last year, we have the dismal, spoiling record of those opposite. They spoiled on Mabo right to the end and it has finally almost spoiled their party. On the economy they have consistently talked Australia down. I notice that when the Treasurer was appointed the Leader of the Opposition said, `Mr Willis inherits a poisoned chalice as Treasurer'. May I say, without the intonation, some poison, some chalice.

PARA.TAB: Today, the honourable member for Mayo was talking about one month's current account as ruining the whole of the current account and the policy settings. The opposition has had no new policy since Fightback, and now that is politically unmentionable. There is no opposition policy. If we asked any person in this parliament, in the press gallery or anywhere what are the central policies of the current opposition, no-one could provide an answer. As an opposition it has chosen a policy of moral vacuum as its preferred environment. Is it any wonder its leader has withered in it? But, undaunted in the withering, he goes on and says:

ANSWER.PARA: Leadership is about grabbing the flurry—
and pulling it back under control and imparting that discipline, and that's what I'm in the process of doing. I don't think they're ignoring me.
Whatever those opposite are doing, they are not ignoring him—but it is for different reasons. There were other ones. He went on to say:
I'm here, that's all I know.
We know he is here. He said:
I'm happy to answer all your questions. I'm here, that's all I know.
Then we have Bronwyn Bishop. Bronwyn has said a thousand times that leadership is not the issue; she is not running for the leadership. But Ray Martin, rather obviously, said:
But three times today she wouldn't say it.
The Leader of the Opposition said:
Look, she can't keep on repeating the position.
In other words, the Leader of the Opposition is now an apologist for Bronwyn. She cannot keep on repeating the position. How weak can you get?

PARA.TAB: The fact is, he should have knocked Bronwyn out at MacKellar. He should have said to the federal Liberal Party, `I am the leader and, if you want to keep me, she doesn't get the seat of MacKellar'. That is what someone with some guts would have said, but he does not have any guts. Here he is saying, `Bronwyn has said a thousand times that leadership is not an issue. She is not running for the leadership'. But three times she would not say it. `She cannot keep repeating the position.', he says. Poor Bronwyn! He is an apologist for her.

The Leader of the Opposition talks about the government betraying the people of Australia. The government has consistently stuck to a solid policy framework for a decade. We have stuck to and introduced our election commitments. He is now without a policy at all or a policy framework. He has chosen a policy immoral vacuum as his preferred environment. He has chosen to spoil and attack the government on its policies. Even worse for him, he has now become an apologist for an opponent who is dogging him and staring him into the ground.

—My memory is obviously a lot better than his. I would like to go through these points with him because many times in this parliament I have answered these questions.
