TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Is the minister aware of the current industrial campaign being conducted by the Communications Workers Union and others, and their allegations that Australia Post has a hit list of planned post office closures? Can he inform the House whether those claims are correct?

—I thank the honourable member for his question and for his continuing interest in the postal services provided to his constituents. I am, of course, aware of the campaign which the Communications Workers Union has initiated and its claims that the government's decision to open up $250 million worth of Australia Post business to competition will result in 500 post offices closing. I am very disappointed that the CWU has launched this scare campaign, because it has had the simple effect of alarming members of the public—perhaps in the honourable member's electorate—and also causing some distress to some Australia Post employees.

PARA.TAB: I was intrigued that virtually every federal electorate included a number of the post offices that were on the alleged hit list of 500 post offices until I found out that the list was prepared by the CWU and not by Australia Post. I think we should realise that the CWU has confused two reform issues in its campaign. The first is that Australia Post has been seeking to restructure its retail post office network. That is the result of a five-year strategy being developed and the result of its trying to improve customer service. It has also been trying to modernise its retail network. In 1992 it had the agreement of the CWU for this retail post office strategy.

That is the first issue. Australia Post has set out to modernise its network and to improve the locations of the retail post offices. Australia Post is introducing retail post office shops so that they are more attractive to consumers; they are at the right end of town so that more people are likely to spend money in them. That is something which will guarantee the further development of the postal network and improve the quality of services offered by Australia Post.

In addition to putting Australia Post shops in more accessible locations, under this strategy Australia Post is also seeking to convert small unprofitable post offices into licensed post office operations. I know that has been a matter of some concern amongst members of the government. Australia Post has advised me that, firstly, if an official post office is being considered for conversion to a licensed post office, Australia Post is committed to maintaining the same range of postal services which are now available from the official post office; and, secondly, that conversion will only follow a detailed review involving unions, the local community, chambers of commerce and so on.

I can assure you, Mr Speaker, that Australia Post is committed to modernising and improving its network, not reducing it. I would suggest that the CWU could better use its resources. Instead of handing around material such as this, which I think some honourable members have received, it would do better to try to ensure that its members receive accurate information about the government's campaign. The second element of the reform process is that the government decided last November to allow greater competition for some of Australia Post's domestic mail services. That will affect about $250 million worth of business. Australia Post has indicated that it will fight to protect every dollar of that business, even though it will be exposed to competition.

Some people have incorrectly suggested that, as soon as Australia Post faces any competition, it will lose the business. That is just not borne out by the facts because today, before implementation of the government's decision of last November, 40 per cent of Australia Post's revenue already comes from services that are open to competition. So it is just selling Australia Post and its employees short if we assume that, if there is competition, Australia Post will lose the business.

The government has demonstrated in its reforms in aviation and telecommunications that, by introducing competition, we can provide benefits to consumers—and I am sure that will be the case with Australia Post as well. Those who assume that Australia Post is unable to compete and who seek to prevent one of Australia's most successful government business enterprises from modernising and improving its services are not doing Australia Post or its employees any favours whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Would the minister inform the House what advice her department gave her on the environmental credentials of the Hellenic game shooting club to which she gave $42,000 under the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program in 1992-93?

—In the last round of community grants, a grant of $42,000 was provided to the Hellenic game shooters of South Australia. This was to build a facility near Murray Bridge in South Australia, which I believe is in the electorate of the honourable member for Barker. This club engages in target shooting as well as hunting live game. The facility funded will enable the club to train its members in the rules applying to shooting as well as the etiquette involved and the correct use of their weapons. If anything, the project should result in a better educated group, resulting in a reduction in the number of protected species accidentally killed or injured.

PARA.TAB: The point about this grant—and this is a very important point—is that the activities of this club are legal. The opposition has a clear inconsistency on this subject. On the one hand, it is saying to me—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order relating to the relevance of the answer. The question related to the minister's advice from her department. She has already demonstrated she is no threat to the Prime Minister, but she should answer the question.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat. The minister is answering the question.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order which goes to disruptive behaviour: there is not the remotest chance that any of the remarks made by the minister in the course of her answer were irrelevant to the question. That was a deliberately disruptive interjection.
—Order! I have already ruled on that. It is early days yet, and I am sure that the honourable member for O'Connor will be careful in his continued approach to this whole question.

—The point about this answer is that this is a legal activity; it is not an illegal activity. It met the guidelines. On the one hand, those opposite are saying to me that one should regard these applications dispassionately, look at the application and make a judgment on them. On the other hand, they are saying to me, `No, be biased, put in your own personal views about this'. I do not put in my personal views. I look at the application. It is a legal activity and, therefore, it was funded under the guidelines.

—Can the Prime Minister inform the House about Australia's recent export performance? Does he believe that we have created a new export culture in Australia that will persist through the current economic expansion?

—Today's balance of payment figures are a timely reminder of some of the trends in our trading performance. The Treasurer and I remarked earlier on other aspects of it, but I think it is worth recording that over the decade our exports of manufactures to east Asia have increased elevenfold—1,272 per cent to be precise. Work done by my department shows that our export performance does not worsen as the economy strengthens. We are likely to find that the people who have developed these markets now take the view that, having used export markets, particularly in the recession, to gain volume, even with smaller margins, they will not now forsake those export markets when we see a pick-up in domestic demand—that is, they will keep a relatively high proportion of their exports in those markets.

PARA.TAB: In the case of BHP, where we saw a very big pick-up in production, record volumes of production, although with lower profits, of a year or two ago, it will maintain its export markets to keep that ballast in its productive base. This is part of the cultural change which we have seen and it is why businesses see the opportunities as they are seeing them now in South-East Asia in particular, in manufactured exports as well as for the bulk traded commodities into north Asia. Exports of elaborately transformed manufactures in the first half of 1993-94 were 17 per cent higher than for the same period the year before, which shows a continuing strength in our capacity to get into those markets and to actually service them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister might just wait for a moment. Those on my left will adhere to the standing order in respect of listening to answers to questions in silence.

—I think it is worth dwelling on the point mentioned by the Treasurer. Honourable members would be interested to know that the debt servicing ratio—that is, the capacity of the country to service its debt—the ratio of servicing its net debt to the value of exports of goods and services, has declined from a peak of 21 per cent in 1990 to just 11.9 per cent in September. That is its lowest level for a decade.

PARA.TAB: While there has been, understandably and appropriately, concern in Australia about the level of our debt, the key thing is our capacity to service it. It is not so much the level that then matters as our capacity to service it, and it is that capacity which is improving as the proportion of our service costs to the exports of goods and services continues to decline. Having that come back to around 11.9 per cent of our goods and services proceeds I think is a very bull point for the economy.

Again this goes back to the kind of country Australia has become under this Labor government. Australia now has a high technology, export focused, open economy with dramatically reduced border protection, a free financial market, a good fiscal policy, a productive culture, a wages policy that is working, a low inflation rate and low nominal interest rates. This whole policy mix is now coming. It is producing a change in confidence levels in business that we have not seen for a long time. This is not because people think that the easy money days of the 1980s are back but because there is a real productive basis for going on into the future.

From the government's point of view we are going to go on and continue to improve the model we have been working with for just on 11 years. The honourable member for O'Connor was just talking about the states. The areas of the micro-economy such as electricity, gas supplies, infrastructure, transport are the areas which require continuing reform.

We have seen great reforms in the areas of telecommunications, ports and wharfs. There have also been great reforms in the Commonwealth area of aviation. There have been dramatic changes to the seamlessness between the domestic and international carriage of passengers. It means that things like the development of a sensible electricity grid in eastern Australia, a free flow of gas and the opportunities to trade in gas on free and fair terms, and access to water at competitive prices will make the economy much better. That is why there is a role for the states and Commonwealth to do these things and to get them right.

So far the government has done quite well with, for example, the National Training Authority. We pulled together the six state TAFE systems to make a national system. Other areas of the micro-economy are going to be important. The government will be working on those. But obviously, in the coming few months, the government will be working on the labour market, the problems of long-term unemployment, regional development policy and industry policy to keep the efficiencies up to the economy to maintain the kind of growth which we have had.

We take great heart from the new export culture in Australia and our export performance. We take great heart from the fact that the debt service component of the current account has come down dramatically, which means that Australia is in a position to better afford and service the debt which was acquired in the 1980s due to the fact that Australia was arriving at a position of complete uncompetitiveness by the early 1980s. All that has changed and the new culture will stand Australia in good stead.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. The minister will have noted that the Prime Minister was just boasting about the type of country Australia has become. Will the minister explain to the House why, after 11 years of Labor government and 11 years of Labor environmental policies, an international study reported in today's newspapers has labelled Australia one of the worst nations for the production of waste with one of the highest per capita rates of greenhouse gas emissions and the second highest emitter of sulfur oxides?

—In future I would hope to have the total support of the opposition for all our environmental initiatives. I would really appreciate seeing some policies from the opposition to give support to our policies. I am aware of the survey, but at this stage I have not seen the report. I am making arrangements to obtain a copy of the report.

PARA.TAB: My initial reaction to the press coverage is to ask about the methodology. There are some very real dangers in selectively using OECD data to provide a snapshot of a country's performance as the approaching data collection varies considerably from one country to another and the results of any attempted comparisons are likely to be of limited value. Secondly, they have assessed 11 different environmental criteria to produce an overall score and ranking of environmental performance. What they have really done is to assess different criteria—apples and pears, if you like—and this sort of approach is very dubious.

I will obviously be very interested to read the report and will do so with a great deal of consideration. I will be very happy to discuss it with the shadow minister. There is no doubt that in the management of waste, CFCs, greenhouse gases, not only have we taken domestic initiatives but also we have a very high international standing. I have very rarely seen any support for these areas from the opposition. I would hope that this is the turning point in support for environmental policy from the opposition. I look forward to seeing a few environmental policies from the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the House. Is the Leader aware that some members of the House, particularly on the other side, feel that their time and talents are being under-utilised? Does the government intend, through the committee system of the House, to provide members of the government and, particularly, the opposition backbench with more opportunities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I hate to report that there is some evidence that in the rural military districts of the Congolese Liberation Army there are signs of mutiny. I have here a piece of widely circulated correspondence from the honourable member for Cowper to his acting leader which states:

ANSWER.PARA: Having received a fax from John Hewson last night which listed the new Coalition committees, it is apparent that Dr Hewson and the Liberal Party are treating the National Party with contempt and I write to protest in the strongest possible terms.

The honourable member then went on to list the relevant policy review committees about which we have heard much and the statements by the honourable Leader of the Opposition outside in recent times. He goes on:
In terms of the involvement of individuals, there are 31 Liberals and six Nationals which means that only 16% of the people involved come from the National Party.

I warmly welcome the return of Ian Sinclair to the front bench but apart from that, as one of the few "Indians" left in the Opposition, I suggest that a Shadow Ministry of 37 "Chiefs" verges on the absurd and taints us as well as the Liberals.

I have some terrible news for the honourable member for Cowper. It seems that the shadow ministry of 37 is about to be expanded because at the same time as the honourable member sent his letter to his colleagues, an ad appeared which must have been inserted in the papers. It is headed `Tomorrow's leaders should apply today'. It states:
The Liberal Party is looking for men and women of talent and with a commitment to serving the people of Australia as possible candidates for parliamentary seats.

What a commentary on the rest of those opposite! The Liberal Party has evidently decided that there is nobody here on the opposition benches who fits that description, so it is looking for some appropriate replacements. The ad further states:
We want to identify potential candidates now as part of our preparation for the next federal election.
This is a very important point because the Liberal Party really would want to keep this secret:
Please respond in writing on a confidential basis as soon as possible.

They seek them here, they seek them there, they seek them under rocks, they seek them under bushes, and apparently they also seek them in aquariums. The honourable member for Boothby has had to warn his leader that he is about to have Senator Bishop `close her jaws'—that is the expression. At least we have the theme music now for the challenge. Of course, when these leaders arrive in this place and find an opportunity to serve on a frontbench of 37-plus, they will have to devise a few policies and no doubt a few committees will be appropriate for that.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I must correct the analogy of the honourable member for Cowper who said that, `. . . 37 "Chiefs" verges on the absurd and taints us as well as the Liberals'. I must confess that, in this particular environment, we do not see the opposition frontbench, and particularly its leader, in the context of Chief Sitting Bull. If we are going to draw analogies, we see him more in the context of General Custer, whose last words—which probably well apply to the Leader of the Opposition—were reputed to be, `We have seen better times than these in the 7th Cavalry'.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister. He knows that Australia has one of the highest rates of suicide in the world, particularly amongst males aged 15 to 19 years. The government has no strategy to give any hope to parents and youth who are confronting this waste of life. Why should we not develop a comprehensive national strategy to reverse this human tragedy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: HOUSING, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND HUMAN SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that there is a concentration of premature deaths from suicide in the age group mentioned by the honourable member for Mitchell. That certainly is regrettable. It is a matter that the government should and does take an interest in. It is one of the issues referred to by Brian Burdekin in his recent report on mental health. This report is currently under consideration by the government, which will be consulting with the states over the next several months and producing a comprehensive report by the middle of this year.

PARA.TAB: The reasons for suicide are very complex. We often think about young people as living their lives in many ways free of pressure and stress, but for many young people their youth can be a very unhappy period. The reasons for that are complex; there is no simple answer and no answer that can be separated from a broader approach to government policy.

We care for a very large number of young people through the supported accommodation program and the associated programs for young homeless people. Those programs have been reviewed and evaluated. We are currently formulating proposals which will be the subject of the next five-year agreement with the states, which will be signed by 1 July next year. Those efforts, which are very important, also need to be linked to efforts made, for example, in the field of mental health, which was particularly the subject of Brian Burdekin's inquiry. Issues such as this are complex, and the government needs to address them in a way that produces specific strategies.

The reasons for suicide are profound and difficult. One cannot expect—even after we implement the results of the Burdekin report, sign a new agreement on supported accommodation and work with the states in a whole range of areas—that ultimately we can do more than have some impact on a problem which has very deep roots within modern communities.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The continuing tragic level of unemployment in Australia.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition (2.49 p.m.)

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is about unemployment because unemployment is an issue that touches almost every Australian family. Yesterday we had the government's assessment of unemployment and we had a self-congratulatory performance by the Treasurer (Mr Willis), in which he said that the Australian nation had a magnificent future awaiting it. This magnificent future has a social dimension that excludes the unemployed of Australia. Yesterday, in the Treasurer's words, we were told:

SPEECH.PARA: We expect that the participation rate will remain at somewhere where it is at the moment, at around 63%, which means we're not going to, despite that higher employment growth, this year, make any further substantial headway on the unemployment rate, which was forecast in the budget to be around 10.75%.

So that is it. There is no change and no hope. There is nothing for the next 12 months. We should have a look at the dimension of the unemployment problem in Australia. We have 937,000 people unemployed. We have 344,000 people who have been out of work for more than a year and 187,000 people who have been unemployed for more than two years. What the figures do not show is that we also have 586,000 people who could find only a few hours work a week. We have 160,000 people who have given up, and we have nearly half a million kids who live in families in which both parents are unemployed.

There are other dimensions of this problem, as I have mentioned. One such dimension is underemployment. The Bureau of Statistics has a very broad definition of unemployment. A person has to work only one hour a week to be defined as employed. An underemployed person is someone who works part time but wants to work more or someone who is working full time but is not working full-time hours; for example, he has been stood down or is working short hours because the work is not there. In August 1993 the ABS reckoned that there were 586,000 people underemployed, which is 6.8 per cent of the labour market. That figure compares to 3.8 per cent after the 1982-83 recession. So that adds to the dimension of the tragedy of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Then there is hidden unemployment, which the Bureau of Statistics has been looking at recently. The hidden unemployed are people who are able to work but did not meet the ABS's strict criteria, who are actively seeking work but are not able to start in the next four weeks or who, for a whole lot of reasons, have given up. The ABS looked at hidden unemployment from September 1989 to September 1992. In that time, the figure for discouraged job seekers had gone up from 76,000 to 145,000. In that 12-month period we can assume that figure has gone up by another 10 per cent, which makes the best estimate 160,000. If we add those figures together—937,000 unemployed, 586,000 underemployed and 160,000 who have given up—18 per cent of the Australian labour force is currently affected by underemployment or unemployment. That figure compares to 13.7 per cent after the last recession. So the magnitude of what is going on has to be looked at in that broad sense. If the government does not look at the matter in that sense, it is not being honest with itself about what is happening.

The increased magnitude of the problem is not matched by an increased response. The very long-term unemployed have not got much attention. Three years ago there were 67,000 long-term unemployed people; today there are 187,000. That is an increase of almost 200 per cent. They are people who have been out of work for two years. What hope have they been offered in the last couple of months from the wonderful economic miracle that awaits us? None, there is no hope.

The figures are actually worse than that. I noticed in a report that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) gave in caucus this week that he used a figure of 400,000 long-term unemployed. I thought that was strange as it was a lot higher than the 344,000 that the ABS has produced. I also remember the former Minister for Employment, Education and Training softening us up by saying that the figure for long-term unemployed people could go higher than 400,000 this year. Let me tell honourable members that that has happened.

Only recently the government released its newstart recipient numbers. People have not paid much attention to this till now. Newstart recipients are the people that the government pays every fortnight because they have been out of work for more than 12 months. As at December the government was paying 451,000 people a newstart allowance. So the figure of 400,000 that the Prime Minister is using is just a sleight of hand. By the government's own figures, it pays 451,000 people who have been out of work for 12 months. That was the position in December, and that figure has gone up every month for the last two years. They are the long-term unemployed. That is heading inextricably towards the 500,000 mark. Others know this. ACOSS knows it. A couple of weeks ago ACOSS was talking about a figure of 450,000. ACOSS knows this because it has to deal with these unemployed people. It sees the social consequences of what is happening.

The social consequences are great. EPAC looked at unemployment last year and put out a paper on the social consequences of unemployment. It looked at divorce, marriage and crime. It reckoned that if the employment rate was taken down to 6 1/2 per cent there would be 800 fewer divorces, over 4,000 more marriages and 20 fewer homicides. That is the cost that Australia today is paying.

The AMA has had a look at unemployment as well; in fact, it has released several papers on the social cost of unemployment. What has to be understood about the social cost of unemployment is how it affects the individual. The AMA has been very good at this. Men and women have a significantly worse health status if they are unemployed. The mortality rate is 17 per cent higher for males if they are unemployed. Unemployed men have a 53 per cent higher rate of smoking, 50 per cent more doctor visits, a 57 per cent higher incidence of high blood pressure, 250 per cent more mental disorders and 68 per cent more bronchitis and emphysema. Unemployed women have 42 per cent more serious chronic illness, 35 per cent more hospital admissions, 80 per cent more outpatient visits and a 43 per cent higher rate of smoking. Twice as many people who are unemployed have skin disease, nervous disease and emotional disorders. That is the social cost of Australia today.

The AMA went further and said, `Okay. Are they sick because they are unemployed or are they unemployed because they are sick?'. The AMA could not explain the excess sickness by pretending that unemployment does not affect sickness. There is overwhelming evidence that the social consequences of this today are as the AMA states.

There is crime as well. In the last few days we have had reports from the Australian Institute of Criminology expressing its concerns. Honourable members should listen to what Professor Chappell says on this matter. It is fairly chilling. He has written:

SPEECH.PARA: The cost of crime in Australia is very low compared with the cost in the United States and some other countries.
He also states:

Our fear as criminologists is that two or three decades of continued relegation of more than 300,000 Australians to long-term unemployment may put us at risk of crime problems closer to those of the US . . .

That is the future Australia potentially faces. Given the magnitude of that problem, we would expect a national crisis. Back in early September the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean), who is at the table, made the odd foray into talking about employment. He recognised the problem. He said that we have to get economic activity and targeted job creation going and we have to address the particular needs of the long-term unemployed. He said that that was what the employment white paper was about and that the government would respond later that year. That was in 1993. The way things are going, it will be late 1994 before we have anything on this.

PARA.TAB: We are nearly a year into this electoral cycle and what have we had? A report. When are we coming up with some results? In May. And how long will they take to have any effect? At least six months. So we are talking about nearly two years of inactivity before we get any results on what is our most serious social problem in this country—two years of inactivity related far more to the political cycle than anything to do with the needs of the long-term unemployed.

Opposition senators questioned representatives of the minister's department in the Senate estimates. They were asked, `What are you doing for the long-term unemployed?'. All they could point to, in a similar self-congratulatory way that we saw yesterday from the Treasurer, was an expansion in labour market programs. They said, `For the long-term unemployed, we have a 43.6 per cent success rate, which is not bad'.

Let me tell the chamber what that success rate means. It means that three months after people have done the training program they are either put on another training program or they find a job, regardless of whether it has anything to do with DEET training or not. Honourable members who have talked in their electorates to people who are on this training merry-go-round will know what it is like for people to constantly go from one training job to another. That is a success for DEET. We heard from the Prime Minister that after the election these people would not be forgotten and that the great hand would reach behind and pick them up. The only hand that has reached behind them yesterday reached into their pockets to slug them with an extra petrol tax. These people were expecting tax cuts, but they did not get them.

The response to this matter has been pathetically slow. The response to this has everything to do with the timing of the next election. If those opposite genuinely wanted to do something about this problem, they could have easily done it in a 15- to 18-month time scale. It does not take 15 to 18 months to do what the majority of people acknowledge needs to be done. It does not take 15 to 18 months to get DEET working well; to get labour market programs focused; to find out what is working and what is not; and to cut out the dead wood. There is no evidence that that is happening yet, and we will not hold our breath.

It is nice to know, though, that there are some areas of growth. During the last three years there has been a 60 per cent increase in the staff of the CES. In one sense, that is understandable. But that has come from people who have been relocated from other departments. Other departments have had great exercises in cutting their staff numbers; they have shuffled them all off to DEET. The system under which we work in DEET is so rigid and inflexible that we have ratcheted up the staff to the point where they are stuck. It may very well be that, if we find the needs are not there or we find there are alternatives to DEET—which have been suggested—we will not have the ability to ratchet down and we will be left with an inexperienced, vast work force with very little to do.

It is interesting to look at the sorts of ideas that are being floated around by the government. Everyone knows what has to be done to achieve any real effect. We do not deny that the long-term unemployed have to be kept in touch with the labour market. That is economically and socially sensible. But in the end, unless the government has the guts to make some genuine industrial relations changes and to implement wide-ranging micro reform, there will not be much effect. Last year, EPAC said that we could increase GDP by 12.7 per cent if we finished micro reform. Everyone forgets that in the end the key—I have not heard from the Labor Party about this—is investment. If we look at this recession compared with the last recession, business investment in the last recession was up 23.9 per cent. This recession it is down 8.3 per cent.

We will now hear the government's response. We will hear a predictable mixture of self-congratulatory economic news such as `We're doing all we can' and a misrepresentation of what we took to the last election. But the Australian public knows that things are not right and it knows that government members are sitting on their hands. Government members can run and can misrepresent, but we will not allow them to hide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the opposition for the opportunity early in this session of parliament, when I have new portfolio responsibilities, to address this issue. I say at the outset that the question of unemployment is the most important issue facing this economy. Whilst there has been some recent encouraging news, the level of unemployment in this country is still far too high and more needs to be done. I believe that more can be done.

PARA.TAB: Let us just get some perspective on the position, because it is important to understand the difference between the challenge facing us coming out of this recession as against that coming out of the last recession. In the 10 years that this government has been in office there has been a 25 per cent increase in jobs. We have seen 1.6 million jobs created in this economy in that time. So let there be no talk about us not being able to create jobs. The problem we face—it is unique to the postwar settings in this nation—is that in the same period that saw employment grow by 1.6 million jobs we saw unemployment grow by 230,000 positions.

We have in this economy a unique position of jobs growth but, at the same time, unemployment growth. There are two important reasons for this position. The first is the increase in the participation rate. Because we have created jobs, more people are encouraged back into the work force. When we inherited office—when we won office—in 1983 the participation rate was three percentage points lower than it is today and almost four percentage points lower than was achieved in the late 1980s. Every one percentage point increase in the participation rate absorbs 88,000 jobs.

The simple fact of the matter is that we have encouraged, in a way that the opposition was never able to do in its reign of government, many more people—particularly women—back into the work force. That is why they have supported us. They recognise that, in the development of growth, the sharing has to recognise all sectors of the economy, not just the traditional ones. So the growth in participation is an important reason why the unemployment rate has gone up.

The other important reason the unemployment level has gone up is that the economy has achieved a mismatch of skills. There is a difference between the skills now required of a restructured economy versus those available in the work force. Again, the reason for that is that for the first time we saw the need to integrate this economy in its industrial development. We did not just rely on export earnings coming off the farm or out of the quarry; we did something to convert them before they left our shores. For that to happen, we, just like any developed western economy, required a position where the demand in the work force was for more skills rather than unskilled labour.

Unfortunately, in this economy, the training dimension to meet that demand has lagged behind. Certainly in policy settings the government has made some important contributions towards ensuring that assistance is given in that respect. Examples include the improved retention rates in secondary schools; increased places in universities; and going to the states and putting pressure on them to get a national approach to vocational training.

With this mismatch of skills, we require a solution this time around. It is not just a question of economic growth but, as we say on this side of the House, economic growth plus—the plus being the targeting, the focusing and the development of programs that can equip a work force and people who in other circumstances would be unattractive for employment.

No-one can doubt the importance of economic growth in this equation. I have indicated that our approach requires us not just to rely on economic growth but to do more than that. We should not forget the significance of economic growth itself. I remind the House that the green paper which dealt with restoring full employment in the economy made a very important observation. If we are to have economic growth at 3 1/2 per cent for the rest of this decade, then the level of unemployment by the end of that decade will fall to around seven per cent. If we can get it to 4 1/2 per cent, however, the unemployment rate will be at five per cent. So whilst growth is not the only solution, the reality is that without growth we are not even in the game. Therefore, an important part of the strategy has to be the development of policies that not only promote economic growth but also sustain it.

That is why the solution to the unemployment question cannot simply be an approach that derives from one portfolio area of interest; it has to be integrated across portfolios. The government has recognised this need because, in developing the green paper as a direction in which we might head, it has also had the regional development task force report and it is also committed to an important industry statement. These statements will be brought together in the next couple of months to provide the way forward and the solution for this at the moment seemingly intractable problem.

Economic growth is the key, but we have to recognise that economic growth will not make employment for those long-term unemployed groups in the community, the ones that are most seriously disadvantaged and the ones that will not be picked up quickly in the response. We have to equip them with the means by which they can become more attractive to employers when the recovery picks up. It is for that reason that we have identified not just the long-term unemployed but those at risk, which can include the young kids who are not interested in staying in school because they cannot see a future; they are not interested in getting into training. These are the people who need special attention. I agree that, if we are not going to address their problems, that will add to the social dimension of difficulties that this economy could face, such as the rising crime rate and the breakdown in family values.

The point I want to make is that there is a social and an economic dimension involved in the response. Whilst it is nice to hear the shadow minister for education, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Dr Wooldridge), on the other side of the House talk about all these nice things, it is very interesting that whenever the Liberal Party has to actually come forward with a solution the social dimension and the nice rhetoric are forgotten because its policy solutions provide no innovation, no direction and no ability to deal with those issues.

What did the Deputy Leader of the Opposition have to say about the green paper on unemployment? In a paper that was circulated to his shadow cabinet colleagues, he goes through the issues that are contained in the paper. He goes through some analysis. In part, he makes the same high-sounding phrases. But, in the end, his conclusion reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Only a thriving and competitive economy, based on a strong and sustained growth in productivity and investment, will guarantee such job creation over time.

TALK.START.PARA: —No policy.

—In other words, there is no policy to deal with the difficult part of the solution; it is simply an assertion that, if we get economic growth, the rest will follow. I remind the House of what was able to be achieved when those opposite were last in office. They were running at in excess of three per cent economic growth in 1980-81 and 1981-82, but they still left this government with a legacy of 10 per cent unemployment with a lower participation rate. If our participation rate had applied to the legacy of those opposite, the unemployment rate would have been 13.9 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite should not talk to me about the hidden unemployed for whom they now weep mock tears. Those opposite were discouraging from entering the work force the people we have brought in. They were relying solely on the traditional approach to getting the economy going: hoping that the resources dimension of the economy would solve the problem. We have a different approach and, as I said, it is an integrated one. It is one that recognises that we have to foster policies to stimulate economic growth, but that importantly we also have to continue to better refine, develop and deliver the existing labour market policies.

For the sake of the House, let me again put in context what this government is spending at the moment. This government is spending in excess of $9 billion on income support and labour market programs. It is also spending $1 billion to administer that $9 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too expensive.

—I believe it could be expensive. We should be looking at whether we can get better efficiency in that area. But it is easy to get that efficiency if all we are going to do is to drive the economic dimension and not try to equip the people to deal with the social dimension as well. I believe, and this has certainly been my experience in my electorate, that the CES officers are very helpful individuals. At times they have to operate with conflicting dimensions of where we are trying to place people.

PARA.TAB: One of the important areas that I will be looking at—and I know the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Snowdon), who will follow me in this debate, is spending important time on this issue at the moment—is more effective mechanisms for delivering existing programs and making them work better. In addition to that, we have also said that we are prepared to consider further resources in the context of the issues that surround the notion of the job compact.

Within the notion of the job compact comes the concept of mutual obligation. For this government's part, I am very attracted to the direction that says that, if we as a government are prepared to put additional resources in to try to solve this problem, there is also an obligation on the part of industry and the recipients to play their role in meeting their obligations. I believe that is an interesting development. It is an important part of what has come out of the green paper. It will be a significant dimension of the follow-up discussions that I will be having in the next couple of months.

I would not like to leave the House believing that the extra assistance will be focused on only the long-term unemployed. I believe they need particular attention. I believe they are disadvantaged because they have not had the opportunity to keep up with where the training direction is going. They have not had the work experience. Their self-confidence is down and they will require heavier costing responses not just because of issues associated with wage subsidy but also because, importantly, we will have to develop case management approaches with them.

I do not accept the notion that economic growth can look after the rest. The important focus needs to be on the long-term unemployed and those seriously at risk. But we need a response and a solution that also recognise the need to continue to skill the work force and to underpin the direction of structural change, which we have been responsible for overseeing and implementing so as to make the economy more competitive. As the recently revised forecasts have shown, we have made progress this year with 116,000 new jobs. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity of supporting the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Dr Wooldridge) in this discussion before the House about the continuing tragic level of unemployment in Australia. This Keating government is almost into its second year. The unemployment crisis that we have at the moment has existed since Labor came into power in the early 1980s. It has overseen a high level of unemployment for the past 10 years. It is no good this government blaming anything else. It is no good this government blaming the cyclical economic activity around the world which it has no control over.

PARA.TAB: This government has been in power long enough to realise that many of the programs the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) has just been speaking about have not achieved the results the government was looking for. Why has the government not looked further at enhancing those programs, or linking those programs to other reforms that should—and we know will—alleviate the tragic unemployment problem? We talk about the high unemployment levels and about the long-term unemployed, but let us remember that without employers there cannot be any employees. The point that has been lost sight of in this debate is that the government has not focused on the people who are out there in the community providing real jobs for our unemployed.

So where are we today? The December unemployment figure was 10.7 per cent, down 0.4 per cent on the previous month. It will be interesting to see the January figures next week. In my electorate of Lyne, the Port Macquarie unemployment figure in December rose by 0.7 per cent. In Taree it rose by 0.6 per cent. Regional unemployment, therefore, is still too high. It is not being affected by the programs that the government has in place at the moment. Only two months prior to that we saw the worst seasonally adjusted unemployment level in Australia's history, 11.2 per cent.

What about what the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), had to say in his opening address on budget night in August last year? I quote from his budget speech which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The greatest issue facing our nation is how to provide jobs for our fellow Australians. Too many are now out of work. Too many have been out of work for too long.

PARA.TAB: The primary objective of this budget is jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: Really, the primary objective of that budget was to raise taxes—taxes on the jobs of ordinary Australians. This government has continued in that vein. It has not addressed the real issue. The former Treasurer nominated jobs as the key issue, but since this government was elected it has used all the sleight of hand tricks and the smart mouth sayings of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to evade and not address the issue of unemployment in Australia, particularly the issue of the long-term unemployed. I will reiterate the statistics that were used by the first speaker in the debate on this matter of public importance today about the long-term unemployed. The tragedy we face today is the people who have been out of work for over 12 months, who face at this stage, with the programs this government has in place, little prospect of finding employment. Unemployment has risen from 444,386 to a staggering 451,022 people. Now, nearly half of all the unemployed are considered to be long-term unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame.

—It is absolutely unbelievable. As I said at the start of my address, this government has been in power for 10 years and has not been able to come to terms with the tragic situation in Australia. What are the government forecasts? We listened to some very interesting words from the current Treasurer (Mr Willis) yesterday, who talked about a `conjuncture of events'. His forecasts are these: his revised forecast for growth, 3.5 per cent; his revised forecast for inflation, two per cent; his revised forecast for investment, 4.25 per cent; his revised forecast for interest rates, remaining low; his revised forecast for unemployment, 10.75 per cent—what it was in the budget. On top of improved growth figures on what was forecast, there are better inflation figures than forecast and better investment figures but still the same unacceptably high level of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: What has the government done? What are the labour market programs that the minister was talking about? I am sure we are going to hear from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Snowdon) shortly. We must admit that, as part of the policy to address unemployment, some of the labour market programs are important—but not by themselves. We have seen labour market programs over the years, such as wage subsidy schemes. At the moment they last six months. What happens to the majority of those people who have been given employment under wage subsidy schemes at the end of the six months? Most of them go back on the unemployment queues. They do not get real long-term jobs out of it. They go along to apply for a job, but six months training or six months work experience is not enough. Anybody on the government benches who has been an employer—

TALK.START.PARA: —There aren't any.

—That is exactly right. If there were, they would realise that six months training, six months work experience, is not enough. It should be at least 12 months. What about the job creation schemes? They are fantastic for injecting government funds into infrastructure spending. They provide short-term prospects, short-term jobs. But what is the prospect of work at the end of those job creation schemes? There is none. The people who have participated in those job creation schemes are back on the unemployment queues. Admittedly they have had work for a short period, but who has paid for the work? It has been the taxpayer, not the private sector. It has not been generated by growth. It has not been generated by profits or export income. The taxpayer has paid for those schemes. Those people who have been employed in those schemes are back on the unemployment queues at the end of those schemes.

PARA.TAB: The training schemes are fantastic—we have the best trained dole queues that Australia has ever seen—but they are not focused correctly. The minister just admitted that the training schemes are not focused in the right areas. We are training people to apply for jobs. We are training people to do things they do not want to do. We are not giving them traineeships. I have an industry in my electorate that employs in excess of 300 people. It manufactures components for the automobile industry in Australia. They were looking for a tradesperson to do a particular job. They searched Australia and could not find one. They had to convince a tradesperson to migrate from England to fill that position. It is a sad indictment on this government that, after having been in power for 10 years, we have not got those trained tradespeople.

The minister admitted that the retention rates of high schools are higher, that there are higher levels of tertiary education participation. That does not matter because there are no jobs at the end of that training for those people; there are no jobs at the end of that education process. What do we find at the other end of the scale? We find that we have not got the trained tradespeople in this country to assist in the manufacturing industries that we are trying to develop. Again, it is a sad indictment on this government. The government, on the other side of the argument, has maintained a large number of impediments to the private sector for employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is spelled, t-a-x.
—Tax, all taxes: the superannuation guarantee levy, the training guarantee levy.
—Oh!

—The Parliamentary Secretary thinks it is funny, but he has probably never been in business and had to pay these taxes. I get people coming into my office on a daily basis to tell me about the problems. They structure their business plan so that they maintain their levels of employment and their levels of employees' hours of operation to stay under the threshold of the superannuation guarantee levy and the training guarantee levy. Yesterday, we had the introduction of higher fuel taxes. This government collects 34c a litre from higher fuel taxes. That is a tax on jobs. This government has not been prepared to address the on-costs on employment, such as penalty rates, holiday pay and payroll tax.

PARA.TAB: Before I finish I would like to make a couple of comments on the green paper. The green paper, it seems, is going to reinforce the government's attitude as far as the labour market programs are concerned. It is not prepared to link them to proper workplace reforms. The government at the end of last year had the opportunity to introduce some proper workplace reforms in its industrial relations legislation. It espoused all the great changes it was going to make in that industrial relations legislation in the election campaign last year but it did not have the guts to do it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and Parliamentary Secretary (Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: ) (3.29 p.m.)—As with his leader in this debate, the last speaker from the opposition, the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), demonstrated an appalling lack of vision and understanding in regard to the real issues. It is interesting that whilst the opposition continues to bleat about what it believes to be a lack of activity by the government, we have yet to see from the opposition any coherent policy response at all around any issue, let alone the labour market issues.

PARA.TAB: The only input that we have had from the opposition in relation to labour markets and the question of unemployment has been the statements which have been made by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), who is sitting at the table, and the shadow minister, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), who opened this debate. First, it is perhaps worth looking at what the shadow minister had to say in his response to the green paper. When the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) responded he said:

SPEECH.PARA: This is a band-aid approach which does little or nothing to create sustainable work for the unemployed: only a thriving and competitive economy, based on strong and sustained growth in productivity and investment, will guarantee that over time.
What does the shadow Treasurer say? In a press release headed `Coalition will fight against the jobs levy', he says:
The only constructive way to get the long-term unemployed back into the work force is to improve Australia's economic performance.

Well, boohoo! There is not one commentator in Australia who does not believe that a very important factor in improving the job opportunities in Australia is to increase economic growth and to improve economic performance. But that is one part of the scenario. The key word from the shadow Treasurer is `only'. He says it is the only constructive way. `Only' is the word he uses in his press release.

PARA.TAB: I suggest—as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said during question time—that what we are seeing from the opposition is a policy vacuum. Opposition members are in a void. They do not have any adequate responses to these great human issues. The government has acknowledged for some time the central importance of addressing the question of employment and unemployment to this government's social economic agenda. The government is not running away from the issue; it is addressing it full frontal, warts and all. It is prepared to examine all of its policies that it has put in place to address the issues hitherto.

Whilst opposition members acknowledge that, as far as they are concerned, the only way to address this issue is through the mechanisms of the free market, they have no real vision about the way in which labour market programs relate to the importance of getting long-term unemployed people in particular back into the work force. What are they suggesting? Are they suggesting that those people who might unfortunately be unemployed for 12 months more should just take the punt and rock on down to the local sheetmetal worker who has got a vacancy and expect to get a job because they have been 12 months long-term unemployed? Opposition members know—or are supposed know—how the market works. They know, as the Prime Minister and the previous Treasurer, the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), said during the budget debate last year, that this government is about helping people up. What we are proposing to do and what we have done hitherto is look at ways to equip those people who are long-term unemployed with a better than even chance to get opportunities in the labour market.

We have had programs which have been very successful. Even the previous member who spoke in this debate acknowledged the importance of those programs, yet his shadow spokesperson, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Chisholm, came in here this afternoon and spoke in quite concerned terms about the needs of unemployed Australians. We acknowledge those needs; we do not walk away from them. Instead of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition making a constructive contribution to the debate, instead of giving us some propositions which he thinks might be appropriate to assist in the rehabilitation of those people who are unfortunately unemployed, instead of assisting in the debate by putting up proposals which might in fact help to get people back to work, the only blithe contribution he was able to make was, `We'll wait for economic growth'. It is just not enough and no reasonable observer of the situation in the Australian labour market accepts that it is enough. This government does not accept that it is enough. The green paper process, which the minister spoke about during this debate, is one very important part of getting a reasonable response to addressing the needs of unemployed Australians.

Secondly, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be aware, the Labor Party caucus is most concerned that unemployment and employment opportunities should be seen as a core of this government's social economic agenda. As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, there is a committee, which is jointly chaired by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) and the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan). It has been travelling around Australia taking submissions from people about the way in which ordinary Australians feel about the question of unemployment. It has been very important to the contribution to the debate within our Labor Party caucus.

Unlike the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer, we are not in a position to say that we can wave a magic wand and, hey presto, resolve the problem. What we are saying is that the concerns of these poor Australians who are unemployed need to be addressed in a coherent way, in a way which is constructive, in a way which addresses their needs, not in a way which just blithely says, `Let the market determine the outcome for their plight'. It is not appropriate to adopt that sort of attitude. I say this for the information of the honourable members opposite.

In regard to the nature of those people who are unemployed, I quote what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition on one occasion said in an interview on the ABC television news on 13 January. The announcer said that the opposition members claimed that `they were not the right sorts of jobs'. The honourable member for Chisholm said, `It is women who found the jobs, not men'. I am not quite sure what he meant by that. I am not sure what the female members of his caucus think about that sort of statement but I suggest to someone who is supposed to be soft and fuzzy in terms of the opposition, who is supposed to have some appeal to the community, that he understand that women are a very important component of the Australian labour force. They should not be denied access to the labour market. We should not decry the fact that women are able to get access to jobs within the community.

Let me just say that we must understand the nature of the labour market and understand the nature of those people who are unemployed. It is important that we recognise the plight that these people are in. Young people are the largest group of unemployed persons. Twenty-one per cent of unemployed people are aged between 20 and 24 years. Forty per cent of all long-term unemployed are between 20 and 29 years of age. Sixteen per cent of unemployed people are born in countries where English is not the first language. These groups constitute 45 per cent of the long-term unemployed.

They place a particular burden on this government and on the community. There is no point in the opposition asserting that young people constitute an important component of the long-term unemployed and that people from a non-English speaking background constitute a huge component of the long-term unemployed without the opposition accepting a responsibility to put programs in place which will give those people an opportunity to compete equitably and equally in the labour market. That requires us to develop and further develop successful programs which we have had in place for some time.

That is what the process of policy review is about. It is accepting that the programs which are currently in place could work better; it is accepting that the delivery mechanisms which are in place could work better; it is accepting, as this government has done, that there is a need to improve the delivery of employment programs. That is why we have adopted the approach towards the Commonwealth Employment Service, which I might say has been ahead of the green paper debate, and why we have perceived the need for change in the way we deliver services.

Whilst the shadow minister can quietly admonish the CES for what he believes is its role, let me say the CES has adopted an approach over recent months which is very important to ensure that those people most in need in the labour market get opportunities. It has put in place a restructure of the organisation and policies which will improve the responsiveness and flexibility of the labour market programs, develop volunteer and work experience opportunities for long-term unemployed and introduce, for example, account executives to pursue vacancies and liaise with industry and employers. These are all very important changes. It is very important that we acknowledge the crucial role of the employment services and get people access to jobs for job vacancies. (Time expired)

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Tickner, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill reflects the continuing commitment of this government to securing legitimate title to traditional lands on behalf of the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory. The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 provides a mechanism whereby traditional Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory referred to in schedule 1 of that act may be granted to Aboriginal land trusts to hold title on behalf of Aboriginal people. Since the act came into operation in 1977 a total of 57 separate parcels of land have been scheduled under the act.

PARA.TAB: The effect of this bill would be to bring within the schedule to the Land Rights Act that area of land which is the subject of the Wampana land claim. The Northern Territory government, the Central Land Council and Gambamora Industries Pty Ltd have entered into an agreement which settles that land claim. As part of that agreement the Northern Territory government agreed to request the Commonwealth to exercise its powers under the land rights act to grant the claim area to the traditional owners by scheduling that area

SPEECH.PARA: under the Land Rights Act. The result of such scheduling would be that no further hearing or report by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner would then be necessary in order for the Aboriginal people concerned to be able to have the full rights of enjoyment of their traditional lands in fee simple.

PARA.TAB: The government has the assurance of all parties to the negotiations that representative views of all Aboriginal people concerned have been obtained and their wishes taken into account. There are no financial implications arising from this bill. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Nugent) adjourned.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch, I was saying a few words about the fact that not only is access to tertiary education in Australia restricted because of Labor's policies, but also all students are now fee paying through HECS. Students have the worst of both worlds. We had to accept some restriction in access for the sake of free education. Now we have restricted access as well as fees.

PARA.TAB: In the course of her speech the honourable member for Macquarie (Ms Deahm) referred to the disadvantage experienced by students in the rapidly expanding area of the western suburbs of Sydney, which is serviced by the University of Western Sydney. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) talked about people in outlying areas of Melbourne being disadvantaged. But all had to concede that the Gold Coast region of Australia is in fact the fastest growing area in Australia. It is an area that has suffered because of this government's funding policies for higher education.

I have said before in this place, and I will say it again, that some people have an image of the Gold Coast as being a wealthy, glamorous, glitzy place. Those people do not ever look at the facts. When we look at the statistics, such as average household income and so on, we find that the Gold Coast region is one of the lowest income areas of Australia. It would be as mistaken to take the homes on the harbour side of Sydney as the norm for that city and saying that people who live in Sydney are very wealthy.

The reality of life for people who live on the Gold Coast is rather different from that portrayed by its image. I would like to point out to those who have talked about the difficulties of people living in the outer suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne that it is not only the large cities where there is disadvantage. Apart from an infrequent, privately owned bus service, there is no public transport from the Gold Coast to the Brisbane universities. Students who live on the Gold Coast and who want to do courses which are not offered at the Gold Coast University College are extremely disadvantaged by geography.

If honourable members care to look at the geography of the Gold Coast itself, they would see that students can live 25 miles away from the Gold Coast University College campus with access only via a very poor public transport service. They would realise that, for young people attempting to access tertiary education on the Gold Coast, life is very difficult indeed. Further, there are only limited courses available at the Gold Coast University College and extremely limited places.

Some criticism has been made—and properly so—of the fact that, under this bill, Victoria gets no allocation at all. The allegation has been made—and it seems to have substance—that there were political considerations in determining how many places each state got. I point out that Queensland, which has 10 times the population of the ACT and the most dispersed population of any state in Australia, receives only six times the allocation of the ACT, whose population lives in a single city. Physical access to the ACT's institutions is reasonably easy. Whilst Queensland appears to have done relatively well, a redress of historic imbalance and shortfall was required. Of course there is also the matter of it being the most rapidly growing state with a greater and greater proportion of Australia's total population. Further, having a dispersed population causes difficulties in areas of tertiary education.

The government has fallen back on the device of saying, `Well, fewer people should be going to universities anyway'. They have the fall back position of TAFE. The result of this diversion of students means a diversion of TAFE resources away from students who want to do TAFE courses to those who do not want to do them, but who are enrolled in a TAFE course only to further their university aspirations. This is an enormous waste of scarce resources.

Finally, because time is very limited, I want to make a couple of comments about the Open Learning Agency. One of the things this bill does is scale back on the funding of the Open Learning Agency, because the actual enrolments have fallen rather short of the estimates. This is a great disappointment to the opposition, as I am sure it is to the government. We have been critical throughout of the way in which the government went about setting up the Open Learning Agency, although as long ago as the 1984 federal election we were advocating the establishment of such a form of education.

One area of concern is access by mature age students to tertiary education. The Open Learning Agency was meant to be a device to enhance access by mature age students to tertiary education. There is a very real concern that the government has abandoned these students because of the political imperatives of school leavers.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training, twice in the same paragraph of his second reading speech—a paragraph to which I have already referred—sought to give emphasis to the particular needs of school leavers by saying `especially school leavers' and `including recent school leavers'. The opposition agrees. We believe that qualified students, whether they are recent school leavers or mature age students, should have access to tertiary education—and we say that the government's policies are preventing this.

Let us look at the facts. A recent report of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its Higher Education Council has revealed that access of mature age students has suffered as demand for places by school leavers has risen. Several states have reported that in 1992 demand for places by mature age students was higher than by year 12 students. Reinforcing that, New South Wales, South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland all had approximately one-third more mature age applications than year 12 applications.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Dr Wooldridge) has already pointed out that as the recession continues to force retrenchments of middle aged Australians, including those who already hold post-secondary qualifications, thousands more will seek access to this form of education. However, over the last seven years, the number of undergraduate mature age entrants nationally has dropped from 55.7 per cent to 47.9 per cent. We lament the fact that the Open Learning Agency is not meeting more of the unsatisfied demand, part of which it was established to meet. We also lament the fact that mature age students who have a particular need appear to be being precluded. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1993 amends the Higher Education Funding Act by increasing the higher education contribution scheme contributions payable by students who take longer than is usually required to complete their courses; by increasing the HECS contributions which are payable by students taking further undergraduate or postgraduate studies; and increasing the rates payable by graduates who choose to defer their HECS liability. The current HECS system is flexible and caters for the needs of all students, irrespective of their financial circumstances. Students are able to pay their HECS liability per semester up-front or they can choose to defer that liability until they are earning a decent wage.

PARA.TAB: In Australia, university enrolments last year were in excess of some 580,000, an increase of some four per cent on the previous year, and they are expected to surpass that mark this year. In fact, university enrolments increased by some 64 per cent in the 10-year period from 1982 to 1992.

Labor's commitment to higher education is unprecedented—and I would compliment the two ministers at the table, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) and the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free). I would particularly compliment the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training on the good work he has done in the period he has been minister. I know that Minister Crean will also bring a great deal of experience into the portfolio, which we have yet to see. But certainly I have enjoyed working with Minister Free up to this time, and I am sure that will continue.

The demand for tertiary places continues to grow as a natural result of growth in population and the increasing number of students who are returning and completing their secondary education. That, again, is as a result of policies which Minister Free has been a part of implementing. The changes that this government has brought in certainly have seen more students get into university—student numbers have grown—and students themselves have been able to obtain the best possible chance to join the work force in a field of their choice. It is certainly our responsibility to ensure that everyone who would like to study at university is given a chance to qualify for a place.

No doubt remarks have been made that some students do miss out on places at university. But I think we need to look at the increased numbers of students who have been able to qualify and get into university in the last 10 years as the numbers at universities have expanded. It is a little bit darwinian when we think of the numbers of students who do sit for the HSC, the number who do aspire towards a higher education. The fact is that only a certain percentage has ever been able to obtain a university position. The policies and changes that have been put in place over the last 10 years certainly make that fairer where a student's socioeconomic background does not preclude him or her from being able to get into university.

Access to tertiary education in Australia is something that we too readily take for granted. To maximise our tertiary sector, a change in attitude towards our universities must occur. Tertiary education is certainly a privilege, but it is not a right, and should be viewed as such. Certainly gone are the days when high school graduates opted for university to enjoy a healthy social life without having to overly exert themselves.

As we approach the 21st century, it is vital that our universities are able to offer the widest variety of courses to as many students as possible to cater for the ever changing employment market. This change has occurred in the last 10 or so years as universities have attempted to grapple with changing conditions and as governments have attempted to grapple with changing conditions in the economy, the labour market, student aspirations and what society desires. This bill ensures that this will be possible. It will ensure that everybody who wants a tertiary education has access to one.

The changes to the higher education contribution scheme contained in the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill I believe are both fair and equitable. This bill increases HECS funding by some 50 per cent for students taking longer than is usually required to complete a course. Students are currently liable to pay a set contribution for each year of study. The contribution is determined by multiplying the annual course contribution by the student's load, and the student's load depends on whether he or she is studying full time or part time. In 1993 the annual course contribution was $2,328 for a full-time student. The HECS contribution is approximately 20 per cent of the total cost of a student's education.

Increasing the HECS contribution for students taking longer to complete their courses than required will, in the majority of cases, make sure that students work to their fullest potential rather than giving them the opportunity to coast along while possibly denying keener students a position at university. I am not for one moment criticising students but rather pointing out that in the past our higher education has been taken advantage of. I have no doubt that an increased HECS liability will be a motivating factor with students toying with their tertiary studies. Having studied at tertiary level, I can tell honourable members that students serious about getting a quality education know why they are at university and work hard to perform at the highest level they can.

There are provisions for students with genuine circumstances, such as illness, et cetera, to be granted an exemption from an increased liability. The HECS liability for students to take on further undergraduate or postgraduate courses will also be increased. From 1 January, that HECS contribution will be doubled for those students. This will ensure that school leavers have access to university places which may have been taken by students undertaking second degrees. Simply, the bill will make sure that students carefully review and make their university choices very carefully rather than adopting a hit-and-miss approach.
