The bill also accelerates the rate of repayment on a HECS debt from some two, three and four per cent to three, four and five per cent for students who have chosen to defer their HECS liability. Students will begin to repay their HECS liability once that taxable income threshold reaches some $27,748. The deferment of the HECS liability means that students will not be burdened with repayments while they are studying or looking for work.

Our Labor government can stand tall and proud on its commitment to educating Australians, particularly in the higher education sector. It has met the changes which have occurred in the last 10 years particularly, and it is leading the way in pushing the numbers up in higher education. Certainly—as an aside which I understand is not directly related to this bill—it is leading the way in its commitment to the TAFE sector. In Australia 3.3 per cent of our total population is studying at higher education institutions, as opposed to only 1.2 per cent in the United Kingdom. Some 42 per cent of our total education budget, or four per cent of our total budget expenditure, is for higher education

It is worth pointing out that in the five-year period to 1995 some 95,000 additional places will be created at a cost of $1.4 billion, which augurs well for the future of newly created institutions such as the Southern Cross University at Lismore. The Southern Cross University at Lismore will mean that students on the north coast of New South Wales will not have to move too far to receive quality tertiary education. In case honourable members do not know, the Southern Cross University was formerly a campus of the University of New England at Armidale and on 1 January 1994 it became a fully fledged university in its own right.

I also point out that the response to the university has been overwhelming to say the least and the Southern Cross University will offer 1,335 undergraduate places this year. It received some 20,000 applications for those places. Of those 20,000 applications, 4,500 students nominated the Lismore institution as their first choice. Having a university on the north coast will benefit the region in many ways as it has already done in the past, and it will continue to do so. Foremost, it will enable students to study the course of their choice and locally if they want to. Regions such as the north coast have traditionally suffered from what could be described as a brain drain. In previous years students have had to leave the region in order to undertake their university studies. Unfortunately, many of those students did not return, which meant lost opportunities in terms of job creation and lost knowledge.

I believe that the university will strengthen the north coast by providing not only quality education to its students—one student about to graduate is the son of Minister Free; and I congratulate him—but also by providing jobs and creating economic spin-offs for the region. There has been a tremendous spin-off to the city of Lismore, the surrounding villages and the north coast in general which has been created by the presence of the university. As certain areas of the economy there, particularly the rural industries, contracted some many years ago, that shortfall in local input of money was picked up opportunely by the presence of the university as it expanded considerably in those last five to six years.

As I said earlier, there were some 20,000 applications for those few places at the university. Perhaps the minister might consider expanding the 1,335 undergraduate places a little next year; 20,000 students cannot be wrong. The strong demand for places at the Southern Cross University is a clear indication that higher education on the north coast has a very bright future. We can all be very justifiably proud of our university there.

I would also like to comment on some of the outreach centres that the university has established, particularly the Tweed open learning centre. It certainly received my blessing and support three years ago when it was opened. It has been a bonus for the city of Murwillumbah. It has certainly received the patronage of many students there. It has meant that people who would normally be faced with a journey of one hour or more by vehicle—a private passenger vehicle, too—to the city of Lismore have been able to access the facilities through that open learning centre. It has been a great boon to many people who would not normally be able to undertake a university education. I commend those types of institutions and changes to the university. They have meant a great deal to people in the electorates of Richmond and Page and even to one or two students across the border in the electorate of McPherson, I understand.

Overall, there has been criticism by the other side of the changes proposed by the government in this piece of legislation. We have introduced equity into the university system. It has meant that many of our students who would not normally be able to get into university have been able to do so. Certainly, I think the ministers at the table can be proud of this. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable members who have participated in the debate on the Higher Education Funding Bill. I did not introduce the legislation, but it is an important part of the learning curve to swat up on it and listen to what other honourable members have had to say. In response, I want to comment on a few issues that were raised by the opposition. I say at the outset that, if anyone does doubt the Commonwealth's commitment to funding for higher education, he or she need look no further than the figures themselves.

PARA.TAB: This bill provides funding which will rise to $5 billion in 1996. For the triennium that we are dealing with—1994-96—$14.8 billion has been committed by the Commonwealth, which has resulted in a massive increase in places since 1988 under this government. Places have increased by 25 per cent in universities. In excess of 100,000 new places will have been created in the decade 1988 to 1998. There are now over 580,000 students in our universities out of a population of 17.6 million. The proportion of the population in higher education in Australia is 3.35 per cent compared with only 1.28 per cent in the UK. I make that point from the outset. I will now address a number of the issues that have been raised.

The first issue that I will touch on is in relation to school leavers. It is argued that we have changed the policy for unfilled places and that this is having an impact on mature age students. Despite the huge increase that the government has made in those 100,000 places, the institutions have chosen to allocate growth in those places to graduates undertaking further undergraduate qualifications as well as increasing the provisions for postgraduates.

The reality is that more than 90 per cent of places created between 1988 and 1993 have been taken up by students already in the system. It does not leave much for the school leavers. In fact, opportunities for school leavers fell by 8.1 per cent in the period 1990 to 1993. Given the fact that the universities, the educators, the opposition—everyone—said that part of the reason why we had to increase our commitment to places in universities was due to the demand coming from school leavers, it seems only fair that we redress that imbalance. That is essentially what the government has done with its recent discussions with the universities.

We have negotiated school leaver and undergraduate targets with institutions as part of the profile discussions undertaken last year. The key thrust of those discussions was to provide opportunities for all those who are new to higher education. Even with the new understandings about school leavers, the impact will still result in 50 per cent mature age students having access to places and being in places in universities. So the share will be evened out. The exercise is one of evening up and it is consistent with the arguments put to us associated with the need to increase places.

The other issue that was raised by the opposition went to the question of the criteria for allocating public resources. There was reference to the speech of the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), in November last year. In that speech he indicated that the criteria for allocating public resources needed to be looked at in the future. As to future places—this bill deals with future places—the minister indicated at the time that it would be based on an assessment of low population and high participation areas being reversed—high population and low participation. I cannot see anything wrong with that approach. If what we are talking about is need, based on where the activity is happening, it makes sense for us, as part of our commitment, to take note of those shifts and to try to adjust places accordingly.

The way the formula has been applied has nothing to do with the political circumstances in Victoria. It has been done by objective criteria based on information which has been exchanged at the profile discussions. I point out that, of the 1,500 places, only 1,000 have been allocated in that manner. The other 500 places are still up for grabs, so to speak, based on the extent to which the universities can attract industry interest.

I note that Victoria has been extremely successful in the past in garnering such places. If we look at the last three years, of the total 2,200 joint Commonwealth/industry places in universities, Victoria was successful in gaining 1,188 of those places. That is over 50 per cent. When the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) argues that there is no opportunity to accommodate additional places, not only is he misrepresenting the position but he is selling his state and the universities in that state short. In respect of the criterion which could involve the shift of currently allocated places, to which the former Minister for Employment, Education and Training, referred in his speech, I point out that the commitment was made that there would be full consultation with those affected and I recommit to that position.

The honourable member for La Trobe said that the Berwick campus would get no additional places and would therefore be disadvantaged by this measure. I have today had the opportunity to speak to the Vice-Chancellor of that university and I suggest that the honourable member for La Trobe ought to get his facts right in this regard. Whilst it is true that Monash—or, for that matter, any university—does not get any additional places out of the 1,000, it is able to bid for the remaining 500. In addition, the government has recommitted itself to the capital works program for the Berwick campus. Discussions between the university and the Commonwealth have also resulted in a situation in which that university is embarking on an innovative new approach. Without the additional option of places, it intends to use some of the capital expenditure, along with information technology and networking, to provide services from the university to a much wider regional base. I would suggest that, rather than spreading misinformation in this place, the honourable member for La Trobe ought to sit down properly with that university, which he claims to represent, and find out precisely what is happening.

In terms of his argument that the demand is not there, the honourable member should note what Professor Chipman from Monash University said in the La Trobe Valley Express on 20 January. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: He said this week, predicted that the demand and supply for university places in regional Victoria had never been better and students would have their best chance of ever of getting their entry level scores—
The article continues:

The problem of excess demand for university places had now been overcome due to increased places being allocated to school leavers and a nationwide reduction in the number of students in year 12 secondary courses.

I think that demonstrates that the Commonwealth is trying to come to grips with what the actual position is, where the real demand is, where the pressures are and where the needs are. I think that should properly be taken on board by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: My final comment goes to the question of open learning. I am interested in the comments of the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) in relation to this matter. I am very interested in the open learning concept. This bill provides significant funding to enable that development to continue. I intend to visit the facility in Melbourne the week after next. I am told that the program is going extremely well. There are 9,000 students enrolled, half of whom are school leavers. The open learning program is well on target to have 20,000 enrollees by the end of the year.

This is an important innovation that this government and the former Minister for Employment, Education and Training were instrumental in pushing through. It provides the additional flexibility that is needed and again it cements this government's commitment to education, in particular to higher education and more innovative and effective ways of delivering it. The government does not support the amendment that has been moved by the opposition. I commend the bill to the House.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like an explanation of the unusual nature of proceedings. I am quite happy to be accommodating where it is within the rules. My understanding is that, when the Speaker vacates the chair, the chair is taken by a deputy chairman of committees and it ought not be the same person. I would not like there to be some flaw in relation to this matter. It has some implications in relation to the way in which legislation might be passed. It may be that a university might challenge the efficacy of the decisions that the government is taking in relation to this matter. They might want to challenge the number of places. If we allow a technical defect to arise, obviously there could be a very serious flaw in the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN (Mr Les Scott)—I am indebted to the honourable member. The honourable member for Cowper will take the chair.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the chamber. I requested the committee stage without warning and that is why there was no Chairman of Committees here. I was not worried about the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) taking the chair. I was worried about who he was going to report to when the time came.

PARA.TAB: The opposition requested the committee stage because there are a couple of comments I want to make. I offer the apologies of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Dr Wooldridge)—the shadow Minister for Employment, Education and Training—for not being here to take part in the debate. He is actually interstate. It is the lot of people in his position. I am sure that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) will understand.

I appreciate the contribution of the minister and welcome the fact that perhaps we are actually going to start debating some education issues in this chamber. There are a couple of things I want to refer to on behalf of the opposition.

I make it clear that the opposition supports moves that will open up opportunities for students and lessen the rigidity of the present situation. We recognise that that is what the government is attempting to do at least in the terms that the minister stated in his speech in reply to the second reading debate. I will not reiterate all of our arguments about how we think that should be done differently. However, we do recognise that there are problems at present with students staying on to get further qualifications and thereby occupying places, making them unavailable to other students to enter tertiary education at all. It was for that reason that we had moved an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the bill that this matter needed to be looked at.

The levying of HECS on students according to their present qualifications and, in particular, what their student load will be is one of the very important issues in this bill. We have all heard arguments from a wide range of people, including the National Union of Students, academics and others, about whether or not this move is fair. The opposition sought, through its amendment, to get a committee to call in this evidence and find out the facts about how people will be affected. Perhaps it is possible that the government might look at a relevant modification of this policy. Having said that, we do not defend a situation where people stay in the system, year in, year out, doing courses and getting qualifications, becoming the professional students we hear about and, under the present limited situation, thereby denying other students access to any tertiary education at all.

The minister quite rightly pointed out that institutions have pursued certain courses which have exacerbated the situation. Many times during my years in this place I have pointed out that we have to be vigilant on behalf of students. One cannot leave it to those who make decisions in universities as they do not necessarily put the interests of students first on all occasions. I have witnessed that often enough. There is a role for politicians to make sure that students' interests are protected. I would hope that that is what we—the government and the opposition—are about in this place.

I turn to the minister's statements in relation to school leavers. I reiterate and emphasise that we do not want to see school leavers put at a disadvantage by mature aged students, but we also do not want to see mature aged students put at a disadvantage by school leavers. The rigidities make it an either/or situation and are at the core of our criticisms of the direction of the government's education policy.

The minister said—I tried to write his words down but may not have them absolutely accurately—that the opportunities for school leavers fell in the 1990-93 period by approximately eight per cent and that this figure had to be improved. He said that this is obviously a matter of great concern. Our criticism is that the Government's approach amounts to rearranging deckchairs. We are still very concerned about mature aged students—those who did not have access to tertiary education in their time—those who, for reasons of geography, marital status, lot in life, fate or whatever, could not have study at the tertiary level.

We are also concerned about people who have qualifications but who, because of changes in our society, in our economy, now find themselves unemployed. People with heavy family responsibilities and commitments in life are finding that their qualifications no longer carry them into employment, whether it is because they are out of date or because industry has changed. These people who find themselves in competition with younger people with newer, more relevant qualifications are seeking to go back to tertiary institutions to get further qualifications. We read about this all the time.

I am sure the minister is as aware as anybody is of the great heartache out there in the community, particularly amongst those aged 40-plus who are finding themselves on the scrap heap. This will be an increasing problem in our society. For 10 to 15 years, that issue has been raised in debates on education in this parliament. The issue involved is access by older people to further education and training so that they can keep up with technology, remain employable and remain contributing members of society. These people, for a variety of reasons, are very important. The minister said that the government's aim is that mature aged students constitute 50 per cent of tertiary entrants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even with this change, it will remain at 50 per cent.

—I thank the minister for that clarification. That is still a very significant reduction. The figures I quoted from an NBEET report showed that in the seven years to 1993 mature aged tertiary entrants had dropped from 55.7 per cent of first year undergraduates to 47.9 per cent. Even 50 per cent is a big reduction from the 55.7 per cent that we had back in the mid-1980s. I believe that the pressure on the system would have become very much heavier since then. The opposition had hoped that the Open Learning Agency would have attracted more enrolments than it has. It is included in this bill because there is a downgrading of funding following an enrolment shortfall. We are very concerned about that.

PARA.TAB: I want to say a few words about what the minister had to say about allocating places and bidding for places. Anyone who reads this debate might well be confused about the figures we are talking about. I will place on the record the figures that I have been referring to in this debate because they are not contained in any official document before the parliament and would not be easy to access. The information I have from the department was that the 1996 allocation would be New South Wales, 350; Victoria, nil; Queensland, 370; Western Australia, 200; South Australia, 295; Tasmania, 135; ACT, 60; Northern Territory, 15; Australian Catholic University, which has campuses in New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and the ACT, 150. That adds up to 1,575. I have only just done the additions because I wanted to see whether the figure was 1,000 or 1,500. Obviously something is a little bit loose there. Those are figures which were supplied to the opposition and to which I have been referring.

The fact that only 1,000 were allocated and that 500 are still up for grabs raises an even bigger question mark over those figures. We will be looking with great interest to see what the outcome is. I will be very interested to see whether Queensland stays at 370 and whether the Gold Coast, which is an area of significant disadvantage in terms of tertiary places, maintains its position.

I thought it was necessary to put those figures on the record, otherwise the debate would be a bit of a nonsense to people who may wish to refer to it. If the minister can clarify those figures any further, I would be very obliged.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Mr Crean)—by leave—read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (HOME CHILD CARE AND PARTNER ALLOWANCES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 15 December, on motion by Mr Sciacca:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a number of comments about the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill. I hope that before we progress for too long the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca), who has some responsibility for this matter, might be present to hear what I have to say on behalf of the opposition.

PARA.TAB: This bill introduces two new allowances. The first is to be known as the home child-care allowance and the second as the partner allowance. These measures were announced in the 1993 election campaign. The bill includes amendments to the Social Security Act and the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990.

From 29 September 1994, a new allowance, to be known as the home child-care allowance, will be available through the social security system. I emphasise that this allowance replaces the dependent spouse rebate that is currently available through the tax system for couples with dependent children. It is important that people understand that point before we proceed. It is part of this government's pea and thimble trick that it proclaims that it has a new initiative which brings substantial benefits to large numbers of Australians while at the same time taking away other benefits that are payable to them. And it holds it out as if it is a new initiative! What surprises me is that the government has the audacity to present some 11 members to speak on this bill who will probably want to tell us that it is a great new initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.
—I heard the honourable member for Moreton. He will not want to acknowledge that it is a pea and thimble trick.
—Rubbish!

—Well, I will take people through it. The maximum rate of allowance will be $1,560 per annum, indexed annually. The allowance will not be taxable, but it will be subject to an income test based only upon the dependent partner's income. The income of the non-dependent partner will not be so tested. The cut-out point for the home child-care allowance is $250.85 per fortnight or $6,522.10 per annum. The payment reduces at 25c in the dollar. It is a tapered test. The comparable cut-out point for the dependent spouse rebate is $5,982 per annum.

PARA.TAB: The point is clear that a benefit that is paid largely on the same basis as the existing dependent spouse rebate is to be paid not through the tax system but through the social security system. It will be paid until the end of the calendar year in which a dependent child, generally the youngest child, turns 18 or until the child ceases secondary schooling, whichever happens first.

The benefit will not be paid when a child is a prescribed student, except if the child is qualified to receive payments under the assistance for isolated children scheme. A prescribed student child is a young person who has turned 16 and is qualified to receive payments under a prescribed educational scheme such as Austudy or Abstudy. To qualify for the allowance, the person needs to be an inhabitant of Australia and physically present in Australia.

There is to be another allowance: the partner allowance. The complexity of these matters never ceases to amaze me. The abolition of the dependent spouse rebate for couples with dependent children means that some current recipients of the job search allowance, newstart allowance, sickness allowance and special benefit will be required to pay tax on their allowances unless further amendments are made to the social security system. I am not complaining about that—it is to make the scheme coherent—but paying an additional allowance to make a coherent scheme begs the question. To overcome this consequence, a second new allowance, the partner allowance, will be introduced in September 1994, and changes are to be made to the beneficiary tax rebates available now under the tax system.

So we have separate legislation—it will keep us legislators in business—in relation to the Income Tax Assessment Act to remove the beneficiary tax rebate scheme that is now available. The partner allowance will be paid instead. It is to be an additional amount of allowance paid to the current recipients of the benefits that I mentioned. The partner allowance will be available to dependent partners of those receiving special benefits as well. The partner allowance will be paid directly to the dependent partner. The combined amount of allowances received by these couples is said not to be affected by these changes.

It is interesting that when we go to the estimated outlays for both of these measures—and some of the information is given in the explanatory memorandum—we find that the first year in which we can see the full year effects of these changes is 1996-97. The reason is fairly simple. It would appear that the government will have a net outcome of quite a substantial budget effect in 1994-95 and 1995-96. It is because of the extent to which the new outlays are paid up front and because people will have to claim later their dependent spouse rebates that the savings are not generated immediately.

In 1996-97 the government will receive in the order of $900 million—$920.3 million to be precise—in extra tax through the abolition of the dependent spouse rebate. The net additional cost, or the outlay effect, of the new scheme in that year in the social security budget is $1,146.5 billion. We can see that the net budget effect of these proposals is not a new benefit of over $1 billion to families; the net outcome is $226.2 million in the year 1996-97. That is the effect of these changes.

I want to make it clear at the outset that we will not be opposing this bill, but we are intending to draw to people's attention some of the consequences of this legislation that are not readily understood, or explained by the parliamentary secretary, or explained in the explanatory memorandum. The government would have us believe that these proposals are more generous, but the income of most families will not change, other than as a result of other changes the government made in the last budget. There are certain families—and this is an advantage of some sort—who only receive beneficiary income at the moment where there are no tax amounts payable in that family situation and where there would be no dependent spouse rebate available. Those families will receive an additional benefit. I acknowledge that.

One of the other changes, we are told, is that the benefit will be paid directly to the parent caring for the child rather than to the parent who receives the tax concession. I imagine that that is another significant advantage. The point is often made that the maternal spouse, or the one that is caring, carries a greater load of certain types of expenditures. That would be the argument. Of course, the benefit is immediately payable through the social security system. It will go onto the same rates at which the family payments are paid. As a consequence, rather than waiting until the end of the year or receiving it through the reduced pay instalment reduction, on which basis the dependent spouse rebate is presently paid, if people fall within the income test limits, the amount will be available immediately rather than at the end of the year. They are the advantages.

I put that because I think it is fair to outline those changes, but I think there are other ways in which these effects could have been achieved. Certainly, it would have been characterised in a different way if the government had seen fit to look at changes that might more accurately reflect efficient administrative arrangements.One has to wonder why we have the child support scheme in the Australian Taxation Office. Why is an office which deals with tax making payments to people who are receiving maintenance? Why is it involved in collecting and paying those instalments? One has to wonder why the tax office has been set up with that responsibility if logically the social security department should have been doing it.

As part of these changes the government introduces a child-care rebate scheme. What do we do in relation to that? We do not make the payments through the social security system, we make them through the Medibank offices. What sorts of coherent, sensible administrative arrangements are we putting in place if we have to amend a multiplicity of acts and have to establish a separate bureaucracy for each form of payment that is being made? Where is the sense?

The government would argue that it is providing these additional benefits because it wants to help families. These are certainly not the same families who this year, in the Year of the Family, have suffered as a result of the income ceiling being reduced from $64,938 to $60,000 for the basic family payment for families with one child or who have suffered as a result of the additional amount allowed for each child being reduced from $3,249 to $3,000. Certainly they are not the same families who saw the existing assets value limit for the basic family payment reduced from $607,250 to $550,000; who saw the application of the family payment and income test to new student parents—after the reduction we made, it now applies only to those going into the system, as distinct from those who are already there; who saw the employer provided fringe benefits now taken into account for income testing for family payments; and who saw some people in necessitous circumstances losing benefits, particular those in remote areas, in defence forces and the like. The government was not prepared to accommodate them when it made these changes.

These measures stop 116,000 families in the system from receiving family payments. And of course there is a cut in the payment which many other families will receive and on which they are dependent. It excludes the 116,000 families but there are a lot of others who have reduced benefits in the family payment system—not the same system we are debating here today. We are talking about the income available to support families; this wonderful new initiative of the government. I have to say that if it was a big initiative for the Year of the Family then it misses its mark widely.

I want to make some other comments in relation to it. It is interesting that, while we are stopping 116,000 families from receiving family payments, there are some people who will gain eligibility for assistance—the government did not explain this. We are not opposing this either, but it ought to be understood that holders of PRC entry permits or refugee entry permits come into it for the first time. So at the same time as some families are losing benefits, new families are receiving benefits that we were not told about. I guess that is one of the reasons why the system costs an extra $200 million to administer.

I want to take honourable members through some of the other matters because the opposition, while not opposing this measure, will be seeking to refer the bill to a committee of the Senate for an inquiry. The reason is clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is original.

—The originality comes in the matters that we think ought to be investigated. It will need to look at the definitions of income that apply, and I will come to that in a moment because there are some people who at the moment would receive the dependent spouse rebate and who, as it appears to me on reading this legislation, will not receive the child home care allowance. It will look at the application of the income tests, the administrative arrangements for couples when they separate and the adequacy of those arrangements and what happens when people are temporarily absent from Australia. On the date of application they have to be here, but what happens when they are away for short periods of time? It will look at the tax file number provisions. I imagine with a large number of additional Australians coming into a situation where there is data matching that will be a significant matter. These are issues, including the residency requirements, that we expect the Senate committee will review.

PARA.TAB: I want to address some of these factors because they have consequences and probably will not be readily understood. Hopefully, if there is an inquiry by the Senate, they will be better understood. I mentioned earlier in my introduction that the age requirements for this legislation are especially constructed to deal with situations where young people who are 18 years of age or who have ceased secondary schooling receive other prescribed educational payments. Because of the way the government has structured this at the moment, people with students up to the age of 25 now receive the dependent spouse rebate at a higher level. We now have a group of people with student children aged between 18 and 25 years receiving a lower rate of payment.

At the moment the dependent spouse rebate is paid for those with no dependent children and will continue to be paid to those with no dependent children. It will be paid at the rate of $1,188 per annum. But for those with dependent children it is paid at the rate of $1,425 per annum. The cut-off age for students under this new scheme is 18 years of age, whereas under the dependent spouse rebate scheme children in full-time education until they reach 25 years were counted. Taxpayers with student children satisfying the separate net income test of the Income Tax Assessment Act will lose out on the abolition of the dependent spouse rebate for couples with dependent children.

It is quite clear that the scheme cuts off the allowance to a student receiving the payment under a prescribed educational scheme; that is stated. Certainly, when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was making his announcements at Bankstown he was not saying to those dependants in the education system that there will be a lower rate of payment under this new arrangement and that they will be eliminated from receiving the benefits that are now paid. He was not prepared to do that.

The explanatory memorandum states in relation to this matter that the total cost of the outlays for the measures is $4.25 million which, I imagine, is administrative this year; $500 million in 1994-95; and $300 million in 1995-96. It would be interesting to know what the cost would have been if the dependent spouse rebate had been retained for students between the ages of 18 and 25. I suspect it is another one of these pea and thimble tricks that the government has been involved in.

For me it is a bit of an education to try to go back and rehash the residency requirements in the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Social Security Act and to make some sense of them. We are told that our Social Security Act is written in plain English. It is very interesting the way in which these provisions have been developed. As I take honourable members through it, they may start to wonder whether or not it will be an act in plain English after these new provisions.
The new home care provisions in the new section 904 provide that a dependent child cannot qualify for the new allowance unless:
the child is an `inhabitant of Australia'; or
or is a dependent child of an `inhabitant of Australia' and is living with that person.

SPEECH.PARA: What is an inhabitant of Australia? That is defined in section 23(1) of the Social Security Act. A resident of Australia—this is where the PRC students come into it—means:
(b)the holder of a refuge (temporary) entry permit; or
(c)the holder of an old domestic protection (temporary) entry permit; or
(d)the holder of an old PRC (temporary) entry permit; or
(e)the holder of a new domestic protection (temporary) entry permit; or
(f)the holder of a new PRC (temporary) entry permit.
They are defined as residents presumably because they would not have been so defined before.

PARA.TAB: An Australian resident is defined in section 7(2) of the Social Security Act as a person who:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)resides in Australia; and
(b)is one of the following:
(i)an Australian citizen;
(ii)a person who is, within the meaning of the Migration Act 1958, is the holder of the valid permanent entry permit;

Do those opposite want me to go on? It is fascinating; it is riveting reading. We need to understand that this is all qualified by the fact that people have to be present in Australia, which is a limiting factor. These factors are relevant to residents in Australia. A resident is defined as a person who resides in Australia. If we go to section 7(2) of the Social Security Act, we find out what factors are meant to be taken into account.

PARA.TAB: There is a fourth test. We have to look at the nature of the accommodation used by the person in Australia; the nature and extent of the family relationships the person has in Australia; the nature and extent of the person's employment, business or financial ties with Australia; the nature and extent of the person's assets in Australia; the frequency and duration of the person's travel outside Australia; and any other matter relevant to determining whether the person intends to remain permanently in Australia.

These tests, which are meant to assist, are quite different from the ones found in the Income Tax Assessment Act. That act contains four tests in relation to the dependent spouse rebate to determine whether a person is or is not resident in Australia. The act states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person satisfying any one of these tests will be a resident of Australia. These tests are:
(a)actual residence in Australia in the ordinary meaning of that expression;—
so we did not need a definition in relation to it—
(b)domicile in Australia—
a concept well known to the law—

PARA.TAB: unless the Commissioner is satisfied that his permanent place of abode is outside Australia;

SPEECH.PARA: (c)presence in Australia continuously and intermittently for more than one half of the year of income, unless the Commissioner is satisfied that his usual place of abode is outside Australia and he does not intend to take up residence in Australia; or
(d)an Australian official abroad and is a contributor to the superannuation fund for Commonwealth officers or is the spouse or child under 16 years of such a person.

What interests me is that we require people to be present in Australia to get this allowance, yet a residential requirement is there which enables officers, Australian officials and our defence forces, in the peace groups that are serving abroad and looking after Australia's interests, to continue to get the dependent spouse rebate. This legislation, drafted in plain English, is quite clear. The child had to be here in Australia on a given date to be able to receive it. So we write out those who are serving abroad in Australia's interests.

PARA.TAB: I regard that as another serious consequence of the way in which this legislation has been drafted. It may have been unintended, but with this government we would not know whether it was not another sneaky way, in the spirit of the pea and thimble trick, of ripping back from Australian taxpayers benefits they now receive.

I hope the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) is being helped by the advice he is now receiving. There has been no parliamentary secretary or minister with responsibility in this area present in the course of this debate to hear any comments. One wonders how they are able to contribute sensibly to a discussion of this sort.

I come to the question of the way in which definitions of income and income-free areas apply. The definition of ordinary income in the Social Security Act is designed to achieve payments on a needs basis. This allowance is not an income support measure and the ordinary income benchmark to establish the home child-care rate has been raised by the inclusion of further amounts for the purposes of section 926. The government wants to narrow the definition of income taken into account, whereas if it is trying to stop people getting benefits it needs to widen the definition of income to restrict people's eligibility. In the words of the explanatory memorandum:

SPEECH.PARA: These modifications are being made to better accommodate the nature of home child care allowance compared to other payments under the Principal Act.

When we look at the concept of the separate net income on which the dependent spouse rebate is based, we see that, while departing from the concept of taxable income, it is closely aligned with ordinary notions of income. On the other hand, the concept of ordinary income for the purposes of the Social Security Act has been modified to such an extent that it is a misnomer to refer to the outcome as ordinary income.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the dependent spouse rebate, provided for in the Income Tax Assessment Act, a statute that taxes income and capital gains, there are constraints on including amounts that are clearly not income or capital gains which are not present in extending the meaning of ordinary income within the Social Security Act, a statute basically providing income support and, in the case of the home child-care rebate, supplementary payment.

It is clear that the substitution of the dependent spouse rebate for couples with dependent children under the Income Tax Assessment Act with the home child-care allowance payments under the Social Security Act must disadvantage recipients of the dependent spouse rebate in view of the very wide definition of income. So, having regard to the fact that the need of couples with children for the concessionary payment is greater, it would appear to be, in my view, inequitable for the government to propose to let the dependent spouse rebate for couples without children remain unchanged.

It is very interesting that the government has left the dependent spouse rebate payable with all of the income tests that are presently used, which are considerably different to those which are now being used in the social security scheme, as people whose income situations are going to be roughly comparable and who are now receiving an allowance under the home child-care allowance arrangements will be considerably worse off in many cases, just because of the way in which the question of income is dealt with.

I think it is particularly interesting that the government gets into such complexity in trying to model a new scheme to fit closely the scheme that is being abolished. It then fails to be able to translate it into the new scheme adequately. That is clearly what is happening with this bill.

I do not think this bill can be dealt with in the parliament in a couple of sitting days. I certainly doubt whether very many members of the government will turn their minds to these questions. They will be in here trying to praise the government for what it has done, for its pea and thimble trick. For that reason, I think it is very appropriate that the Senate—it seems to be the only house to be able to do this, as the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) lamented last night—give adequate scrutiny to the bill. If we had a system whereby committees of this House were given responsibility to look at legislation, then we in this House could perhaps look at some of the details and seek to have them clarified.

The system being the way it is, the opposition will not oppose the measure but we will seek that reference to a committee in the Senate. We will ensure that this legislation is thoroughly examined and we will ensure that all of these tricks that the government has been engaged in are fully and thoroughly exposed. When it rips back the benefits people presently receive in order to expand benefits for a group of others, we will make sure that people who are the losers know why and how that occurred. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to be my lot in life as the chairman of the government's caucus community services committee to have the great pleasure of following the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) in a number of these debates. It is always entertaining to be in the House to listen to his contribution.

PARA.TAB: It was interesting tonight to sit here watching and waiting for the dramatic moments that the honourable member for Berowra always injects into his speech. But I was disappointed. It actually took eight minutes before he slammed his fists on the table, as he does in every debate. Throughout the 30 minutes there were long, pregnant pauses, mainly because he had to fluff out his 30-minute time limit. He had only about four minutes worth of points, so he had to be repetitive. He kept grasping at these pregnant pauses. He dramatically raises his voice when he has a really important point to make. It is really entertaining. It is great to be here and to listen to him. I am pleased that I have the opportunity to follow him on a regular basis.

All these New South Wales Liberal members are falling over and being made better offers. I wonder how long it will be before some great drama society in New South Wales realises what it is missing out on. It might make a great offer to the honourable member for Berowra to lead its cast in some great new production, because he certainly has the flair for dramatics and the language. There is not a lot of substance in what he says, but that is not needed when one is on the stage. A few good lines and great dramatic movements, together with a raised voice and shaking of the hands and banging of fists on a table—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's good enough for Bronwyn.

—That is right. The honourable member for Berowra has obviously been tutoring other New South Wales members of the Liberal party. He would be a great loss to this parliament, but if a better offer comes along he should take it. It was obvious from his whole presentation that he really was clutching at straws. He had the hide to describe a new policy program and an increase in funding to families in our community of $517 million in 1994-95 as a pea and thimble trick.
—You obviously didn't listen.

—I listened very clearly. I would love to have that pea. If he described $517 million as a pea, he should give me a lot of peas. A fair swag of money—it is an increase in funding—is going to families in this country.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, I noticed that you listened very intently to the presentation of the honourable member for Berowra. You would have observed that he could not tell you anything about what opposition members would do for families. There was no mention of their having all these great policies for families. The main reason for that is that they do not have a single policy. Their silly Fightback policy was so roundly rejected by the people of Australia just nine or 10 months ago that they are now bereft of policies. Not only are those opposite bereft of ideas and anybody who can lead them out of the wilderness but they have absolutely no policies. That was transparent in the presentation by the honourable member for Berowra. He could tell us nothing about what his party would do for families.

In the presentation of the honourable member for Berowra to honourable members of this House today, he failed to say that his party wanted to rip $10 billion off families and other welfare recipients in this country. That was part of the opposition's policies. It is an example of the great compassion of those opposite for families. Not only did they want to impose an additional tax on everything that families eat, wear and drink but also they wanted to rip $10 billion out of the welfare system.

The honourable member for Berowra had the hide to come here and pontificate in front of us. He did all these grand dramatics and said how dreadful it is that the government is planning to introduce a policy that, in the 1994-95 financial year, gives an extra $517 million to families. I will let the people of Australia make the decision—as they did in March and as I am sure they will do every three years for the next decade—about which party in this parliament has some care and compassion, new ideas and something of value to contribute to families. Which party is trying to identify areas of need and put in positive programs to assist families? It certainly is not the party that the honourable member for Berowra represents. That is clear by his presentation today.

It was an astounding presentation when one takes account of the fact that the policy we are implementing was an election policy. It was one that the people of Australia very positively responded to. It was one that the families of Australia recognised as being of benefit to them. This policy is another part of the package of election promises that this government is now implementing. I am proud to be here this afternoon speaking on behalf of the government in support of this legislation. This is a very positive, new initiative. This is something of which the Australian Labor Party can be proud. This policy will benefit families around this country.

In the few moments I have available to me, I want to outline some of the facts, as compared with the furphies that we heard from the previous speaker, about this legislation. Today we are talking about two new allowances: the home child-care allowance and the partner allowance. Some important facts that people need to appreciate is that this new home child-care allowance will benefit 840,000 families throughout Australia. That is a major achievement in this International Year of the Family.

However, what is more important is that approximately 55,000 families whose tax liability was previously too low to get the full value of the existing dependent spouse rebate will now receive much greater assistance from this new allowance because of the introduction of the home child-care allowance. The honourable member for Berowra was not prepared to admit that very important point.

The honourable member for Berowra clutched at straws when outlining some problems. We specified in the legislation the specific tests that would be required. We talked about residency. We dared to say that people have to be resident in Australia to receive the allowance. He railed against the government for that. But if we had not included those measures and clearly set them out in the legislation he would have said, `This is an incompetent government. It is prepared to give this allowance to anybody. You do not even have to be in the country and you will still get it'.

One cannot win with the honourable member for Berowra or opposition members generally. They purely oppose whatever comes forward. Although the opposition has indicated its intention to support this legislation, one would never know it by the way the honourable member for Berowra railed on this afternoon.

One very important point in this legislation is that, through this process of the home child-care allowance and the partner allowance, the government is ensuring that the person who has the direct responsibility for caring for children in the home—the dependent spouse in the home—will be the recipient of this money. Previously, through the dependent spouse rebate system used in the tax system, the worker who was bringing home the pay packet got the benefit of the dependent spouse rebate through his or her tax rebate. There was no guarantee that the spouse who was at home looking after the children got any of that money. The family got it, but it was not necessarily ensured that the dependent spouse got it.

This legislation ensures that the person who is responsible for the care of children in the home will receive the money. The fact that those who have that responsibility will get the money is a very important philosophical improvement and something about which we should all be very pleased.

That is what is also important about the changes in the partner allowance. The additional income that was attached to the jobsearch allowance and the other unemployment and social security benefits which were added to the recipient's payments for his or her dependent spouse will now be separated and sent to the spouse so that he or she has the opportunity to receive that income for his or her needs.

The income level that has been set is an increase over and above what was previously allowable. It is a significant additional contribution by the government to the welfare of families in this country. It is something about which we should be very pleased. I believe that the system as it is outlined in the legislation makes the current system much fairer. As the honourable member for Berowra has indicated, some people who currently receive the dependent spouse rebate will no longer receive it because of the imposition of the income test.

This means that the system of financial support to families in this country corresponds with the system that applies generally to social security; that is, it is targeted to those who have the greatest need. I do not think that is a principle that we should have any problems with and I do not believe it is a principle that the people of Australia disagree with. They believe that government payments should be targeted to those families or individuals—whether they be aged persons, young families or people with disabilities—who have few resources and assets to be able to fend for themselves. That is the purpose of introducing an income test on the allocation of the home child-care allowance.

The procedures outlined in this legislation are very important and the government is rightly proud of them. It is the implementation of an election commitment and continues the record set since the election of the government of fulfilling all of its election commitments, as we did through the budget last year and will do now in this measure. It is an important new addition to the package of financial support that this government provides to families in this country.

I would like to raise in this debate another element of care for families. My view is that there is a need for some improvement in the access to occasional care facilities for the very people we are talking about; that is, dependent spouses at home who have responsibility for children. It is an area in which I would like to see some additional effort made by the government over the next couple of years.

At the moment the government funds around 4,200 occasional child-care places nationally. Funding is available for another 780 places, but they are yet to be put in place by state governments. We have a commitment for 5,000 occasional care places—4,200 are currently in place and 780 are yet to be put in place. Some 18 per cent of long day care usage is for non-work related care; in other words, it is for people at home who wish to use the child care for purposes other than studying, looking for jobs or actually being in employment. That amounts to some additional 28,000 equivalent full-time places for occasional day care.

As I indicated, some 840,000 families in this country have a dependent spouse with dependent children at home. Therefore, the number of places available for occasional day care for those people is quite low. The last time the government introduced any major new initiative to boost the number of places in occasional day care was in the 1988 child-care strategy, which flowed through until 1990-91 when most of the capital expenditure was spent on provision of places.

In the 1993-94 financial year the government will be spending some $10.9 million on the provision of occasional day care. It is a very important contribution for those spouses at home. It is part of a very large package of child care that the government has implemented in the last six to seven years. But because over the last few years we have placed such a priority on work related child care and on providing places in the child-care system for mainly women who wish to return to work and who have child-care responsibilities, we seem to have lacked paying enough attention to those people who are in the home and who have child-care needs as well, but who are not working or seeking further study.

I place on record my view that, in the next budget or within the next two years, the government should seek to increase the allocation for occasional care, but also try to sort out some of the problems that are currently existing, particularly with the New South Wales state government, in the implementation of the current agreements. I indicated that some 780 places for occasional care were funded out of the 1988 strategy that are yet to be put in place. Out of that 780, 670 are in New South Wales.

There seems to have been some blockage between the New South Wales government and the federal government in working out the financial arrangements to enable those places to be built and to be funded on a recurrent basis. That is denying the families of New South Wales and the dependent spouses of New South Wales an opportunity to have access to those occasional care places. It is very important that, whatever those problems are, the two governments sit down and work them out so that we can get that funding flowing into the community to provide those places. It is one of the concerns that is raised with me in my electorate, even though the Queensland government has been very good in negotiating with the federal government. Only a handful of places are yet to be fully funded in Queensland.

In my electorate I have a number of dependent spouses, people at home caring for children, who have raised with me their concerns that all of the child-care places in our area are taken up by working people and that they have little or no access to occasional care so that they can carry out their responsibilities. We should not forget that in most cases it is the full-time mothers at home who are contributing greatly to our community in the form of assisting in schools, community organisations and a range of other areas in a voluntary capacity. In order for them to perform that very valuable community role that we absolutely rely on in our schools and community organisations, we need to have some additional child-care places for them so that they can place their toddler children in occasional care. This will then enable them to be able to work for organisations such as Meals on Wheels or to work in the school tuckshop or in school classrooms.

As the government has placed a very strong and appropriate emphasis on work related child care, I fear that the provision of occasional day care has tended to lapse in the last two years. I urge the government to consider an increase in funding over the next two years for the provision of occasional day care places so that we can correct that imbalance and provide that service to those families who are playing that very important role of raising children in their own home, who are playing important roles in community organisations and institutions such as schools and who are acting as volunteers in nursing homes or in a whole host of other places. They are providing to the community important services which are not work related, but they also need access to that occasional care. So I ask for a little redress in the current balance of provision of child-care places in the next budget or two.

The Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill, which we are talking about today, is a very important new initiative by the government. It is a much fairer and more equitable way to distribute family support to those people who are staying at home and caring for dependent children. It is a very strong initiative in this International Year of the Family which will amount to an additional $517 million in 1994-95 and an additional $341.5 million in 1995-96. It is by no stretch of the imagination a pea and thimble trick. It is a significant additional expenditure for the provision of families in this community. It is something that this government is very proud of and I am proud to support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that I will have the ear of Deputy Speaker Hollis for the next 20 minutes or so, as he and I have had a few private discussions about some of these issues over the last few weeks. This debate, as the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) suggested, is timely because it is the International Year of the Family and child care is a very important subject for all families.

PARA.TAB: On the face of it, the changes that this legislation brings are quite supportable. The principle of recognising the importance of the contribution made by a stay-at-home or non-working parent to the care of children is a very important one. However, in practice, the dependent spouse rebate achieved the same purpose, but for some reason it is no longer politically correct to regard the stay-at-home parent as dependent, and I suppose it is not worth having a deep argument about that. Dependency is out. It might be natural, but it is not politically correct.

I do not really want to dwell too much on that issue. I accept the change in respect of that factor. I understand, particularly as I have taken advantage of the dependent spouse rebate in my own tax for many years, that the rebate really did get lost somehow in the working spouse's tax return. The $30 per week maximum which the home care parent will receive will be of more practical use. I do not think there is any doubt about that.

However, I take up the point that the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) made in speaking for the opposition on this matter and take issue with the honourable member for Moreton. I do not do that terribly often, but on this occasion I will. There was an element of dishonesty, or a misleading element, let me say, in the way this legislation was introduced. It was foreshadowed with a flourish by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) early in the election campaign. The impression that he gave then—and, indeed, the impression that I had for some time—was that this measure was something new and that it was over and above all existing mechanisms. It was only when we read the fine print that we found, despite what the honourable member for Moreton said, that this measure is essentially revenue neutral.

I concede that there were some families who did not get the full dependent spouse rebate—55,000 families, I think he said—and I am prepared to accept that figure. They will get the home child-care allowance. That is where the additional expenditure comes from. But by and large one cannot argue that this is other than revenue neutral. The substantial effect of this legislation is to replace the dependent spouse rebate with the home child-care allowance. As I have said, in principle I do not have a problem with that. In fact, the principle I subscribe to very strongly because it recognises the importance of the contribution made by a stay-at-home parent to the care of children.

The shadow minister for social security, the honourable member for Berowra, has outlined a number of important practical concerns we have about the legislation. They are detailed concerns. Hence the opposition's intention to refer this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. There are a number of unanswered questions about it.

As I said, child care is, quite correctly, an important element in the debate which is occurring in the International Year of the Family. The remarks I want to make tonight hopefully will be accepted in the broad context of that debate. The government, and particularly the minister, Senator Crowley, whom I call, perhaps a little unkindly but quite pointedly, not the Minister for Family Services but the minister for family disservices, has already turned the International Year of the Family into a platform for all sorts of minority groups who aspire to be regarded as families. But the real focus in the IYF needs to be on children, not on the rights of consenting adults or on all sorts of other peripheral issues that the so-called Minister for Family Services wants to talk about.

I do not think the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) will disagree—although she has on occasions disagreed with me—that child care is essentially, fundamentally, basically, a parental responsibility. Any couple who have children must start from that point. They must realise that the care and upbringing of those children is their responsibility. I do not think there is an argument against that—not, at least, a cogent one that I have ever heard. However, the extent to which they undertake the function of child care personally or delegate it to somebody else is the matter which is being debated. I use the word `delegate' very carefully, for when parents do give the responsibility to someone else it is a delegated responsibility. For ultimately the responsibility for the care and upbringing of those children is the parents' responsibility. That is a very important underlying point that needs to be made early in this debate.

The next point may be a little more controversial. I challenge the honourable member for Forde, and the long list of government speakers who have been trotted out on this subject—and I will listen to them all with interest—to refute that most people accept that parent care is best. I say that again: parent care is best. I think most people recognise that, except for the social engineers such as the minister, who apparently wants to get children into government accredited child-care centres as soon as possible so that boys can be taught to play with dolls and girls with cars and all sorts of other things. Social engineering is really what it is. I have no doubt about that.

Most authorities agree that nobody and nothing substitute for a child's parents—mother and father ideally. Studies in bonding and attachment theory have shown that a child's emotional and mental wellbeing are closely related to the level of contact between, particularly—whether you like it or not—a mother and her child. One study concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: Children deprived of parental care in early childhood are likely to be withdrawn, disruptive, insecure or even intellectually stunted.

They are not my words; I am quoting them from a so-called expert. We could even read `and uncivilised' into that, dare I use such a word. The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), used that word in that broad context recently and the press picked it up; the politically correct out there grabbed it and ran with it and distorted it and twisted it.

PARA.TAB: John Hyde pointed out in his column in the Australian on 7 January that Norman Dennis, writing for the London thinktank the Institute of Economic Affairs, looks at crime and broken families and makes a connection regarding the functional family, whose children, in Mr Dennis's words, are more likely to become civilised—again using that word in its proper sense—than those who have not had that advantage, that is, the advantage of a proper functional family and proper parental care and involvement. Of course, John Hyde in his column recognises, and the honourable member for Gwydir certainly found out, that that—and I quote John Hyde—`is a singularly politically incorrect conclusion but one that may have the virtue of truth'. As one family expert put it:

SPEECH.PARA: In three decades of work as a social scientist, I know of few other bodies of data in which the weight of evidence is so decisively on one side of the issue. On the whole, for children, two-parent families are preferable to single-parent families and step families.

Of course, we all know of happy single parent families and unhappy two-parent families. I was just talking to one of my own staff before I came down here who is a single mum. She has four wonderful children, all of them university educated. So I do not dispute for a moment that there are not very good children who are the results of single parents. What I am saying is that this is not the ideal. It is not me who is saying that; it is all of the experts who say that.

PARA.TAB: The case for the two-parent family is not—and I underline this for the benefit of the honourable member for Forde, who will have the opportunity to speak after me, and who I am sure will take the opportunity to say something on this—about knocking single parent families. To highlight the importance of two-parent families is not to denigrate those who find themselves, often through no fault of their own, in the position of being single parents. I emphasise this for the benefit of the honourable member opposite, because do I not want to be misrepresented.

The facts are that, by a number of indicators, children from intact, stable two-parent families will do much better than children from broken homes or single parent families. The experts say that. I think it is commonsense by and large, but the experts who have done decent studies on it conclude that. I have not seen anything that refutes that contention.

A number of studies show that children from mother-only families attain fewer years of education and are far more likely to drop out of high school than children from intact families. A number of studies show a very real connection between delinquent or criminal behaviour and broken families. Those opposite might not like that and might want to say, `Hang on, that is putting down single parent families', but I emphasise that it is not. These are facts.

Suicide rates also tend to be higher amongst those from broken homes. That is probably understandable, too, up to a point. For example, a statistically significant incidence of separation and divorce has been observed in the families of adolescents who attempt suicide as compared with others in controlled groups. All of this reinforces the importance of parents to children. That is the only reason I am making these points and putting them on the record.

Parents are important to children. Some people probably think that that is not the case. I do not think that the social engineers, many people in the government and the minister, in particular, are really prepared to accept, other than in some general terms, that parents are important to kids. I listened to some of them and I actually think they believe that parents are dangerous for kids and that kids are better off away from their parents. There may be the odd or obscure small percentage of cases where that is true, but I am saying that the vast majority of kids are better off being cared for by their parents. The more parent care they get when they are young, I suspect that as they get older the better off they are. They cannot get enough of it.

I would like to hear someone argue against that in the vast majority of cases. I ask honourable members opposite not to get up and trot out, `There are 20,000 kids who are abused every year'—or however they want to define that. We are talking about millions of kids who are better off with continual exposure to their parents—the more, the better.

I ask those opposite, in respect of this particular legislation: does this legislation really recognise the importance of parent care? On my analysis of it, the answer has to be a resounding no. In fact, this legislation really focuses attention on how fundamentally flawed this government's approach to supporting the family really is. Everything this government has done and continues to do is dictated by minorities, such as extreme feminists. I am not talking about feminists in general. I am very reluctant to do that when the honourable member for Forde is going to follow me in this debate. I am talking about extreme feminists.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are `feminazis'.

—`Feminazis', that is the latest term. Is that not appropriate? I think I heard somebody the other day call them members of the sisterhood. But, unfortunately, the job culture which some of these extreme feminists have created has totally invaded the family culture—overtaken and thrown out the family culture—and the children have suffered. As I said at the outset, that is what this debate is ultimately all about in the Year of the Family. The kids are important.

PARA.TAB: A rapidly growing share of our children are being raised by hired workers—by substitute parents. All of the research confirms that this is not ideal. Let me state quite clearly—also on the record so that people cannot take issue with this—I cast no aspersion on the qualifications or motivations of those who work in or operate child-care centres. There is a place for professional child care. There is a place, as the honourable member for Moreton was saying, for occasional, respite, part day care or whatever we want to call it. My criticism is not of those who work in child-care centres because they are just caught up in it. The people that are building the child-care centres are taking advantage of the system the government has created. My criticism is of this government.

The government's laissez faire approach to child-care funding—as it was with nursing home funding until it woke up to what was going on—has seen a huge proliferation in child-care centres. As my wife observed quite cleverly the other day, instead of corner stores, we now have corner kindies. Every time we go down the road there is a new one popping up. There has been no real attempt, as far as I can see, on behalf of this government or any government to ensure this proper targeting of government funding to meet the needs of a certain area. It depends on the local council. Child-care centres are popping up everywhere.

What really has been missing in this huge child-care boom, which is going on and which is underwritten by the taxpayers of this country, is planning and targeting. The federal government has effectively given an open cheque to speculators in allowing 85 per cent of fees to be subsidised for those on low incomes—interestingly, whether they are working or not.

Even on that issue I can never quite figure out the rationale for, say, an unemployed couple who, unfortunate as they may be—I do not want to sound uncompassionate here because I need to be PC on that issue as well—have to go looking for jobs and then putting one of their young children in child care five days a week. Why? Because they get an 85 per cent subsidy. Because they can get it for 32c an hour. Why would we put that incentive there? Why would we tempt them with that sort of incentive? It just does not make sense to me why the taxpayers should be paying unemployment benefits on the one hand and giving those unemployed a full subsidy to have their children minded 50 hours a week on the other hand. I am not suggesting that there is not a need for respite care to give them time to go looking for jobs, or to study, or to do whatever, but surely there is something wrong with the extent of this. That is the point that I am making.

The sad fact is, ultimately, that many couples do not have any choice about who cares for their young children. I say sad because it is a sad fact. The parents would like to choose parent care, but the financial realities for them are otherwise. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) tried to tell us yesterday that buying a house was now within the reach of every couple in Australia. Of course, that is not true. The reality is different, as many young couples are finding out. They both must work if they are to have any chance of making mortgage payments on a new home, let alone the cost of electricity, rates, taxes, pest control or anything else that people have to put into their budget when they are trying to buy a house.

The government's whole approach has been to create incentives for mothers of young children to enter the work force. Why? Surely not, as Mike Seccombe suggests in his article in last week's Sydney Morning Herald, because women are needed by the national economy. What about the one million people who are already unemployed? They are needed in the national economy as well. Ironically, it is the increasing participation rates of women in the work force—do not necessarily get me wrong here, please, because I understand that women can choose to work, and that is great—which have created the whole unemployment problem in the first place.

To make the point even more strongly, when we are talking about the home child care allowance of $30 a week, the maximum rebate for work related child care is over $60, but it goes further. Low income earners with children, including—we might observe once again—the unfortunate unemployed, can actually get up to $92.50 a week for 50 hours care in a child centre. The debate in this matter has only just begun, not just tonight on this particular legislation, but on this whole area of what is best for families and what is best for kids.
