It is my contention, carefully considered I might add, that the government has it all wrong. The big question is, `What is best for children'? The government, in its enthusiasm for social engineering, has lost sight of this.

Every bit of this government's approach ultimately is anti-family. Its industrial relations policy perpetuates unemployment and is biased against part-time work to allow time for families. Its tax system precludes income splitting, which would benefit marriages and which provide a financial incentive for non-earning spouses to enter the work force.

Finally, the social security system then becomes enormously complex and almost unworkable as the government attempts to apply bandaids to a society which is haemorrhaging all over the place. The sad fact is that the solutions to many of these problems are simple, but not politically correct. Many mothers of young children who work would choose not to if they could. They have said that. The government could fascinate such a choice by paying the home child-care allowance at a realistic level; one that would put a true value on the service which is provided by the stay at home parent. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with great pleasure to speak on the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill because it is the implementation of government policy which was promised during the 1993 election campaign. As the government, we are prepared to keep our promises to families. This comes out of the Halfway to equal report and the recommendations which were made in that. I was a member of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which travelled Australia and spoke to a whole range of women's and men's organisations and to parents to seek what it was that they needed.

PARA.TAB: Many honourable members will recognise that the dependent spouse rebate for very many families, particularly those low income families, was really not available because the level of tax which many low income families paid meant they did not get the benefits of such a dependent spouse rebate. Many people to whom we spoke during that inquiry recommended that that rebate be changed and that some cash payment be made to recognise the kind of contribution which carers of children make to the children in particular and to society in general.

We recognise that the people who stay at home to look after children are usually mothers. But in this, the Year of the Family, we also need to recognise the great joy and the great celebration that belonging to a family brings both to the individuals and to the community. We need to recognise the enormous resource of joy and pleasure which they provide for the community.

While there have been some sidetracks into discussing the kinds of issues that the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) has raised, we have to remember that over 80 per cent of our families are a reflection of the kind of traditional family that we have here and that 13 per cent of our families are sole parent, with 94 per cent of those being headed by women. I know that statistics are drawn out and we ask, `What kind of children are best? Who does best? Who is richest?' and so on but what we do know in all the research is that the most important factors in any child's life are love and being cared for.

If children are surrounded by love and by caring, then those children grow up in an atmosphere in which they recognise themselves as a human being with dignity and they then can go on and so develop. But, of course, that is not always possible. We have very many people whose marriages have deteriorated and broken up. We have people whose husbands die, such as many of our war heroes, and so many women find themselves in the situation of being on their own with their children. Far be it for us to say that these children somehow come from dysfunctional families.

I think that perhaps what we need to focus on is the reality of families. In modern day Australia families come in all shapes and sizes; they come in all colours; and they speak all sorts of languages. Caring, love and concern are really the factors which determine what makes a family and for whom those families are. If love and generosity of spirit are about the important issues then I think we should all rejoice.

The honourable member for McPherson may not have noticed this, but in last weekend's Sunday Mail there was a wonderful story about a lady, who was by now a grandmother with 128 children, who had raised six or eight children on her own, who had come to Australia as a migrant and whose English—despite the fact that she had been here 40 years—was probably not terribly good. Articles such as this show us just what love and treasures family life can give us. I think that all of us perhaps get too sidetracked on statistics rather than looking at individuals and at people. After all, it is people who make up families.

These home child-care and partner allowances are about a recognition of people. This is a response to what people tell us they want. This is a government responding to the actual and factual way in which this society operates. We have heard the issues raised relating to child care. I say to honourable members opposite that in terms of fee relief we have the priority of access guidelines. Places in those centres have to be determined in an ordered and orderly fashion. If perchance there are people out there who are finding loopholes through the system, we have to say that those people and those child-care centre owners are the ones who are abusing the system. It is not the government which has established a very clear priority of access in response to what the community says it needs relating to the way in which it likes to delegate child care. Of course that is so. Child-care centres are part of our family. They are part of our children's growing up. They are part of our culture. They are there because this community and this society have shown us that they want to participate in the economic life of our community.

I am always somewhat bemused by people who suggest that there is somehow something terribly strange with women working. This argument has only emerged since women have got equal pay and have received considerably better jobs within our community. Prior to equal pay, very many women—poor women in our community—have always worked. They worked as housekeepers, cleaners and in factories. Women have worked for generations and for hundreds of years.

If we read about the Industrial Revolution in Britain, we read the terrible stories about women actually having babies on the floor of those factories while the mills continued to roll and about women in the coalmines with their children working. Nobody suggested that somehow that was a terrible thing until, in fact, we had social reformers. We saw poor women in this community work for very little pay. Nobody raised a question of that. It is only now that we have equal pay for women, that women have access to universities, to colleges, to highly paid and other decision making jobs in our community that suddenly it is wrong for women to work. I find it quite extraordinary.

This community and our society today are about choice. Women have shown in this community that they will make a choice across a whole range of things. We find that in over 60 per cent of families both partners work, which is an important point to make.

I find it somewhat ironic from those opposite who are from the conservative side of politics that somehow hired child-care workers are somewhat strange. The biggest users of hired workers and nonparental carers are the royal family and the monarchy. Somehow those opposite say to us, `This is the person who is to be admired and whom we must revere. These are the kind of people we want to control our world'. Yet in the next breath they tell us that children who are reared by hired workers are somehow second best and that they have not got the best kind of image. Surely members of the conservative opposition must see the paradox in those kinds of arguments.

We on this side say to those opposite that child care and child raising are about love, care and concern. It is also a recognition that child care is a difficult and an expensive job. People have a right to have that work acknowledged in our community because in our community we acknowledge jobs that are important by making payments for them.

We all know that traditionally in this community women have always done a huge amount of volunteer work. I might say that it is still women who are doing the caring, despite the fact that they have entered the work force—albeit many of them part time to accommodate their volunteer work in the community. They are in paid work a couple of days a week and give the rest of their time to tuckshops, meals on wheels and various other family commitments which they have, be it caring for their aged parents, elderly grandparents, parents-in-law, sisters or whatever. It is not just a question of the kind of child care and caring for children in the home that very many of our families find themselves in. Indeed, the Year of the Family celebrates the joy with which families support each other. It is the joy that comes from being part of that family and being part of a caring and supportive system that this government recognises through the kinds of allowances which we have here in this bill.

I find it quite extraordinary—I know the honourable member for McPherson said he was concerned that I would raise the issue of women entering the work force—that some of the big changes relating to our unemployed have been brought about by the restructuring of the work force, the kinds of micro-economic reforms that we hear lauded by so many of the industrialists. Indeed, the changing nature of work has meant that very many people's jobs have gone.

We have all heard about—I have certainly cited them here before—some of the big steel factories. One in my electorate used to have 480 people in its work force. It modernised, trebled its production and now has a work force of only 120, simply because those jobs have gone. It has modernised; it is more productive—all the kinds of things we hear lauded as being important. So our driving force must be to find new industries to enable people to be accommodated as the work force changes.

In our lifetime we have all seen enormous changes come about, particularly when we look at the way in which offices are run, the kinds of people who are needed and the kinds of skills which people need to run offices, such as communication and telephone skills. The honourable member for McPherson may be interested to know that telephones, when they were first invented, were considered to be too important to give women access to them. Nowadays being a telephonist is traditionally a woman's job.

Society is evolving, changing and moving. As it changes and moves, the views which perhaps people thought were important and which encapsulated what they saw as an ideal are possibly not true and perhaps never even really existed. As I have said in this House many times, I am tired of people telling me how wonderful the 1950s and 1960s were. I grew up in them and have no desire to ever return to them.

If we talk of home ownership and the lives of women being changed, let me tell honourable members that they have been changed dramatically from leaning over a hot copper, stoking up the stove, and hand-wringing out sheets and hanging them on the line, which people did until the advent of the washing-machine. I think perhaps we forget that houses have doubled in size from 12 to 22 squares; that people now have access to a whole range of communication services—cars, transport and other things—not to mention health and education services which existed in that period for a very small group of people in our community.

It may depend on where one comes from and where one is as to what was actually the golden age. But perhaps the golden age was simply an age when some people were young and tended to have a very distorted view about what the world was actually like.

The International Year of the Family, this home child-care and partner allowance, the government's policy in relation to families, family allowance and family allowance supplement, child care and child-care fee relief, the accreditation of child-care centres and the whole process of the way we support and assist families are acknowledgments of the needs of society. It is not a question of the government taking the lead; it is a question of the government responding to the needs of our community. As women and families demand child care of a different kind, as we see shifts in the way in which the work force operates, as we see the different roles that people may or may not have in their families, we as a government respond and say, `Yes, this will help you; this is for your support'.

I am quite horrified at the support for and the stories that have been around for some time about income splitting. I take people back to the inquiry into equal status for women in Australia and its subsequent Halfway to equal report. Indeed, there was a certain amount of discussion in that report on income splitting. I think we all would acknowledge that income splitting is of great advantage to the wealthier people in our community. We as a government have traditionally looked at those families which are in need and which we believe are deserving of our support. That is why we target our funding. That is why we have means testing. That is why we have priority needs. That is why we actually ensure that the people who are most in need receive our income.

I was somewhat horrified to hear an opposition speaker earlier complaining about the drop and change in the nature of the family allowance, that those families who are on $64,000 a year and were receiving family allowance are now no longer receiving it. Let me tell honourable members that in my electorate there are not very many people on $64,000 a year raising families. Most people who live very close to my electorate office and who are in receipt of the allowance are families that are probably on a third of that kind of income. Those people are very grateful for the family support they receive. I know that they welcome the home child-care allowance. For many of them, the dependent spouse rebate really meant very little. They do not pay or were not paying the level of tax which ensured that they could get the full benefit from that income tax rebate. While they have cash in their hands, they can actually purchase school shoes, clothing and family needs for their children.

I ask the members of the opposition to welcome these home child-care and partner allowances in the spirit in which they have been made. They are part of the government's commitment to our community, they are part of promises which were made, and we as a government uphold them.

The debate about the sorts of families we have and who are families is really very much a sidetracking of the issue. We have families of all sorts. Families bring us joy; families care for their members, be they children, adults, older people, extended families, next-door neighbours or whoever. All of those people make up families. The joy which families bring to individuals and to our community is what we are celebrating in this 1994 International Year of the Family.

We ensure that families are supported, that families are recognised and that families in all their shapes and sizes care for children. That care has to be recognised. We support them with this cash home child-care rebate. The same is true for the partner allowance in that partners support each other and they too form families. The question here is whether they have dependent children. That partner allowance is also an acknowledgment that people support each other and an acknowledgment that all families need to be looked after. That partner allowance, together with the home child-care allowance, is a cash payment that people can use each week and each fortnight in a meaningful way to meet the needs of those families.

We have seen the family allowance and the family allowance supplement welcomed by families, and we know that they will go out and spend it. We know that the community, and the business community in particular, responds very well to people spending those allowances and welcomes those allowances. The community forms part of the retail trade. The community will also welcome the home child-care and partner allowances as people spend them fortnightly in their local supermarkets and stores.

I am very pleased to be part of a government which has ensured that those women—it is mainly women—who care for their children at home now are acknowledged and that the partner allowance will be part of a cash payment each fortnight to support those families in our community that are in need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate that will take place during this International Year of the Family will be an interesting one because I believe that it will show that sound and happy families, children and parents together, produce adults who are sound and well adjusted and that they are of economic and social benefit to the community. I hope that this process does not become a competition between people saying that there is one form of a family that is equal to all others and, therefore, there is no preferable form of family. Study after study, psychological report after psychological report, research after research, Australia-wide and internationally, clearly demonstrate that the preferable family form for raising children is two parents, a mother and a father, together with the children.

PARA.TAB: I refer honourable members to a presidential report into urban families called for by the mayors of United States cities. In calling for the report, the mayors stated that it was their view that rising rates of family break-up were driving the United States major problems—crime, drugs, addiction, poverty, mental illness and falling school achievement—with immediate repercussions for the economy and the United States international competitiveness. I believe that by the end of this year the view held by US urban mayors, who said that their society had to cope with problems that were created by family break-up and the destruction of the family, will be firmly established.

I do not think it is a matter of looking back to the 1950s and 1960s, as the previous speaker hinted. It is a matter of looking at the really difficult problems in our society and asking: are we best trying to do a patch up job on the problems after they have occurred; or can we, as a society, analyse where some of these problems start and take remedial steps before they begin? That is what the government is failing to acknowledge during this debate. But I need to acknowledge the effectiveness of this small part of what I hope is a more extensive program of substance that the government may reveal during 1994.

What the government has done is taken the spouse allowance and directed it to the child carer. In that process, an additional 55,000 families become eligible for a benefit that they would not have otherwise received, and for those who already receive that benefit, it is directed to the carer, whether it be male or female. So that redirection of those resources is interesting and adequate. Even so, it has some shortcomings. The value of the spouse rebate is about $27 a week on average across the Australian community. Carers can now claim up to a maximum of $30 a week, so it is more targeted, a bit more restricted and, generally, I think a welcome process.

The trouble is that a two-income family would also gain a benefit that is roughly worth about $40 a week. In order to restore some equity in what the government is doing, a maximum of $40 a week would seem to be a more reasonable approach rather than limiting it to $30 a week. However, the government jumped on the bandwagon during the election campaign and said, `We are going to look after families with children'. People actually believed that this was an additional amount and that there was genuine intent behind the government's expressed concern. That has been proved wrong. It is not an additional amount; it is basically a redirection of funds.

I refer honourable members to some important comments which I think are foundational. Mr Brian Burdekin has blamed the breakdown of the traditional family in Australia for soaring levels of child abuse. In the Herald-Sun on 28 August 1993 Mr Burdekin pointed out that 70 to 80 per cent of child abuse cases in Melbourne come from non-nuclear, non-traditional families. Mr Burdekin declared his alarm at the apparent 500 per cent increase in sexual abuse of girls in families where the adult male was not the natural father.
I refer honourable members to a statement—and I think it is foundational—by Nathan Glazer, Professor of Social Structure at Harvard. In the publication Commentary, he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: On balance, it would seem that certain traditional arrangements, whether they are biologically determined or have been learned at some primordial stage of social development, work pretty well, and that despite the age-old hopes of radicals of both Left and Right, there is no better way to raise children than the family (as Churchill said of democracy, it is the worst way—except for all the others).
Daniel Moynihan made an interesting statement in the publication Nation and family when he wrote:

A nation without a conscious family policy leaves to chance and mischance an area of social reality of the utmost importance, which in consequence will be exposed to the untrammelled and frequently thoroughly undesirable impact of policies arising in other areas.

These writers are saying that we need to look at the foundations of our society and decide whether or not they are beneficial, and I would vote yes every time. Despite the facts that are often publicly presented in the press, I would go back to Brian Burdekin's statement because that is a thorough analysis and no-one can doubt his objectivity in this area. He has made it very clear that a family with a natural father and mother is by far the best way of avoiding child abuse—particularly sexual abuse of girls. We can point to other statistics; there is plenty of information—heaps of it.

PARA.TAB: What will the government do during this year? The government has made its first tentative step—and it is nothing more than that. It cannot be held up as some great innovation. It has taken funds already there and redirected them, albeit in a more thoughtful manner. The process is basically revenue neutral. But what will happen during the rest of the year when Australia's taxation, social welfare, and community support systems and institutions have to cope with families and their problems, and try to treat them as individuals?

Australia would have perhaps the most individualised taxation system in the world. There are few that can match the individualised process in the Australian tax system. That is one area that needs close attention. We need to draw on experience and examples and deal with hard facts, not emotion, in looking at the results of different tax systems and see whether, in fact, they are more beneficial to Australian families than the current Australian taxation system.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics produced a report that said that 80 per cent of people living in one home are still recognisable as traditional families, while only six per cent are de facto families. Nevertheless, under pressure of both the law and the media, an increasing number of people are refusing to enter into any legal relationship at all. An increasing number of people in de facto relationships do not live in the same house. If the law, through the processes of government, encourages that process, we ought to make an assessment of whether that is an effective role for government. Is the government being positive or negative in its impact on society? Is it catering to small group pressure or cries that at the time seem worthy but when analysed prove to be detrimental if applied broadly?

The government has been tardy in its establishment of a program for the International Year of the Family compared with the International Year for the World's Indigenous People. I understand that we are now into a decade for indigenous people. A working party was set up twelve months prior to the start of the International Year for the World's Indigenous People. It was only in the latter months of 1993 that the government focused any attention whatsoever on the International Year of the Family. For those who think this is a right wing conservative sort of issue, the International Labour Organisation, in its report entitled Women workers in a changing world, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: No woman should be forced by economic circumstances to work outside her home . . . Women with family responsibilities, particularly those with young children, should be able to stay at home if they wish so. As has often been emphasised, the incontestable right of every mother to remain within the home and to bring up her children herself should be protected and respected. This emphasises the general desirability of formulating and implementing fiscal and social policy which would enable such women to stay at home if they so choose.

So there cannot and should not be a factional or political process of the Left or Right involved in this situation. There are plenty of people with barrows to push; I acknowledge that. They should identify which barrow they are pushing and what sort of impact they want to have on our society, whether it is beneficial or whether it is a narrow interest to suit their own particular preferences or their own preconceived ideas about what is best for our society. If it is one or the other, then surely it cannot be contemplated when governments consider the broad issues of family. These interests should be listened to, taken into account but not contemplated when looking at the broad issue of establishing effective family policies in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Financial Review of 28 July 1993 reported the release of a research paper by EPAC, the government's own research body. That paper indicates that single income families are in many cases under substantial financial pressure. This was a comparative study which looked across the board at those people in our society who are suffering and those who are not.

The net impact of the government's last budget and its previous policies has been to disadvantage single income families as compared with the rest of society. That ought to be rectified. If we add up the financial advantages of tax decisions and social policy decisions, such as child care and access, we find that the single income family has been the most seriously disadvantaged. The government has not chosen to rectify this situation. In fact, it is parading the decisions of today as a positive support for single income families. But the government has failed to acknowledge that the decisions of its last budget will leave families in Australia worse off.

Whilst those on incomes below $55,000 will receive an additional benefit of up to $30 a week, we can write off on average $5 of that in additional costs brought about by the increases in indirect taxes and fuel taxes. We can quantify those increases. The Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) cannot deny that low income families and those dependent on their own private transport to get to and from work are the ones that are being disadvantaged. Those families live mainly in the western suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne.

The Labor Party has set out almost consciously to hurt most of those people it claims to support. During the recent by-election in Werriwa, the Liberal candidate said that the Labor Party attitude to Macquarie Fields was a ghetto mentality. He was not saying that the people of Macquarie Fields were ghetto people. He was not making a reflection on individuals. The fact of the matter is that the results of the poll indicate very clearly that the people living in that area agreed with the statements of the Liberal Party candidate. They knew they had been rejected. They knew the Labor Party was prepared to rubbish them and grind them down. So if there was a swing in that electorate that demonstrated a recognition of the government's biased treatment of our community, it was right there in Macquarie Fields, the area that the Prime Minister took a spin through just to prove that he did not think they were ghetto people.

The Prime Minister never goes to the Macquarie Fields of Australia. He never goes to the welfare centres. He never goes to St Vincent De Paul, Matthew Talbot or any of those other centres. We would never find him in those places. We find him with the bankers, the foreign affairs experts and the financial wizards of this nation. He is never anywhere where there are real people.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a Vaucluse boy, isn't he?

—He took the money and lived in Canberra. He claimed Vaucluse and lived in Canberra. That is the style of living and the attitude of this government. We only have to apply a little bit of care to the analysis of the delivery of both the government's economic and social policies to see that it is a yuppie mentality that drives this government. It is a cell phone mentality, a Porsche mentality, a Mercedes mentality, a French clock mentality, an Italian suit mentality that drive this government. The government does not listen to its backbench. When the backbench has enough fortitude to raise issues, they are usually from the Left and the Left is rubbished along with everybody else who wants to rise an issue of conscience.

PARA.TAB: I am looking forward to a year of real debate. I do not believe that there will be fortitude, strength or numbers on the other side of the House to convince this government that it should have anything but a yuppie mentality towards Australian families. I am convinced that the government will not get into the real issues of Australian families but will listen to the glib, superficial Anne Summers' of this world. A lot of the time I like what she says but she does not identify with the real families of Australia and how they hurt and how they try to manage. Very few people in Canberra can.

I would like some government members to come down and talk to some of the Aboriginal families in Redfern. They do not go down there. They try to get a few activists down there to stir things up. They do not visit the families and see the hurt and pain they experience when trying to raise families in Redfern—or Macquarie Fields, for that matter. I will await the arrival of the new honourable member for Werriwa with a great deal of interest. He has proclaimed his social conscience and understanding of the Australian community across western Sydney. Despite what was said in the press, the vote in Werriwa was not an endorsement of the government or even an average return for a by-election.

I await with real interest to see whether he can change the ghetto mentality that, with every budget, the government is helping to create in Macquarie Fields. Unless he is prepared to do that, he will fall into the ranks of those other government members who proclaim this small measure as a breakthrough for families in Australia and an initiative that is worthy of continuing during the International Year of the Family. I do not believe that the government has the wit, the fortitude or the heart to refer to the love and affection that families generate about which the previous speaker, the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), spoke. The trouble is that that sentiment is not reflected in substance; this is about symbolism rather than substance.
Debate (on motion by Mr Swan) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (HOME CHILD CARE AND PARTNER ALLOWANCES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whatever we do in this House must be aimed at the long-term future of this nation and the long-term future of our children. Policies to secure that future are central to our policy making role. The home child-care allowance, which is central to this bill, is a very good initiative which will strengthen the array of government policies to protect and strengthen the family.

PARA.TAB: The home child-care allowance shows that this government is financially committed to those people who choose to do unpaid work in the home caring for children. In this International Year of the Family, it is a very important initiative which should receive far greater credit from the opposition than it has done so far in this debate. For example, the opposition has said that this measure is revenue neutral. This measure will result in the additional expenditure of $226 million in 1996-97. It reflects the government's continued commitment, through an array of policies, to support the family and the care of children, be it through a home child-care allowance which looks after those who seek, in an unpaid capacity, to care for children in the home, or whether it be through other child-care initiatives which are the subject of election commitments from last year. The maximum rate of this allowance will be $1,560 per annum or $60 per fortnight. This rate will be subject to an income test based on the income of the person receiving the allowance. This allowance is approximately $6 per fortnight higher than the current maximum rate for the dependent spouse rebate. As I said before, this measure is not revenue neutral; it involves substantial additional expenditure by the government to support Australian families, which is entirely appropriate in this International Year of the Family.

The problem with the existing dependent spouse rebate is that it is provided in recognition of the fact that the cost of supporting dependants reduces a person's capacity to pay tax in comparison with a person who does not have dependants. The clear advantage of the home child-care allowance is that it recognises the work of the carer and pays money directly to the carer. That is the significance of this measure. In that sense, it is a path-breaking reform which deserves some credit from the opposition. It goes to the heart of commitments that this government made in the 1993 federal election campaign. Through this initiative we have promised $6 per fortnight more than was promised in that campaign. In addition to that, low income families who receive no benefit from the dependent spouse rebate will be major beneficiaries—to the tune of 55,000 additional families. On top of that, as I said before, they will receive an extra $6 per fortnight over and above that which was promised during the campaign.

The home child-care allowance is a payment directly to full-time carers or even part-time carers of children, who are usually women. This stands in stark contrast to the absence of any policy from the opposition in the area of family support or in the area of child care. I know that some members of the coalition are fiddling with income splitting options which are generally, but not always, regressive.

The major advantage of this initiative, which I hope the government can build on over time, is that it will provide additional support to families on low and middle incomes in a way in which income splitting measures, such as those that have been put forward by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), cannot do. Clearly, full income splitting favours high income families, if it is done in an unrestrained way, to the detriment of low income families. Some of the options that have been canvassed but which are not opposition policy are clearly very regressive.

In the past month we have seen some statements from various opposition spokesmen in this area. For example, we had a statement from Senator Vanstone who recently told a Young Liberal conference that the sorts of policies that the Liberal Party needs can be compared to a bus. Senator Vanstone said that people were not interested in the seats or the brakes; they were only interested in the general direction in which the bus was going. The fact is that in policy terms, be it policy terms for child care or policy terms for the support of a family, the opposition is careering out of control without any brakes, seats or general direction. That is a sad thing in this International Year of the Family where we should be having a mature and informed debate about those policies which can best support the family, those policies which can best support the unpaid carers of children, and those policies which can best support the carers of children who may, through their own desire or through no desire of their own, have to go to work.

Support for families is about giving families genuine choice. The reason why the home child-care allowance is so central to support for strengthening the family is that it gives families a greater capacity to make a choice as to whether the carer of the children, be they male or female, decides to stop in the home in an unpaid capacity or decides to go into the work force. It is about providing choice. In that sense, it complements a range of policies that this government has put in place over many years to support the family.

I only have to mention this government's major initiatives in terms of family allowance payments and the family income supplement. On top of that, we now have the home child-care allowance and, for those who choose to work and have to buy their child care on the open market, we have the child-care rebate. These are very significant measures. Over a decade or so this government has put together a comprehensive array of policies to support the family and, in many ways, the home child-care allowance is probably one of the most significant because, for the first time, it provides assistance to the unpaid carer of children in the home who so desire to do that. The emphasis here, once again, is on choice and on freedom.

What does the opposition have to say about all of this? It has had very little to say, except for making some very down-beat assessments of the home child-care allowance in this House today and, in particular, claiming that it is revenue neutral, that is, it is some sort of meaningless initiative which will be of no benefit to unpaid carers of children. When this measure commences in September and the $60 a fortnight arrives in tens of thousands or up to a million Australian homes, it will be supported. The assessments that those opposite have given it will be looked on very dimly by the Australian people as a whole.

This tends to reflect the `Fightback' attitude that the opposition displayed throughout last year and in the years before that. It is best summed up by what the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) told us of what he thinks about helping people. He said, `If you bend down to help people they drag you down'. That is exactly the kind of laissez-faire approach to policy that is hostile to the family and hostile to the care of children. It must be resisted. It is resisted and this government is moving forward with further initiatives to support the family.

This initiative is something that full-time carers of children, who are mainly women, have wanted for some time. A recent survey conducted by the Australian Institute of Family Studies found that 40 per cent of women employed during pregnancy did not return to work after the birth of their child. Those families suffer. They have additional costs to clothe, feed and look after the children and, of course, they suffer a loss of income. The home child-care allowance recognises that. I for one would like to do better than the $60 a fortnight.

As we have this debate about how we best look after families in the future and whether or not we change the taxation system to move to some form of income splitting, we will have to have a debate about how we best provide funds on a targeted basis to low and middle income families so that they can best secure freedom of choice as to whether they want to look after their children in the home or whether they want to return to the work force. This initiative is about choice and as such it is very important. The Institute of Family Studies survey has not been recognised by those opposite who simply come into the House and make remarks in a stereotypical way which really do not go to the heart of the problem of how we support families. As I said before, family support has been central to this government's policies.

Over the past 10 years, families in the low income bracket have seen an increase in their real disposable income of quite substantial proportions. A single income family earning three-quarters of average weekly earnings has experienced an increase of 18.7 per cent in real disposable income. A similar family, where the sole wage earner is unemployed and is receiving jobsearch or newstart, will receive over 30 per cent more in real terms.

More recently, the government has recognised the situation of Australian families through its taxation policy and through tax cuts by bringing the marginal rate for families earning between $20,000 and $38,000 a year down from 38c to 34c in the dollar. That is a very substantial initiative to support Australian families in this community. But the attitude of the opposition to that measure was to oppose it as if somehow it was fair to tax people earning $26,000 a year 38c in the dollar on each marginal dollar of income when average weekly earnings in this country are around $30,000. If we put together the tax cuts, the family allowance, the family income supplement and the home child-care allowance and add to that the child-care rebates that are forthcoming, what we have is very substantial support for the Australian family. It is the sort of policy package which is having real benefits in our community, the sort of policy package which the opposition is simply not capable of putting together.

Looking after families, however, is not just a matter of money, it is a matter of attitude. It is also true that if we are going to have secure, healthy and caring families, we have to encourage fathers to play a wider role in homemaking, in child care and in child growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the dinner break I was talking about policies to protect the living standards of Australian families and how the home child-care allowance was the very initiative to do that. I was speaking about how our tax system, in particular the recent tax cuts, was designed to assist Australian families. I also spoke about how our social security system—the family allowance payments, the family income supplement, and the health care system, particularly through Medicare—contained very important initiatives to protect and assist the Australian family. The home child-care allowance is just one of the latest of a number of initiatives from this government to support the family.

PARA.TAB: I will give one example of what this government does for families. A two-child family with a combined income of $28,000 a year, privately renting, currently receives $64.96 per week from basic family payment, additional family payment and rent assistance. In addition to this, it would receive a further $30 per week from the home child-care allowance. This is the sort of initiative which recognises the importance of the family and particularly assists single income families.

When we are talking about the International Year of the Family and support for families, we should not just be talking about money; it is important that we recognise the changes in society. It is important, for example, that we encourage fathers to play wider roles in homemaking, child care and child growth and that women should be enabled to explore new opportunities for education and employment so that all the carers in the family can balance work, family responsibilities and the care of children. This is just one initiative which encourages the sort of opportunity and freedom of choice that I was speaking about earlier.

When we are talking about families, we should be talking not just about the full-time carers in the family but also about older folk in the community, such as grandparents, who also have an important nurturing role to play in the stability of families. In turn, we must put in place policies to assist older folk in the community. We have done that through programs such as the home and community care program. It is important that we debate support for the family not only in terms of living standards but also in terms of care and compassion in the community.

It is important in this International Year of the Family that we should not waste our time on sterile debates about what constitutes a family. There is far too much stereotyping in this debate. We should not be typecasting individuals into any role that they are uncomfortable with. Many women are happy to stay at home on a full-time basis. This is also increasingly the case for some men. We should not look down on those people who make the choice to stay home, just as we should not look down on those people who make the choice to go back to work.

What we have to ensure, in terms of government policies, particularly those which impact on the financial capacity of the family, is that people have that legitimate choice and that one part of the family is not necessarily forced into the work force even though he or she would prefer to remain at home, or forced to remain at home when he or she would prefer to go to work. This is why the array of child-care policies that the government is presenting in the International Year of the Family is so important. We have a balanced policy. We are recognising the importance of the carer who wishes to stay at home in an unpaid capacity. We are also recognising the importance of those who seek to go to work to meet their child-care needs.

There is also some debate about the type of taxation system that we require to support single income families. I said earlier that elements of the opposition favour full income splitting and that full income splitting can be very regressive. Our existing taxation system encourages non-earning spouses—who usually are married women—to enter the labour force rather than stay at home. That is a consequence of our progressive system of taxation, but it does not necessarily follow that making our taxation system regressive will solve this problem.

Under the sort of income splitting arrangements that the opposition is talking about, a family in which the income earner earns $100,000 a year and the partner earns no income would derive an enormous benefit from any form of income splitting that was given to it; whereas a family in which the principal breadwinner earns $28,000 a year and the spouse earns $5,000 a year would gain very little benefit from income splitting. That is why the home child-care allowance is the perfect alternative to the regressive form of income splitting that elements of the opposition are putting forward in this House.

What we have to do is target the assistance to the carer in a way which is fair to low and middle income earners. I am not talking just about those people who are earning a combined income of $20,000 or $25,000 a year; I am talking also about the great bulk of Australian families, with household incomes somewhere between $25,000 and $50,000 a year. The sorts of arrangements for income splitting that are being put forward by the opposition would disadvantage those types of families dramatically and advantage families which have a higher aggregate income, albeit from only one income earner.

What we are hearing from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and others about income splitting being a fair way to support single income earners is simply arrant nonsense. It is demonstrably very unfair. An alternative to that from this side of the House is the home child-care allowance, which at this stage is $60 a fortnight.

It would be my hope that over time in government we could further support the Australian family by adding to that allowance as an alternative to the inequitable arrangements for income splitting which are being supported by the opposition, which would simply deliver great benefits to people on very high incomes and negative benefits to the great bulk of Australian families with modest and low incomes.

I hope that in this House over the months ahead, right through the International Year of the Family, we can continue this debate and that a home child-care allowance can be viewed, in a sense, as a mechanism for limited income splitting, largely addressing the regressive nature of full income splitting, which is being put forward by the opposition. The 1994 International Year of the Family should be a year in which we reflect upon issues relating to the family other than just financial issues. A great deal has been said about the importance of the family and the need to promote policies which incorporate core family values.

I conclude on the point that we should accept the differing family arrangements that exist in the 1990s. What was normal when we were growing up is not necessarily normal or relevant now. Changes come from the growth of society—changes in the work force and the explosion of the media, as well as an increasing awareness of choice and civil and political rights. Change is inevitable. However, some basics do not change. The notion of the family, however it is constructed, and in particular the traditional family, should remain fundamentally important to our community and our future.

As I said earlier, we should not look down on those parents who choose to work. Equally, we should not look down on those parents who genuinely choose to stay at home. They are all very important parts of the Australian family. I believe that this bill reaffirms the government's commitment to the family. I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca), when introducing the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill, and many honourable members who have spoken to it, have referred to the timeliness of these proposals, coming as they do at the beginning of the International Year of the Family. I hope that this is not the end of initiatives and proposals that come to grips with the vital issues confronting Australia's families.

PARA.TAB: I concur wholeheartedly with much of what was said by the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan). I think we all warmly welcome the many pious statements we hear in support of the family. I do not very often agree with the sentiments and comments of the Queensland Premier, Mr Goss, but I have to say that some of the things he was quoted as saying in front-page newspaper columns in Queensland over recent weeks are thoroughly commendable and represent the kind of attitude that may indeed come to grips with the important future role of families in his state and, indeed, the rest of Australia.

Unfortunately, the policies of Mr Goss's government have not always supported the rhetoric. In a sense, the same can be said for some things that the honourable member for Swan has just said. The government's rhetoric usually is not supported by too much evidence of positive actions in support of Australian families.

As has been said, this is the Year of the Family. It is interesting to note that in 1984 Queensland had a Year of the Family. It has taken the United Nations 10 years to catch up to Queensland. I think that Year of the Family was a very successful event for the state. It had a high profile, local committee led by former Senator Bjelke-Petersen, which was able to mobilise an enormous amount of community goodwill and set up organisations right across the state to help promote activities and issues which were of importance to Queensland families. I hope that a similar spirit can be captured one decade on in Australia as well—in the nation as a whole—as we celebrate our national Year of the Family.

Unfortunately, there have been so many international years over recent times that it has become difficult to engender any kind of enthusiasm for new proposals. People think it is yet another year and ask what the year is dedicated to this time. I think there has been an element of that in the federal government's response so far to the Year of the Family. It really has been disappointedly half-hearted.

The national council for the Year of the Family has only a very small budget and did not even meet for the first time until last September. No effort has been made to promote the establishment of local community committees or to promote a program of activities for the year. In fact, I cannot recall getting anything in my office from the Year of the Family committee at all, yet we are one month into the year. At the launching speech of the council by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in December, I was concerned also by the government seeking to use the International Year of the Family to further its politically correct agenda by including any and every combination of living arrangement in its definition of families.

It is interesting to note that 86 per cent of Australian families are couple families and 82 per cent of children are growing up in couple families. So it is still the norm in our country to have two parents and children make up a family. Of course, children living with sole parents are also families and often need special care and attention. Indeed, special programs often are going to be necessary to make up for the gap of not having two loving parents. Often one loving parent is better than two feuding parents, so those circumstances need to be recognised and accepted as we develop attitudes towards Australian families.

This Year of the Family gives us a wonderful opportunity to focus government and community attention on the essential role of strong and happy families in building a healthy society and a successful nation. I think it is essential that not only should we have a national committee but also we should organise events at the local level so there can be genuine input from every local group into fostering the needs of families and interests in family issues.

I thought the economics editor of the Melbourne Age made some very telling comments on 4 January—an economics editor, not one who may be regarded as having special links with the family. Tim Colebatch said:

Everyone respects the family. Everyone professes concern for it. And yet when we look at how families are treated by government policies, one can only marvel at how much is out of skew, in how many areas our policy structures are at war with our professed ideals:

The economic cost of family breakdown is the least important part of it, yet the Marriage Guidance Council estimates it at $2.5 billion a year. And the Government spends only $20 million a year on marriage guidance to prevent it. That is poor social policy and lousy economics.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, that is the case. When there is a breakdown in a family, the financial cost is only the smallest part of it. The real cost lies in the tragedy of human lives, the bitterness associated with the breakdown, the often intense hatred that develops between formerly loving partners and, sadly, the children who are caught in the middle—innocent victims of an unhappy relationship.

PARA.TAB: So often our government and our communities spend their time picking up the pieces, mending the broken bottles when it would have been so much better to spend time making sure that the relationship did not break down in the first place, doing what we can to support the family unit, boosting our assistance and programs that support the family, helping people with marriage guidance counselling and then parenting plans, doing much more to support and keep families together so we then do not have to face the problem of picking up the pieces of a broken relationship—a dysfunctional family.

This home child-care allowance is a positive initiative, and it helps to recognise and place some financial and community values on the services provided by parents who choose to raise their children in their own home. It is in a sense, though, only a half-hearted initiative. It will offer to the parent who chooses to raise a child in his or her own home $30 a week while the government will still offer $60 a week to parents if they farm their children out to a child-care centre. So a degree of inconsistency exists there. But certainly I think the idea of paying the allowance in a cheque in the mail provides positive signals to the community that are not as evident in a tax deductible spouse rebate.

The government is making out that it is spending $1.1 billion on this new initiative and quietly not recognising the $900 million that it will save by abolishing the dependent spouse rebate for parents with children. But certainly this program will better target in many ways the money provided to support parents, although there will obviously be greater administration costs. The current DSR is very simple to administer. This rebate will require considerably more work. It will, though, enable the benefit to be paid to one group of people in particular who miss out on the dependent spouse rebate at the present time—those low income earners who do not earn sufficient in order to get the full rebate. The government could have done that in another way; it could have provided the rebate as a tax credit. That would have had the same kind of effect, probably with a less administrative cost. But certainly I think there is a strong case to be mounted to ensure that those families that do not have a taxable income are able to share in the benefits that are available.

It is important that we support parents who raise children in their homes. I think that over recent times both the government and the opposition have been bending over backwards to outbid one another in the number of child-care places each was going to provide around Australia. There are a lot of available child-care places in Australian homes. We have not exercised that wonderful opportunity. Instead, a boom industry has developed which is building new child-care centres around the countryside. There seems to be almost one child-care centre in every suburb at the present time.

Child-care centres will always have a role. I support the view that families ought to be in a position where they are able to make a choice between raising their children in their own home and taking advantage of a child-care facility. Indeed, I think we should look very seriously at a policy which is utterly even-handed in this regard. We should pay to parents a child-care allowance substantially more than the $30 a week which is proposed in this particular measure. Parents should then decide of their own free will whether they choose to use that payment to fund a place in a child-care centre or, alternatively, to help one of the parents raise the children in his or her own home. I think that has both enormous economic and, particularly, social advantages. It will recognise the real value to our society and to our community of the task of raising children.

I heard a rather interesting analysis recently about how we provide taxation benefits, as a government and as a country, to industries to expand and to develop their production. But we provide little or no national assistance to the basic future productive unit in our society—our own children.

I think there are tremendous advantages in providing a system which enables parents to make the choice and rewards them equally or even more generously for taking the decision to raise their own children in their own household as a part of their responsibilities to their community and the country as a whole. I can recall being taught in school as a child that one of the evils of the communist system was the way in which particularly the dictatorships and the totalitarian societies would break up the families, take the children away and raise them in government run child-care centres. That was pointed out as being evil. I sometimes look at what we are doing in Australia at present with a degree of amusement, wondering whether we are heading in that direction ourselves, particularly when I see governments setting up national child-care accreditation systems where child-care centres will have to meet guidelines before fee relief is available.

Those government guidelines include a liberal dose of Labor's social engineering philosophies. In other words, if the boys end up playing with trucks and the girls do not get their fair share, the money stops. That is the sort of social engineering that we condemned in the worst days of the communist system. Let us make sure that we do not head in that direction in our country as well.

In speaking about payments to families, this government started the International Year of the Family in an extraordinary way when, as its virtual first act, it decided to cut family allowances to hundreds of thousands of Australian families—a most bizarre beginning to the year. It allowed for lower payments from 6 January to a whole range of families. I am told that around 116,000 families will lose family payments altogether. Lower income tests and assets test limits apply now to all basic family payments and fringe benefits received will be counted as income for all recipients of basic and additional family payments. This is the first time that fringe benefits have been counted in this way and it is affecting many low income families. Indeed, it is the low income families that will suffer the most as a result of this range of measures which took effect on 6 January.

The lower family payments along with the increased subsidies for child care are again likely to force many families to seek a second income, even though Australia still has a million unemployed. Instead of supporting Australian families in this International Year of the Family, the federal government reduced their incomes and started the year off by making their lives a lot harder.

I am sorry that the parliamentary secretary is not in the chamber at present because I have been exchanging correspondence with him on this matter for some time. There is a problem developing for many families, particularly those on farms and in owner-operated businesses who have widely fluctuating incomes but are required to provide income details before their financial year returns have been completed. I have been approached by accountants and others in my electorate highlighting the special problems that occurred particularly around Christmas last year. I have contacted the minister to try to draw this matter to his attention.

The facts are that low income taxpayers are not required to lodge their tax returns until around 15 May. Naturally, accountants need to manage their workload throughout the year. The tax office wants higher taxpayers to put their returns in first so that they can collect from the bigger payers first. That is not unreasonable. The effect then is that the low taxpayers, the poorest people in our society, are the last to lodge their tax returns. That means that they are the last to have their financial statements prepared by the accountants. These are the people who are most likely to qualify for basic family payments and family supplements.

On 1 January their financial statements had not been prepared. The accountants are concentrating on people with bigger returns. So they have a difficulty. If they cannot produce estimates of income by that date, they cease to be eligible for family payments. So many poor people, particularly those in small business and in the hard-pressed rural sector, just simply do not bother to apply because it is so hard to get the figures.

The parliamentary secretary, in replying to me, pointed out that farmers or anyone who is providing estimates on lower income can be 25 per cent out before an overpayment is raised. I acknowledge that, but 25 per cent is not a large variation, particularly when we take into account the fact that some of the farmers in my own area are being required to estimate the earnings from crops that they have not even planted yet. They are expected to be within 25 per cent range of accuracy on their income returns for the end of the year.

So there is certainly a difficulty here. I know that the current arrangements suit the majority of taxpayers and the majority of applicants, but there is a particular difficulty for those with fluctuating incomes, those who need to estimate an income in order to apply for family allowances and also, I might add, for health cards. They are unable to get that kind of financial information. That really does affect the income of their families. These are clearly the people at the bottom end of the income scale, those who are most in need of assistance.

Another interesting part of this particular legislation is the introduction of partner allowances, the way jobsearch and newstart and the like are split to make part of that payment available to the partner. That again will create an additional administrative load, but the idea obviously again has some merit in many cases.

While talking about partner allowances, I note that this particular measure has not been extended to the age pension where there is obviously an anomaly when it comes to partner allowances. If a 60-year-old lady qualifies for the age pension, she gets half of the age pension while her 63-year-old husband is unable to get a pension of any kind. That family is then left with only half of the age pension. If the situation is reversed in that it is a 65-year-old male who qualifies for the age pension, no matter what age his wife is—she could be only 23—she still qualifies for the partner's pension. There is a bit of sex discrimination here of the reverse kind, I guess.

I know that the government has announced that via a very slow process it is going to move to harmonise the pension eligibility age for men and women so that eventually, by about the year 2030 or whatever, this problem will go away. But I wonder whether we might be able to look at it a little earlier and look at these particular cases. Partners may be the same age; there does not need to be any disparity in their ages. If the wife is eligible for the pension at 62, her 62-year-old husband gets nothing. If they are both, say, 65 and the man is eligible, then the wife is eligible for the partner's pension. If the government is accepting the principle that there should be payments to partners, it ought to follow that through also to the age pension system and eliminate this anomaly currently in our system.

I think all of these issues are important for us to address, particularly in the International Year of the Family. I think the best thing we can do in our country to reduce strife, discord and trouble is encourage and strengthen the family unit. People in families help one another. Family members rejoice with other family members when they are celebrating and they share troubles. That provides vital and essential support, support which would otherwise be provided by welfare institutions and facilities of the state. We therefore have not only a social but also an economic interest in supporting Australia's families, giving them every opportunity to be strong and financially secure.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure this evening to support the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill. I thought I was going to have the double pleasure of congratulating the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) on a positive contribution to the debate this evening, but, unfortunately, just like his colleagues, he wandered off and could not help being not just critical, but also critical with half-truths. He was not telling the full truth when he told us how the government cut family allowances at the beginning of the year. He did not enunciate how it was cut so that people earning over $60,000 a year with no dependent children were removed from the dependent allowances scheme. Certainly he did not tell us that his own party, if it had been elected last year, was going to drop that limit to $55,000.
—Oh, Warren, you didn't tell us that.

—Of course he did. These are the half-truths. The refreshing thing about the honourable member for Wide Bay is that he admitted his support for this legislation. We have heard waffle about the pea and thimble trick and our taking it from one and giving it to another. However, the opposition has denied the fact that the government will outlay an extra quarter of a billion dollars in 1995-96.

PARA.TAB: We have all heard about the Anglo-Saxon Christian family unit. It has been stressed by those opposite. They have said, `Don't give money to the de factos. The children of those relationships have to be second-rate citizens'. We even heard one suggestion that child-care places for people on dual benefits virtually verges on the immoral and that to suggest that children from those families should be supported in going to preschools by this government is taboo.

The honourable member for Wide Bay got stuck into child-care centres and how they were being forced to gain qualification by having a certain minimum standard. Is he suggesting that we return to the backyard days of the 1960s where people could not get satisfactory child care? That is the sort of thing that flourished under the coalition government in those days.

Because this government is making a positive move during the International Year of the Family and is bringing in initiatives to ensure a basic standard, the opposition has taken the opportunity to criticise. I assure the honourable member for Wide Bay that this is not a sole initiative. If he looks at the initiatives that have been brought in by this government, he will see that, apart from the home child-care and partner allowances, tax cuts for low wage earners came in just before Christmas; Medicare services were expanded, which those opposite will not use and which they will cut out if they ever have the opportunity of getting back onto the government benches; a fee rebate for child care was introduced; and child-care services were expanded.

Every one of those initiatives relates to the family and identifies this government's support for family units throughout Australia. I was particularly thankful that the honourable member identified that this initiative enunciates our care for those lower wage earners and that we are expanding child-care services for them.

This legislation will give greater assistance to the most needy Australian families. It is fitting that it should be introduced in the International Year of the Family. In one way, the government's policy assists parents in the anxieties and pressures resulting from working and caring for a family at the same time. It also reflects changing attitudes to child raising and paying proper recognition to the role of nurturing the future generations of this country.

The government recognises that women are becoming more and more integrated into Australia's economic life. Their skills are essential to maintaining a competitive advantage. The work force needs the participation of women. So why would we seek to introduce legislation that would encourage them to stay out of the work force?

This piece of legislation is about the big picture. The home child-care allowance and partner allowances are not knee-jerk reactions or a cynical vote catching idea; they are just one part of a total child-care policy, just as the fee rebate for occasional child care is one part of it and the expansion of child-care places is another.

These allowances are also part of the agenda of job creation. Many women in the work force are paid low wages. Many of them prefer to be at home caring for their children or only in part-time work. The home child-care allowance, which encourages child care by parents, is part of a policy of job sharing with favourable tax treatment, making it easier to have one parent at home.

Most importantly, though, this legislation brings the role of parents to the forefront in government policy. It provides incentives for mothers or fathers who want to stay at home while their children are young. It is their right of choice, and the government is honouring its election promises to give them this choice.

The home child-care allowance also breaks new ground because it elevates the role of the child carer and gives it proper recognition. It recognises that while that carer—usually the mother—is at home she is entitled to acknowledgment and respect. The mother has traditionally been classified as a dependant and a tax deduction. How degrading!

The opposition spokesperson on family affairs—a female—has criticised the home child-care allowance as being a transfer from the father's wallet to the mother's purse. That is exactly what it is and what it should be. Mothers do not want to be dependent on handouts. They do not want the indignity of having to wait for the annual tax return, which is not even paid to them personally for the work that they have done during the year. Often it is only a paper entry to pay an accumulation of bills. That is why the government is abolishing the dependent spouse rebate.

The home child-care allowance will not be just a once a year rebate. It will be paid directly to the primary carer. It will not depend on her partner's income and it will not be subject to an assets test. It is an independent source of income. The carer will receive it in her own right each fortnight to assist her in meeting the day-to-day expenses of raising her family. For 55,000 families whose incomes are now too low to get the full dependent spouse rebate, it will be a direct cash bonus of $60 per fortnight.

The home child-care allowance is also about flexibility. It gives parents the option of entering or leaving the work force at any time during the year as their circumstances change. The pattern of Australian women's lives has changed. They spend time in the work force and some periods at home. Many will spend time doing both.

Let us look at some typical scenarios. A mother may be offered part-time work at the local shop and feel that she has a suitable child carer to do her job at home. However, after a few months this may not work out. One of the children may develop a medical condition or the baby-sitting arrangements may change and she wants to be at home full time. That option is now available to her without penalty. She can take part-time work for a few weeks or months, but while she is out of the paid work force caring for her children she can claim the allowance.

She can also do a mix and match, mixing paid employment with child raising and matching both to her family's needs. The allowance reduces at the rate of 25c for each dollar of income over $10.85 per fortnight that is earned. So she can earn $250.85 per fortnight before she loses the whole allowance. I believe that that is a major contribution to the family way of life.

There is the typical case of the woman who has been working full time, becomes pregnant, has her baby and wishes to leave the work force while her family is young. Her current income would drop to zero. However, under this legislation, she will be eligible straightaway for a fortnightly payment of $60. The strength of this reform is that it responds immediately to a family's changed financial situation.

Approximately 840,000 families are expected to receive this new allowance at any one time. An extra 20,000 families will receive it for part of the year. The partner allowance is designed to address inequalities arising from the abolition of the dependent spouse rebate for couples who have dependent children and who receive jobsearch, newstart, sickness allowances or special benefits. The dependent partner will be able to receive this payment directly and, as is only fair, the combined amount of allowance received by these couples will not be affected.

These are measures that assist all Australian families. They address issues of social equity and the long-term vision for this nation. I have a great deal of pleasure in supporting them. It is symbolic that the opposition does not oppose this legislation. I know that, just like us, deep down the opposition knows it is right for Australia too. That is why it gives us on this side of the House a great deal of pleasure in making sure that this International Year of the Family will be a symbolic year; it will be year of progress; it will be a year in which the Australian government makes sure that the family way of life becomes the Australian way of life.

I know that many speakers on both sides of the House wish to contribute. I hope that, like honourable members on this side, members of the opposition take the opportunity to contribute positively, because this is truly a landmark in the way that this government is looking at Australian families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Deahm Ms M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne) has said, a number of members have spoken already in this debate and a number are still to come. We will probably hear a lot of the same things over again and I apologise if I repeat some of the things that have already been said. In fact, the honourable member for Paterson has already stolen a bit of my thunder; nevertheless, I will put it my way.

PARA.TAB: It is very important that this legislation is being enacted in the International Year of the Family. This government has acknowledged that the family is the core of Australian society and we have had a lot of debate about what the family is. I am a single person. I live alone. I have been part of a family; I still am part of a family. Regardless of whether a family comprises a single parent, a person alone, a grandparent with a grandchild or even homosexuals—my God, we cannot even mention that word—it is a group of people who love each other, who maybe live together and who support each other. This piece of legislation is very important in supporting the family.

Before dealing with the legislation, I would like to put it in a historical context and describe some of the changes in the role of parenting over the years. When I left school and went to work in the 1950s, women that I worked with—I suppose one could call them girls at that age—often left work to get married. We know of women who leave work to have babies and sometimes they come back. In those days, women left work to get married. If they did not, it meant that their husbands were not capable of providing for or looking after them. At that stage my sister worked for the ABC. She was forced to leave work when she got married. That is a great contrast to the kind of situation we have today.

Later, in the 1960s and 1970s, we saw a great increase in the number of women in the work force. In some cases, this was of economic necessity and still is. But, in most cases, women wanted to work; they wanted a career; they wanted to be acknowledged in their own right as being something additional to a wife and a mother. They wanted that credibility.
