With that, eventually, came maternity leave and now paternity leave, which acknowledges the important role that men play in the family. Sometimes we can focus too much on one side of parenting. This is an acknowledgment by government departments and various employers that having a family is an important part of life; it disrupts the work flow, but it needs to be acknowledged and handled.

More women in the work force inevitably led to an increase in child-care centres and child-care places. Earlier this evening the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), while spending a lot of time saying, `Don't get me wrong; I don't want you to take this the wrong way, but', made a comment that there seemed to be a child-care centre on every corner. In the olden days we used to say that there was a pub on every corner. I used to think there was a bank on every corner, but they seem to be changing into McDonalds these days.

There has been an increase in the number of child-care centres and child-care places. In last year's budget, the government made further moves to assist in increasing the number of those child-care places. This move was made towards the target of meeting demand for work related child-care places by the year 2001. The Commonwealth has entered into direct partnerships with local government and community groups to provide 500 centre based community child-care places, and some of those have been in my electorate. In addition, 700 out of school hours care places and 4,000 family day care places are also being provided, and they will contribute to an expected overall increase in 1993-94 of 29,000 places, and that is extremely important. The before and after school care places are equally important to the child-care places for the younger children. When parents are both working, they do not get home from work at the same time as the children leave school and those places are very important.

Some things have been said about the need for caring for children. It was said that children who do not have parental care when they are younger develop a number of problems. I certainly agree with that. The honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) in her speech hit on that very aptly when she said that what children need when they are young is love and care. That is not to say that they have to be with the parent all day. Love is something that is there, whether it is there at midday or after school, and children know that.

I, like most members I suppose, attend a number of child-care institutions. To see children from a very young age up to school age being so self-assured and socialised is extremely important. It may sound very old hat and very reminiscent, particularly at my age, but I can remember my first day at school. I can remember my sister's first day at school; she was two years older than I was. When I saw the terror she went through, I lived through two years of terror until it happened to me. I was one of those children who in those days stayed at home with mum, which we always did. I lived such a sheltered and cosseted life that I was terrified of anything outside.

The kids who now go to child-care centres are totally socialised. When they go to school, it is a new adventure. They look forward to going to the big school. Those who denigrate child-care centres ought to go and look at those places, talk to the people who work in them, talk to the kids and talk to the mothers. I guarantee that they will find that very few of the children are deprived and if they are deprived children, it is not the child-care centres that are causing it.

The other thing that this government has done in the budget in support of child care is introduce the child-care cash rebate. This rebate, free of income test and providing up to $28.20 a week for one child and $61.20 per week for two or more children, will be introduced from 1 July this year. It will be for all work related child-care expenses for children up to 12 years where both parents or the sole parent are working, in training or looking for work. This is a great step forward. This initiative is expected to benefit 230,000 families and 358,000 children, and that is an awful lot of kids. Of course, we have long had the fee relief for child-care centres.

Another thing that needs to be acknowledged in this progress of the family, is that more men are choosing to be the child carers. It is very interesting that we accept stereotypes, and to a great extent mothers generally are the primary carers. I have seen a number of families where it has been agreed that the mother has the more demanding career and the father is more inclined to look after the children. That is fine. It is a great step forward to see men pushing prams and walking children. When I was young we certainly did not see that. My father would never have done it. That, again, is a great step forward in the progress of the family.

We also need to look at that role of the wider family. We know of many cases where both parents are working or maybe, sadly, parents have been killed in an accident and grandparents take on that parenting role and do it extremely well. I am sure we are all aware of the furore caused by the Acting Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Anderson) and his comment about children needing fathers. Obviously, it is ideal for families to have two parents, but two parents fighting constantly are definitely detrimental to children and far less superior to living with one loving and caring parent. I heard a few radio phone-ins after those comments, particularly from people who have been brought up in single parent families themselves. They told of the professional careers that they were now involved in and happy with and the balanced lives that they had. So I think we need to be very careful about making judgments and calling it politically correct to say the sorts of things that I am saying now.

What we are doing in this legislation is getting the balance right. We are saying that women, or men for that matter, should not feel guilty if they go to work when they have young children. By the same token, they should not feel guilty about wanting to stay at home and be caring parents and not yet pursue their career.

Along with the child-care cash rebate, this is the other side of the coin. It allows those people to stay at home and receive those funds. The way this will work—and I am sure this has been said a million times tonight—is that the child-care allowance will be paid directly to the carer, the person who is staying home with the children. It replaces the dependent spouse rebate. That again is a rather pejorative sort of phrase. I am sure a lot has been said tonight, too, about that word `dependent'. I remember when I filled in my first tax return, my form S, the claim for wife or `daughter-housekeeper'. It was a phrase that always fascinated me. I could not work out what a `daughter-housekeeper' was. I then realised it was when there was no mum around and a daughter was looking after the poor man who could not look after himself.

This allowance will not be paid to the main income earner; it will be paid to the carer. The dependent spouse rebate will now be called the parent allowance. It will still go to those families where there are no dependent children. So the scaremongering about getting rid of the spouse rebate and only giving it to people who have kids at home is also a furphy.

The child home care allowance both extends the benefit to those families who do not earn sufficient income to benefit from the dependent spouse rebate and places the cash directly in the hands of the person who is doing the work of caring for the children. This makes changes of policy significance in three main areas. First of all, the payment is not linked to gender or family formation. The payment is made to the person who actually cares for the child, whether male or female, parent or step parent, married or de facto. This means that the government is withdrawing from telling families how to arrange their lives. Families are free to make whatever arrangements suit them best. The government will support them in their child rearing work without judging or rewarding one way rather than another.

Secondly, the payment recognises that caring is real work. The honourable member for Paterson alluded to that earlier. For many years people who cared for an elderly or disabled relative or for children laboured under many of the isolating and self-esteem reducing assumptions that theirs was not a real job. To be just a housewife—and how many times have we heard that?—appeared to suggest that work was not involved. In fact, caring work is a substantial and real contribution to both our social and economic life. Even the hardest economic rationalists have to admit that, without nurturing work, nobody would live long enough to purchase products or to join the paid work force.

Thirdly, the payment is individually paid and means tested. In many families, the partners happily share their financial resources and it probably would not matter who received the payment or whose income was tested. But some families require special protection and care because of a partner being afflicted in their capacity for financial responsibility, for example, by addiction to drugs or alcohol, gambling or simply poor budgeting skills. For these people the separate payment to the carer represents a significant form of support which both increases the carer's financial bargaining power within the household and provides a safety net for financial crisis.

Means testing only the carer and not the household as a unit is a step towards recognising the importance of the individual's contribution to the participation in the community. Professor Bettina Cass, of the department of social work and social policy—I have `of the university' here; I am not sure which university—speaking at a recent social security policy: the future conference in Canberra, commented on the way in which the home child-care allowance is a part of a process of adapting the social security system to meet changing expectations and labour force participation patterns in Australia in the 1990s. In particular, she noted with approval the recognition of the social and economic value of caring work. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . based on the individual as the unit of assessment, would be built on the clear societal understanding that these recognised forms of social participation and contribution to the economic and social welfare of the community will provide eligibility for income support, provide it equitably and provide it so as to enhance dignity and support participation.
I am very pleased to support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quick Mr H.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like previous speakers, I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate on the Social Security (Home Child-care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. With 14 speakers listed, it shows the importance that many of us place on this bill. As previous speakers have stated, it is quite appropriate that we are debating this bill in 1994, the International Year of the Family. The home child-care allowance is a major initiative, one of the many in last year's budget, which delivers the government's election promises to the families and, more especially, to the women of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Policies for women are integral to the federal government's economic and social strategies. The government's 1993 election commitments recognised women's work and skills as essential to future growth in the Australian economy improvements, to improvements in living standards and to a fair share of the benefits of economic growth. It also acknowledged the important role the government plays in supporting women's choices about their lives. For the first time, the contribution of women caring for children at home was given the importance it deserves.

It is rather ironic and, I think, typical of the current opposition, having listened to some of the speakers prior to dinner, that when it comes to so many reforms or almost anything resembling progressive change, we have trotted out the shrieks of alarm and the cliches which cast aspersions on what we are about to do. I was somewhat amazed to listen to the comments of several of the opposition speakers, especially the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock). During his speech on the bill he trotted out emotive cliches. He mentioned `the old-fashioned pea and thimble trick'. He said that the government is `ripping back the benefits from taxpayers', and that this is `a sneaky way' to get things done.

The honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) took up the challenge and outdid the honourable member for Berowra. We heard a word which I have never heard before, but which I suppose will go down in the annals now it is in Hansard—`feminazis', who have `taken over' and `thrown out the family culture'. Senator Crowley is the `minister for family disservices'. He said, `This is all about social engineering' and `The government is anti-family'. One wonders why the opposition did not trot out the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter). I would love to hear his views on this bill.

Before I go on to talk about some of the aspects of this bill I think it is vital that I correct some of the false impressions that are being promoted in the media. The honourable member for McPherson alluded to the government's so-called `social engineering'. One remembers the totally false and destructive campaign that the opposition and many of its followers undertook regarding the new guidelines for child-care centres just before Christmas, informing parents that children were no longer allowed to sing carols, that boys were not going to be allowed to play with trucks and girls not allowed to play with dolls—outrageous, mischievous and totally false claims that had parents worrying needlessly.

Then there was the hysterical campaign that started up concerning child-care accreditation. It was interesting to read today in my local newspaper, the Mercury, of claims by the leader of the National Party in the Senate, Senator Boswell, that the accreditation scheme will add up to $69 per week to the cost of caring for a single child—once again, scaremongering. It was interesting to note that this was supported by the executive member of the Association of Child Care Centres of New South Wales, Marion Parker, who claims that the regulations would be `far in excess' of the government's estimated 88c a day.

Staff in my office today have been in contact with representatives of the child-care industry in my electorate about the new accreditation scheme. It appears that the major complaint that child-care centres have about the new accreditation scheme is that, just as they had to do prior to Christmas, their workers once again must spend their valuable time assuring parents that the accreditation scheme is a very positive reform. The accreditation scheme is welcomed. It is interesting to note that in today's Examiner—I do not know what we do in Tasmania but we certainly do it better than anywhere else in Australia—it is reported that in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland fees will rise by between $18 and $69 a week.

But Launceston child-care centres have moved to allay fears that such a rise could occur in Tasmania. The Director of the Bungawitta Child Care Centre said that the accreditation scheme was terrific and well overdue. She said:
The only way it can put costs up is if quality care is not being provided . . .
It will only force up costs for those centres that are cutting corners and they have no right to do that when they are looking after children.
No-one should be providing sub-standard care . . .

SPEECH.PARA: The Director of the Dame Marjorie Parker Creche, which is also in Launceston, said that the accreditation scheme was a positive step which provided security for parents. She said, `We have been fighting for it for some time'. The Director of the Pedder Patter Child Care Centre said the accreditation scheme was the best thing to happen to child care. She said:

PARA.TAB: It should be seen as a positive step for families to know their children will be cared for in a quality environment . . .

SPEECH.PARA: She said that only those centres with substandard services would face additional costs as a result of the scheme.This accreditation scheme does provide the opportunity for industry to set standards to include parents in that process and to continue to develop the industry's very professional image. I suggest that the privately owned child-care centres have been aggressively lobbying those on the other side of the House and that there has been a massive knee-jerk reaction to that lobbying.

PARA.TAB: I ask honourable members on the other side to reflect on those unfounded remarks about child-care centres which were made before Christmas and mentioned here again tonight and also the current comments about the accreditation scheme and the hoary chestnuts that were raised by the opposition members in the debate. Those comments have caused needless concern for parents and have created unnecessary stress and worry for child-care workers and the rest of our community. Honourable members opposite go on about the fact that they care for the family. If there are genuine concerns from honourable members on the other side about this bill, let us debate it properly rather than use the emotive language which I previously mentioned was used by those on the other side.

This bill has by its very name two distinct parts, yet they are linked by a common social justice thread—that of enabling families and especially the care givers to provide their families with additional resources in order to improve their quality of life. Most honourable members have mentioned the fact that 840,000 families across the length and breadth of Australia are expected to receive this home child-care allowance at any one time. As I have already stated, it directly recognises the contribution made by carers of children, who are usually the mothers.

The maximum rate of the allowance will be $1,560 per annum, which translates more understandably to people in my electorate to $60 a fortnight. The rate will be subject to an income test based on the income of the person receiving the allowance. As several honourable members have mentioned, the rate of the allowance will be reduced at the rate of 25c for every dollar over and above $282 per annum, and will phase out when income exceeds $250.85 per fortnight. So, as previous speakers have mentioned, it does allow the care giver to seek additional work, which will perhaps provide them with the opportunity to enter part-time or full-time work once their children are past the age of being cared for at home and enter the school system. It is also important to note that any income of the person's partner will not be taken into account and the allowance will not be subject to an assets test.

It is pleasing to note that the home child-care allowance will be paid until the end of the calendar year in which a dependent child, generally the youngest, turns 18 or until the child ceases secondary schooling—whichever happens first. This generosity stands in stark contrast to the opposition's Fightback proposals which it hawked around the country less than 12 months ago and which suggested that the opposition was going to eliminate family payments once the child reached the age of 12. This allowance, as previous speakers have also mentioned, will allow approximately 55,000 families whose tax liabilities were previously too low to get the full value of the existing dependent spouse rebate to now receive greater assistance.

Both the home child-care allowance and the partner allowance build on previous government reforms to pay family payments directly to the carers of children. In contrast, the coalition is exploring income splitting options which would, I think, be regressive—providing most benefit, as is usual, to high income families—and would not provide a direct cash payment to the carer of children.

I would now like to briefly speak on the partner allowance, to which somewhat radical changes are being made. As a former electorate officer, I think that some people will be wandering into our offices seeking clarification about what is happening with the partner allowance. The additional amount of allowance for a dependent partner previously paid to recipients of jobsearch, newstart and sickness allowances will now be paid directly to the dependent partner as a partner allowance.

It is my fervent hope that, prior to September when this measure is introduced, the minister will ensure that there is widespread advertising about the need for partners to lodge a separate claim for partner allowance. Also, because jobstart, newstart and sickness allowance beneficiaries and their spouses usually hold joint bank accounts, partners may wish to open a new account to receive their partner allowance. Reminders should also be given about the requirements banks have regarding identification and the hassles that this might cause people receiving this new allowance.

The initiatives generated by this bill are properly focused towards the many Australian families who need them. I am therefore proud to be associated with the bill and I commend it most sincerely to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knott Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise to support the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowance) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. If my speech is not as organised as it should be, that could be a reflection of the fact that I have just learned of the death of Matt Gure, a friend of mine from my part of the world. I would like to take this opportunity to thank him for his contribution to society and for the commitment that he showed over many years in his job as a public servant.

PARA.TAB: Child care is a family issue, and is therefore a Labor Party issue. At the last election I was happy to stand on the Labor Party's record against the coalition's basket of woe. For the benefit of those coalition members who are here, I draw their attention to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 6 September 1992, describing the proposed tax system outlined by the coalition before the last federal election. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A tax system which fails to recognise the obligations of marriage and the family must be described as a system of de facto fiscal discrimination against families.

That is where the opposition is coming from, so it should not be criticising the Labor Party for what it has done. Further, the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission had this to say about the Liberal Party's basket of woes:
From the point of view of its effect on the poor and families—the person and the meaning of family life—one must question the moral legitimacy of the GST.

In other words, the Catholic Social Welfare Commission questioned the opposition's moral legitimacy. Yet opposition members still come in here and talk about standing up for family values. They feign concern for the poor and for families, but when they left office only 46,000 child-care places existed—and, according to my records, those places had been initiated by the Whitlam government.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members do not care about child care. They never have and their record proves it. The opposition's record proves that it has done absolutely nothing to assure Australian working families that their children are safe and will be well cared for.

On this issue opposition members should do the decent thing and sit down and shut up because it is clear from the policy announced at the last election that their party has nothing to say. In fact, it has a long record of having nothing to say. Meanwhile, the government's record on child care has been exemplary. We have increased the number of child care places from 46,000 to over 208,000 in 10 years. Opposition members cannot deny that because those are the facts.

I was interested to hear some of the comments made by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) during the debate. To some extent, I was a little outraged by the way in which he made some of his comments. He said, `Let me make it clear, I am not trying to denigrate anyone who is in a broken family or a single income family. I am not trying to denigrate those people in the child-care industry'. In the context in which the honourable member was saying this, he was indeed denigrating people in broken families, the children of those broken families and the people who work in the child-care industry. That is exactly what he was doing, but he did not want to take the load for that. He did not have the intestinal fortitude to say, `Yes, I look down upon you'. No, he wanted to make sure that the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) did not come in and take his heart out—if indeed he has one.

I was very proud to have heard the comments made by the honourable member for Forde from our side of the House. It was one of the better speeches that I have heard. Those on the other side of this House do not realise, have not realised and will never realise, whether they like it or not, that this Australian society is going through a process of reorganisation. We do not live in a static world but a dynamic world.

I am married to a person who was born overseas and who was eight when her family came to this country. It is interesting to listen to some of her relatives who seem to think that the old country that they came from all of a sudden stopped when they left, that it is in some sort of tomb and that all will be exactly the same when they go back. The world is not like that—and thank God it is not. The challenge to the men and women of Australia today—a comment that Gough Whitlam would have made; that is essentially where it started, as you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would know—and the response they have to make to the reorganisation of this society is inequality. He talked about people, irrespective of their genitalia, being able to stand up in a world where they could go forward and use the gifts that had been bestowed on them in the most appropriate way for the service of the community.

Some of us, particularly those in my age group—perhaps those younger than I do not even know about it—forget that up until 1966 it was against the law for married women to have jobs. To the credit of the then Liberal government, it threw that provision out by repealing that law. I urge honourable members to think about the fact that until 1966 when a woman got married she had to leave her job. There were so many women in Australian society who lived lies, who went to work secretly married and whispered about their husbands.

I am glad that this society is changing and that men and women have to face the challenges in front of them. It is not easy for women and it is not easy for men, because a new world order demands that we have to be introspective. We have to look at those things which have been cast upon us by the society around us—the prejudices and the things that we do not even realise that we know or that we have learnt. We have to examine those things and be self-critical. I know that is a very difficult thing in this place.

The honourable member for McPherson gave us a whole range of statistics about broken marriages and told us how the children of those broken marriages were somewhat tarnished. I suppose he was implying that child care was the cause of broken marriages. That is the only thing I could see about the relevance of what he was saying.

I put to the honourable member that broken marriages are all about broken relationships; they are all about people growing apart. Thank God we had Lionel Murphy. Thank God we had a man who stood up and said, `The charade that we have played in this country for years that you have to go out and get some pimp and pervert to take photos of your partner doing whatever in the back of a mini or wherever should be thrown out'. Thank God he tried to bring some form of justice and sense into the divorce laws of this country, because the honourable member for McPherson was implying that the old system was good, that people lived for 40 years in a state of war for the sake of the children and that abuse should have been handled quietly by saying, `Don't tell anyone'.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you know what I am talking about. You have lived in that Australia. Violence was swept under the carpet. In some of our ethnic groups—and I will not name any in particular—it is still a problem. People think they have a property right over another person and a right to inflict violence. As a teacher, I can say that when I first went out into that profession teachers were still caning children to make sure that they learned. There was corporal punishment to make people do the right thing. I refused to have anything to do with it. It took me a lot longer to learn the methodology of not having to beat people, but I felt a lot better about it as a teacher. I did make the effort to try to do that.

So much depression came out of the old system of marriage where people stuck together for the sake of the children and because of what the neighbours would think. There were illegal abortions. The honourable member for McPherson has implied that these things were good. He put the ridiculous proposition—and I hope people heard it—that child care might cause all this.

I recently read a book called Ships to Shore. It is a story about the Melbourne waterfront and the fights that took place there between the working class and the upper crust of Victoria—the aristocracy and the squattocracy. The honourable member for Forde was right. Poor and working class families have always had all their members working to put food on the table, shoes on their kids' feet, clothes on their backs and a roof over their heads. I appreciate the fact that the honourable member for Forde tried to remind those opposite of that. The situation is no different now.

A lot of hypocrisy goes down in this place, including the idea that child care was somehow going to take parenting away. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, would probably have noted one or two such ideas in your period in the House. The honourable member for McPherson is implying that private boarding schools should be banned. He wants to close all the private boarding schools because they are not parented—the parents are elsewhere. But not too many children of working class families went to private boarding schools. If he is suggesting that, a lot of people in the bush would be quite upset.

Our society has to reorganise. Men and women of Australia have to meet the challenge. And the challenge is for equal opportunity. It is not a matter of birth or genitalia or whether we have ability with our brains or other abilities. Intellectual capacity is not the only thing in society. Sometimes I have found that people who do not have a lot intellectually have been world beaters, because they have things called compassion and heart. I would suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that those things have nothing to do with a person's sex; they have a lot to do with a person's soul and spirit.

We hear rantings and ravings—and I have heard some of the most outrageous statements from the other side—about efficiencies and using our resources to the best of our ability. For God's sake, half the population of this country has been held out of positions in boardrooms and in this place—and my party has been guilty of it too. They have not been able to gain those positions—not through lack of ability, not through lack of assertiveness, not through lack of confidence, not through being unable to do the job, but because, in a world that is unequal and unfair, their genitalia got in the way. I do not mean physically, of course, but in fact they were seen as women—and we cannot have women in the boys' clubs.

I suggest that this equality has nothing to do with the breakdowns in marriage. I suggest that, if anything, the breakdowns in marriage have come from a lack of equality. I am guilty of this as much as anyone else. As individuals, we sometimes get caught up in our own self-importance. We get caught up with where we are going and do not talk; we do not express ourselves to the people who mean the most to us. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am learning, and I can tell you that it is hard. There are years of prejudice that have been ingrained. I have tried specifically to fight it, but I still find it coming out. It is embarrassing sometimes when it comes out because I do not even know it is there.

This challenge to create equality may not seem to have a lot to do with the bill before us, but it has everything to do with it. This is not a women's issue; this is a family issue. In years past I took exception to having my language corrected. Some of my fellow human beings took exception to words I used—words like `lady' and others. At the time I found it somewhat annoying. But, really, we do have to address the way that we look at issues.

With respect to all honourable members in this House, child care is not a women's issue; it is a family issue. In terms of my family life, I am desperately trying to do a rotten job. I love my job but, in terms of having a family, it is a rotten job—it takes us away. But I am desperately trying to do my best to contribute to my family in the biggest way that I possibly can.

The honourable member for Lowe (Ms Easson) who, in her first speech—and I emphasise that; her first speech—in this House referred to the creche needed in this place; she is doing me a very great service. When we had those ridiculous hours before Christmas, Sam, my 2 1/2-year-old son, was saying, `Don't go to work, daddy. I don't want you to go to work', to which I was replying, `I've got to, son; I've just got to'. I would have liked to have been able to have him here. My wife will be going back to her profession and holding down a career. Why should she not have a career? Why should she not be able to contribute? A thing that would hold her back is lack of child care.

Our child, when he goes into child care, is looked after by a lovely lady by the name of Sharon di Silva. For the information of the honourable member for McPherson, that woman is as good a parent, perhaps better, than I am—I would not say she is better than my spouse. As was pointed out by the honourable member for Forde, that carer loves my child and, for that reason, I trust her with him.

I was very pleased to hear the comments made by the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Quick) about accreditation. The bottom line on this child-care issue is getting good, decent, safe protection for our children which is affordable and available to all families. It is not just for the rich with their attitude of `Let's ship the kids off to boarding school; we won't have to see them for three months'. Not all parents who send their children to boarding school take that attitude, but there have probably been a few. I hope that this legislation results in a reorganisation of society. Child care will be a major plank in that reorganisation. I hope it results in a fairer Australia which recognises people—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to be speaking in this debate. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), on behalf of the Labor Party, gave an undertaking to the families of Australia prior to March 1993. That undertaking, which was to introduce a new allowance for home child care, has been prepared and is now being enacted in this legislation.

PARA.TAB: This allowance, which will be available from 29 September 1994, will replace the dependent spouse rebate currently available through the taxation system to couples with dependent children. The allowance will not be taxed; it will be for a maximum of $1,500 per annum; it will be indexed annually; and it will be subject to an income test based on the dependent partner's income.

This new allowance is welcomed by a great many women who remain in the home and whose main occupation—a very noble one—is full-time homemaking. Over the past generation, a great many married women with children have joined the paid work force—I am one of them—and I support a woman's right to do so if that is her decision. However, it is also true that many married women with children are in the paid work force not by choice but by necessity. The pressure of finance, mortgage payments and the cost of raising children have often forced women to leave their home and children to seek paid work outside the home. I do not think that a healthy society grows when the overriding ethos is an economic one. I have said often that Australia is primarily a society. Paid work is not the soul of our society. Our work is what we do, not what we are.

Many married women with children, given a real choice, would opt out of the paid work force and happily stay in the home. This is not universally true, but it is substantially true. It is especially true for women with young children. Obviously, as the youngest child grows older the need for the mother to be in the home full time can decline. This allowance is a very useful contribution to families having a choice in this field.

I understand that a lot of the problems and difficulties concerning working women with children still exist. It is therefore most important for this parliament—90 per cent male—to acknowledge the existence of these problems and difficulties. The solutions to these problems and difficulties are related to our economic development. Economically, we are still burdened by high unemployment, a persistent current account deficit and an aging population. A national policy of alleviating the effects of these three problems would require us to be a richer country than we currently are. A richer nation would extend the choices of working women with children.

I am particularly pleased to see that this allowance will be paid directly to the person doing the work of child care. Previously, the dependent spouse rebate operated through the tax return of, generally, the husband. I am very pleased to see that this allowance will be paid to many thousands of people below the tax threshold. The dependent spouse rebate was only available to taxpayers. These benefits, through the new allowance, will now be more widely available. This is equitable and more in keeping with our Australian way of doing things.

A more contemporary and equitable approach is recognised in this legislation, and the carer of the children, generally the wife, is the direct beneficiary of this allowance. I notice that proposed new section 907 says that a person will continue to receive the allowance even after being out of Australia for up to 13 weeks. I approve of this section. In today's world of jet travel, it is easy for parents and children to suddenly leave Australia to go to the side of an ill relative in another country. We are a nation of migrants, and many Australian children have one or both sets of grandparents overseas.

I ask the department to make a special effort to bring section 907 to the attention of allowance receivers. The department has a similar rule for other social security recipients and my office has dealt with people who have inadvertently fallen foul of a rule similar to proposed new section 907. This inadvertence was due to widespread lack of knowledge of the rule. I urge the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) to ensure that his department, which is already run highly efficiently, takes steps to advertise any social security rule that cuts off social security payments when recipients go overseas.

Proposed new section 771HA concerns qualifications for partner allowance. The section is well thought out and a model of clarity. However, real life can never be reduced to the framework of any group of public servants. It is certain that there will be situations in the future not covered by the new section 771HA. Therefore, it would be beneficial if this bill were to give latitude and discretion to the department's secretary and delegates of the secretary in the determination of qualifications for this allowance. We pay senior public servants well. They are well educated and conscientious, and I think this parliament can trust them with discretionary powers to be used in a positive manner in favour of a borderline applicant.

A further situation which qualifies for discretionary powers is proposed new section 771HF. This section deals with the assets test and an allowance not payable if the assets value limit is exceeded. We are fortunately now out of recession and advancing towards a better economic situation. In the years ahead we are likely to see property booms, stock exchange booms and all the other commonplaces of Australia during economic good times. This will make the determination of the value of assets quite problematic. Unless discretion is available to senior departmental officers to be used positively for the benefit of an applicant, we will see a great amount of departmental effort taken up in argumentation over aspects of proposed new section 771HF.

I congratulate the department on its sensitivity concerning the possible death and bereavement of a child, which, of course, brings to an end an allowance for home child care. Such sensitivity is definitely consistent with the general approach of honourable members of this House.

This legislation is excellent. It is a further example of good government by a cabinet that I am proud to support. The Prime Minister gave his word and his word is, again, his bond. Women and children across Australia will benefit from this legislation and we can all be proud of ourselves for having brought this allowance into being.

I say in conclusion that I was recently in America and when I spoke to congress men and women about the facilities we have in this country, they were amazed to hear of what we were doing with regard to child care and the home child-care allowance. They certainly do not have anything as forthright in direction as this and many of them were very envious of the sorts of policies that we have in this regard. I think it is often salient for us to realise how progressive many of our policies are and to take great pride in them in this country. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to take this opportunity to speak in support of the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill, which introduces the home child-care allowance and the partner allowance. The home child-care allowance gives effect to a commitment announced by the Labor government prior to the 1993 election. Both the home child-care allowance and the partner allowance build on previous government reforms to pay family payments directly to carers of children, usually women, and they are totally consistent with the Labor Party's commitment to social justice. In contrast, the coalition is exploring income splitting options, which would be regressive in most cases, providing most benefit to high income families, and would not provide a direct cash benefit to the carers of children.

PARA.TAB: Currently under the taxation system a dependent spouse rebate for couples with dependent children is provided in recognition of the fact that the cost of supporting dependants reduces a person's capacity to pay tax in comparison with a person who does not have dependants. That rebate will be replaced by the home child-care allowance, which will be paid directly to the dependent partner.Approximately 55,000 families whose tax liability was previously too low to get the full value of the existing dependent spouse rebate for couples with dependent children will receive greater assistance from the new allowance.

The home child-care allowance will be introduced on 29 September 1994 and, as I said, it will be paid fortnightly through the social security system. As I also said, it will be paid directly to the dependent partner of a couple with a dependent child or children. That is a very significant part of this bill. The maximum rate of the allowance will be $60 a fortnight, approximately $6 a fortnight higher than the current maximum rate of dependent spouse rebate for families with children. The allowance will be subject to an income test based on the income of only the dependent partner and will not be subject to an assets test.

The government is also introducing a partner allowance payable to dependent partners of recipients of the jobsearch allowance, newstart allowance or sickness allowance. This replaces the current situation where the additional amount is paid directly to the recipient of those allowances. The total amount involved will be the same but will now be split into two separate payments, one to each partner. This will apply from 20 September 1994.

These amendments underline the Labor government's commitment to child-care programs and to support for families with children. As a parent myself with a dependent spouse and young family, like a great many of my constituents in Macarthur, I understand the importance of these programs in the context of social justice.

The Macarthur electorate, south-west of Sydney, is one of the fastest growing regions. It has one of the youngest populations in Australia, with about half the population in the area under the age of 20. Unfortunately, many of the benefits of the significant commitment by this government to children's services programs in recent years have been denied to the people of Macarthur and to the people of New South Wales. This is because the New South Wales coalition government has deliberately obstructed and refused to sign the Commonwealth-state agreement in what has been a joint Commonwealth-state program.

As the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) mentioned earlier in the debate, 780 occasional child-care places funded by the Commonwealth in the 1988 budget have yet to be actually delivered, and at least 600 of these are in New South Wales. This disgraceful situation affects not only occasional child care but also other forms of child care, such as long day care and out of school hours care.

While the New South Wales Liberal-National government of John Fahey continues to play grubby politics with a Commonwealth-state program, the young families of New South Wales, including the areas of rapid growth and high need for children's services, such as Macarthur, continue to miss out. This situation has led to the federal government now deciding to fund many of these programs directly to local government, as was foreshadowed before the last election and announced by the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, last month.

The home child-care allowance is a major initiative in what is the International Year of the Family. We have heard a lot in this debate already about the International Year of the Family and much of it has been hypocrisy in the case of the opposition. Between Christmas and New Year I was on holidays with my family and I could not help but notice in the newspapers that around about 30 and 31 December a number of opposition members were falling over each other to get into the papers to strut their stuff about the International Year of the Family. It is almost as though they had just discovered that 1994 was going to be the International Year of the Family and they wanted to try to use it to make some political point. The opposition obviously has not got any other issues to run with so it thought it would invent something under that particular banner. It ran with the issue of income splitting and the proposal to look at the tax system. It was rather strange to see all of this in the papers. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) were all hopping into the newspapers trying to get some reflective glory in the International Year of the Family.

The Liberal Party was not quite so enthusiastic a year ago when it was the International Year of the World's Indigenous People. We did not hear much about that from the opposition. Those opposite took a rather different attitude towards the International Year of the World's Indigenous People. It was pretty clear from the Liberal Party's response to the Mabo decision and its disgraceful and obstructionist attitude towards the Native Title Bill that it was not very enthusiastic at all about the International Year of the World's Indigenous People.

Now that it is the International Year of the Family the opposition is suddenly jumping out of the woodwork and trying to gain some political mileage. If we listen to some of the rhetoric that we have heard in this debate today and some of the public statements that have been made, it would appear that the opposition thinks it has a monopoly on the family. It is almost as though the opposition thinks that people who vote Labor do not have families. We are told a lot about what sort of family we should have and what the appropriate family unit should be.

Everybody is born with parents and most people enjoy a family life of one sort or another. It is up to an individual to choose exactly what form that family takes. The opposition has missed the boat because it is the Labor government that has taken the initiative on the International Year of the Family. The government has introduced this legislation. I happen to know that for some years several departments—and particularly the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services—have been planning for this year.

The government has developed lots of initiatives on work based child care to encourage employers to provide work sponsored child care for employees. The expansion of the children services program has been tantamount evidence of this government's commitment to child care and the recognition of the importance of families in the International Year of the Family. Once again the opposition is trying to make some cheap political mileage and moralistic mileage out of the International Year of the Family.

It is the Labor government that has taken the initiative in this regard. It is the government that is doing the big things with child care and bringing in the reforms. It took the opposition 10 years to recognise that child care was an important issue in the community. In December 1992 the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) finally realised that Fightback 1 was not a goer and he had to change it a bit and bring in Fightback 2. That was when he recognised that child care was a bit important and he decided to do something about having a policy on child care.

It was a bit late because the Labor government had already been promoting child care, funding child care and recognising the importance of child care to both working parents and families where only one partner worked. The government has recognised the importance of child care as a social justice issue for a long time now. As with most major social reform in this country, the opposition is a long way behind and it will remain a long way behind.

I commend this bill to the House. It is yet another reform that the government promised in its election campaign and which it is delivering. It is another example of the government's great commitment to social justice. This is another example of the great contrast between the policies of the government and those of the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it extremely pleasurable to be able to start the new year following the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) on the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill. In particular I support his final remarks regarding the delivery of the commitments made in March of last year. As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said at question time today, some people find it difficult to accept that this government has been so consistent and so positive. That we have been progressing, step by step, the agenda put forward in the election from March right through till now, and we are still going, I think is fairly significant. It might be a bit hard for the opposition and some in the community who would rather demean that achievement to accept that. But the reality is that we as a government will persist and persevere. Those people who supported us in March 1993 on the basis of our platform and policies will be more than justified with their confidence.

PARA.TAB: It has always been poor practice to use tax rebates as a means of family support and recognition of dependent children and spouses. Turning that spouse rebate into an allowance, as this legislation does, will be a major step forward. In many ways it is coherent and fits very well with the range of actions of this government over the last 11 years. Looking at child allowances and family support—the whole raft of changes and initiatives that have been undertaken in that period—is just one more step in trying to focus on supporting, in ways which are appropriate, those in the community who need support. This is an extremely appropriate way.

Most of the things that relate to this issue have been said, but I think it is important that we still lend our visible and active support to it. It does consolidate the government provisions that assist families with children. I join with my colleagues in speaking in this debate and in adding our personal stamps and voices to it to indicate to all in the community that this government is not just coherent and far-sighted but also very strong and united in approaching issues that affect and support families. In this current year, that is more than appropriate. I very strongly commend the bill, which focuses on improving the conditions of families in the community, to the House.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all the honourable members, particularly from this side of the House, who have contributed to the debate. I listened with some interest to the contribution by the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock). Although I was not able to be in the House, I watched him on closed-circuit television. I must admit that what he had to say was no different from what he usually has to say in matters relating to the welfare of Australians, particularly families and those who need the social security system as some sort of a safety net and means of obtaining income, especially those who are on very low incomes.

PARA.TAB: As the parliamentary secretary in this House with responsibility for legislation in the social security area, I am very proud to have been involved in introducing and debating a number of measures in this portfolio over the last four years which, all in all, has been to the betterment of Australians generally and particularly to those who need our assistance. I will not take too much of the House's time, but I want to make a few comments on some of the contributions that were made, particularly by the honourable member for Berowra, who has come into the House. I apologise to the House for not being here in person when the honourable member made his contribution. I was here in spirit and listening to his contribution upstairs.

The honourable member for Berowra has made the claim tonight that income for most families will not change—that what we are doing here today is a revenue neutral exercise. When this measure is fully implemented there will be a cost to government of some $200 million more each year than the cost of the existing dependent spouse rebate. This is due to a number of factors. Firstly, there is an increase of nearly $6 per fortnight in the maximum payment, which means that nearly 800,000 families will benefit from this higher rate. In addition to that, we are paying up to $60 per fortnight to an additional 55,000 families whose tax liabilities were too low to get the full value of the dependent spouse rebate. Fifty-five thousand families who were getting nothing out of the dependent spouse rebate will now be covered by this measure.

This measure is much more responsive to family needs because it bases payment on the current income of the carer. That will assist up to 120,000 families a year. For example, if a woman leaves the work force to have a baby, she will be able to claim home child-care allowance straight away rather than having to wait until the new financial year.

These policies and measures contrast with some of the known stances taken by my colleagues in the opposition. The honourable member for Berowra claimed that the government did not have a coherent or sensible family policy. He said that different payments were delivered by different agencies—for example, that the child-care rebate was paid by Medicare offices. The reality is that the coalition has no family support policies; it is simply arguing about income splitting.

The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) said that during the silly season a number of opposition members were involved in making those sorts of statements. I do not see how splitting incomes will be of any great benefit to children. There is no doubt that such a measure would be highly regressive and hugely expensive, without delivering any direct assistance to the partner at home caring for the children.

One absolutely unbelievable act of hypocrisy came to my attention during the silly season when I happened to be listening to a report on ABC radio. I heard Senator Jocelyn Newman, if I remember correctly, saying all sorts of things about what the coalition would do for families. She had the audacity, as had the honourable member for Berowra, to criticise the government for lowering the income test for the basic family payment from $65,000 to $60,000. What the coalition did not say—this is the hypocrisy of it—was that under Fightback the opposition intended to knock that figure down to $55,000, which would have had the effect of cutting off twice as many families from the basic family payment system.

A number of coalition members—including, I think, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford)—claimed that every bit of government policy was anti-family. I acknowledge that the views held by the honourable member for McPherson are very sincere. I know that when he says something, particularly when it is about families, that it is said quite sincerely. Nevertheless, the attitude of those opposite, including the honourable member for McPherson, is a little bit rich. Their attitude ignores a number of things. In particular, it ignores this government's record of achievement in supporting families by initiatives such as Medicare and child care, and through direct payments, such as additional family payments for families dependent on social security and low income working families.

Families with two small children and which are renting privately now receive up to $123 per week in tax-free family payments. In real terms, that is worth more than five times the assistance that was paid at the time of our election to government in 1983. On top of that, many of these low income working families will soon get the HCCA. As an indication of just how much this government spends on families, in the 1993-94 budget some $5 billion was allowed for in family payments alone.

The honourable member for Berowra also complained about changing the maximum qualifying age of 25 under the dependent spouse rebate provisions to 18 under the new home child-care allowance provisions. Families without children can still claim the dependent spouse rebate, so the net loss is small. The government has decided to pay the HCCA on conditions as close as possible to those for the family payments, for which 18 is the maximum qualifying age. Therefore, very few families are affected by this and, in any event, it is offset to some extent by the home child-care allowance having a higher child income test than the dependent spouse rebate.

Some younger children with part-time jobs whose families would have missed out on the dependent spouse rebate will now get the HCCA. The HCCA is not payable if the family is overseas for more than 13 weeks or if the claim is made outside of Australia. However, such families can still claim the dependent spouse rebate without a child, so the net loss is very small.

I notice that the honourable member for Berowra issued a press release today which states all the things that he has said in the House. The fact is that he finds it difficult to acknowledge that we are doing the right thing. Since he became the shadow spokesman on social security matters at the time of the last election, I have seen him stand up in this place and absolutely deride every good measure that we have introduced in this House.

I must admit that every time I sum up or participate in a debate on these matters, I know full well that I will never get much of an accolade from the honourable member for Berowra. To be fair to him, sometimes he does congratulate us on some of the things that he knows he just cannot tear apart.

I will be moving one amendment in the committee stage. In the meantime, I commend the bill to the House. It is the delivery of a very important election initiative made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) during the last election campaign. I am very happy to be the person responsible for putting the bill through the House today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 11, line 15, omit proposed paragraph 926(a), substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(a)a payment by way of a social security pension, social security benefit or rehabilitation allowance other than that part of the payment that is for rent assistance, pharmaceutical allowance or remote area allowance; and".

SPEECH.PARA: I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum. This amendment seeks to amend clause 3 of the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill by omitting paragraph 926(a) and substituting a new paragraph 926(a). The new provision will exclude payments for rent assistance, pharmaceutical allowance and remote area allowance from being treated as income for the purpose of assessing the rate of home child-care allowance payable.

PARA.TAB: The effect of the amendment is that, for the purpose of the home child-care allowance, ordinary income will include a social security pension, benefit or rehabilitation allowance but not that part of a payment that is for rent assistance, pharmaceutical allowance or remote area allowance. The amendment recognises that these add-on allowances are made to compensate clients for particular circumstances. Rent assistance, for example, assists a client living in rental accommodation with the cost of rent. The amendment will allow a greater number of people to be paid the home child-care allowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will not oppose the amendment. I make the point, as I did in relation to the debate, that the necessity for an amendment of this sort demonstrates the shortcomings in legislation of this complexity and detail. I think the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill requires very considerable examination because of its impact.

PARA.TAB: Earlier in the debate I took the opportunity of highlighting a number of matters which were of concern to me. They have not been fully addressed by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) in his contribution to this debate. As I am sure is well understood by you, Mr Nehl, and many of your colleagues, obviously the fact that an allowance such as the remote area allowance, to which a great deal of importance is attached, was to be included in the assessment of income demonstrates the shortcoming.

The relationship between my office and the offices of the parliamentary secretary and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) is not altogether that distant that we were not asking for details of these matters, and we were informed in advance that an amendment was intended. A bill of this sort ought to be the subject of a much more comprehensive examination by this parliament than the rather cursory examination that occurs in a debate of this sort. I am disappointed that it will be up to the Senate to undertake that examination.

The parliamentary secretary will see that I do compliment some of his colleagues. The honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) emphasised last evening the importance of committees of this House being involved in scrutiny of complex and detailed legislation. I was particularly impressed by the way he was able to advert how he circulates government legislation amongst his former colleagues in our profession for comment, advice and counsel.

If the government were prepared at this stage to accept that an inquiry be undertaken by a committee of this parliament, I would be happy to accede to that suggestion. If the government is not prepared to respond in that way, the opposition will seek to have the matter referred to a Senate committee to enable that comprehensive review to take place. My examination of the differences between this legislation and the Income Tax Assessment Act in relation to the way in which tests are applied in qualifying for these allowances as against the old dependent spouse rebate, revealed an enormous number of implications for the way in which this new scheme will operate, which the parliament ought to have cognisance of when it is looking at the matter.

The parliamentary secretary gave an explanation in relation to the issue of people living outside Australia. I appreciate the explanation and the fact that eligibility for a dependent spouse rebate might still apply. But it is a fact that eligibility for the dependent spouse rebate will still apply to, say, an Australian soldier serving in Butterworth, or Australian troops serving in Australia's interests in a peacekeeping force, or an Australian diplomat, or even to officers of the Department of Social Security who are placed in some overseas posts and who may be, for a time, with their families. The dependent spouse rebate that they would be eligible for would be at a lower rate than the full rate—with dependants, I assume—so the benefit they would receive would be lower.

I regard that as an anomaly. I suspect it has not been addressed. I would like to think that, if there is this thorough examination, these matters which are being addressed on an ad hoc basis at the moment with amendments of this sort will be reviewed thoroughly, completely and fully. I welcome a response from the parliamentary secretary. If the government is prepared to have a committee of this House do the job, I think that would be a very useful advance.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report—by leave—adopted.
Bill (on motion by Mr Sciacca)—by leave—read a third time.
Debate resumed from 14 December, on motion by Mr Free:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1993 we have a case of basically fiddling with something which is fundamentally rotten. The training guarantee scheme has not worked and altering a few minor points will not change anything. All manner of people and all manner of reports since this scheme was introduced have told the government that the training guarantee levy is not working, but despite that the government simply does not want to listen. The government motto appears to be that as long as it appears to be doing something then it can delude people into thinking that it is governing for the good of the country. In this case it would be far better if the government did nothing at all.

PARA.TAB: The training guarantee levy was introduced in July 1990 by the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins). As we know, the path to hell is paved with good intentions and the government was anxious to improve training opportunities for Australian workers. To this end, the government, with its usual fairy-like lightness of touch, brought in what was essentially a new tax on business to force companies to meet a fairly arbitrary level of training for their employees. At first, this meant that only companies with a payroll of $200,000 or more were required to pay the levy. Later the payroll was raised to $220,000. The levy began at one per cent of annual national payroll and has risen to 1.5 per cent.

The first point about the levy is that it simply does not cover the majority of Australian businesses which are too small to fall within the net. In fact, 93 per cent of businesses are excluded from the requirements of this legislation due to insufficient payroll.

The second point is that the rest were, in most cases, already spending the money on training. The big companies were spending at least two to three per cent on training. For example, companies such as IBM spend as much as 10 per cent of their annual payrolls on intensive staff training. Research by the Australian Taxation Office found that 63 per cent of businesses believed that they were spending the same or less on training since the levy was introduced. For some, the levy was a positive inducement to spend less on training of their staff because it put a specific figure beyond which the businesses were already spending on training and therefore managers decided that they were training in excess of what is normal and could introduce some useful cost cutting into the training area.

A study by Professor Charles Noble of Charles Sturt University which looked at the impact of the levy on businesses in the Albury-Wodonga area found that 81 per cent of firms surveyed said that if the levy was abolished there would be no impact on the amount of training they were conducting. In the report one employer said:

SPEECH.PARA: The training levy is just one more wank in the overgrown undergrowth [of bureaucracy] and no worse than some of the others, but taken together they are as forbidding as a sea of blackberries.

What the Australian Taxation Office found, and various other reports have corroborated, is that 70 per cent of firms believe that the levy has resulted in more administrative work for their businesses. The levy is just another roll of red tape with which to strangle business in Australia. This may not be as crucial to large businesses but, for small to medium sized businesses which exist on a knife edge and have particularly done so in the last two or three years, it is not merely a manifest waste of resources, but often another nail in the coffin.

PARA.TAB: But the truly telling point is that not one study has had a good word for the training guarantee levy. The best that has been said about it is that it has made businesses focus on training. As the ones that do focus did so anyway, this is not really much of a point.

The Vocational Education, Employment Training Advisory Committee pointed out what should have been obvious about this scheme from the start. No money is being spent to assess what impact the changes in training are having. Therefore, there is absolutely no way of knowing whether any goal has been achieved, let alone whether that is the right goal. Twenty-eight per cent of the money spent on education in Australia is spent on vocational training, but only 15 per cent is spent on research. It is because there has been little scholarly research in the area that the Carmichael report got such an uncritical reception and the government has been able to go its own sweet way. Dean Ashendon produced a report for the National Board of Employment, Education and Training pointing out that there is no single body in this country responsible for national directions in skills formation and recognition. It is a gap to which we are looking to the Australian National Training Authority to fill.

A study by Tim Henson, from Monash University's David Syme faculty of business, found that only four companies in 100 had anything positive to say about the training guarantee levy. The study looked at medium sized manufacturing firms in Victoria. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Respondents from all industry sectors stated that they are now simply documenting what was already done prior to the introduction of the act.

Thirty-four per cent of respondents considered the effectiveness of the training guarantee legislation in improving the skills of the Australian work force to be only minimally effective and over 60 per cent of the respondents indicated that the training levy was minimally to not at all effective in improving workplace skills.

PARA.TAB: Expenditure on training has increased over the period since the introduction of the legislation from 2.2 per cent of gross wages and salaries in the September quarter of 1989 to 2.6 per cent in the corresponding quarter of 1990. However, these figures are entirely rubbery because of the lack of record keeping before the introduction of the levy itself and so cannot be relied upon in any way. Training on average now consists of 3.6 hours of on-the-job training and 2.3 hours of external training at a cost of about $27.50 per hour to employers.

The National Society for Performance and Instruction has claimed that this expenditure is money not well spent. The society has cautioned that 80 per cent of trainers and human resource practitioners did not conduct proper evaluation of what training was needed in the organisation served and did not evaluate whether the training had any discernible effects.

The nub of the problem with such heavy-arm tactics for encouraging training is that all of the emphasis is placed on the delivery of the training itself rather than the actual content and the value of the training. This observation has been corroborated by the Job Watch organisation, which reported earlier in 1982 that much of the training provided to the unemployed hoping to reskill is inadequate.

From what I have been told by Social Security officers, the unemployed are put on a merry-go-round of mickey mouse, dead-end, short training courses and are no better off than before they started, but the public conscience of course has been salved because the money has been spent, albeit in many cases uselessly. This is, I suppose, what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) calls being jobs ready. There is no point in being jobs ready unless there are jobs, and the economic miracle we are now witnessing is not expected to do much for those who are already unemployed in this country.

Another taxation office report led to the damning admission that, on the basis of compliance in 1990-91, there was insufficient evidence available to conclude whether the legislation has led to any improvement in the quality of training or any increase in the amount and distribution of employer investment in employer related training. Less than 20 per cent of money spent went to external training programs.

The legislation was aimed at stimulating training in small businesses, where it was most lacking, but here the levy has had the least effect. Businesses with payrolls between $220,000 and $500,000 a year accounted for 65 per cent of the eligible employer population and made up 77 per cent of those who voluntarily lodged shortfall statements and 75 per cent of those who did not meet their training obligations. This small business group, with the equivalent of eight to 20 employees, had the lowest estimated compliance rate at 94.1 per cent.

What should be pointed out about the compliance rates is that for the first year of the levy the standards set by the tax office were not particularly rigorous. The tax office concedes that if its assessments had been more rigorous the compliance rate would have been reduced to around 80 per cent.

Previously, the company had only to show that it spent the amount and made a genuine effort. Now it is required that the training program must be structured. This means that before the program begins, organisations have to identify the skills to be acquired by the participants in the training, the means of imparting those skills, expected outcomes and the extent to which the participants' productivity will be enhanced.

The requirement for structured training presents a particular dilemma for small to medium sized businesses. About 45,000 of them fall within the net of the levy. If the training is not structured, employers who have spent well in excess of 1.5 per cent of their payrolls on training find that they still have a liability to make a non-tax deductible payment to the Australian Taxation Office.

A study by Karen Beresford and Jim Gaite from the University of South Australia reported that small business managers agreed unanimously that staff training was helpful to a business but was not necessarily of a kind that could be claimed under the Training Guarantee Act. This is because much of the one-to-one unstructured training considered vital to a small business is a training cost but it is too difficult, or in many cases impossible, to claim under the training guarantee levy provisions.

I will use an example which may be a little sensitive to members opposite at present. How does one structure the training of a sandwich hand in a little sandwich shop in, for example, Moonee Ponds? The managers interviewed for this report did not know whether they were complying with the legislation and feared the imposition of the levy at a time of diminished income. They identified record keeping as a serious problem. The authors concluded that there was a need for a radical review of the act and its administration as soon as possible.

The training guarantee levy has been more a boon to beach resorts and exotic overseas cities than to businesses as such. It was reported in the Australian Financial Review in July last year that, according to industry estimates, up to 30 per cent—that is almost one-third—of the funds used for training involve overseas and domestic conferences that are little more than executive and staff holidays.

In April last year, several hundred Australian businessmen, lawyers and doctors went to Hong Kong in time for the annual rugby sevens tournament. Many were aided in their travels by the training levy. Numerous legal and business conferences which complied with the training levy legislation were held in Hong Kong during the rugby tournament.

The tax office is trying to clamp down on rorts, but industry sources claim that the amount of pseudo training by companies could range from about 10 per cent to a third of the $841 million that is presently spent under the terms of the levy, or between $85 million and $280 million of this amount.
