I will give some other examples that have been noted of training approved by the tax office: travel to Brazil by a group of motor industry executives; a conference for political lobbyists in Honolulu; and a four-day luxury cruise on the Hawkesbury for members of the New South Wales Employers' Federation.

What should immediately be obvious and offensive to those on the opposite benches—particularly those from the Left of the Labor Party—is that most of this training concerns managers and executives. The training guarantee levy is being used by business to re-skill middle and senior staff, often at the expense of workers.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures at 28 July last year show that study leave was given to 36 per cent of managers and professionals, who made up only 13 per cent of the total work force, while only 9 per cent of labourers and plant operators got study leave, even though they made up almost one-third—in fact, 32 per cent—of the work force. So there is a great disproportion in where the funds are spent in terms of the training guarantee levy itself. If this proposal has the objective of somehow skilling the nation, particularly the ordinary workers of the nation, it is falling far short of those objectives.

According to Professor Richard Sweet from the Dusseldorf Skills Forum, many Australian companies do not require workers at low levels to exercise responsibility and skill. Recent surveys of the metal industry have shown that the levy has been totally ineffective in raising expenditure on training, particularly of blue collar workers. So much for care about the true believers.

The levy has been condemned by the Business Council of Australia as an inappropriate method of encouraging industry to train. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has also called for the scrapping of the levy. The ACCI did a survey of the effects of the training guarantee levy on Australian business, which it released this year. It concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: The training guarantee survives today as a nuisance imposition on the costs of running a business and on the structure of training at the enterprise level.

The firms that participated in the survey indicated that there had been a slight to moderate increase amongst almost 23 per cent of their number. This, as the report states, would demonstrate a useful addition to total output if the aim of economic activity was training, rather than goods and services. But as industry training is merely a means to an end, which is to make economic activity possible, the measure of the usefulness of training is where there is a demonstrable shortage of skills.

PARA.TAB: Only around 8.9 per cent of responding firms can be said to be experiencing skill deficiencies. Increased training is therefore only of benefit to these firms. The government's attitude is clearly that we cannot have too much of a good thing, but increased training costs where there is no benefit or need—the company's workers already being sufficiently skilled for the job—have to be taken into account in assessing this legislation.

Half of all responding firms experience significant increases in costs as a result of the imposition of the training guarantee. Furthermore, there is no reason to suppose, the report argues, that the training provided in firm A, for which there is no immediate need for training, will provide the kind of training needed to meet the skill shortages of firm B. One in six businesses found an increase in paperwork due to the training guarantee, and these are simply a dead weight on the economy.

Training is being directed to satisfy a bureaucratic set of requirements, rather than to target the skill needs of the Australian work force. Recently, the Prime Minister's task force on regional development has found that the training levy is not providing the training for which it was designed. The Prime Minister's own task force recommended that the scheme be suspended for three years. The task force reported that the levy was not fully understood by industry, had received mixed acceptance and was an administrative burden.

The training guarantee is a poor substitute for more difficult reform. There has been a failure by government to consider why industry has not been investing in training. This has much to do with our flat wage structure and, until recent times, a lack of industrial competition. What the government has served up is only training for training's sake. What we need, rather, are incentives for industry to train and for young people to take up vocational training.

I suspect that many on the opposite benches would join the coalition in voting for the end of this nuisance levy if they had a conscience vote on this matter. Therefore, I urge the House to do business and the workers of Australia a favour by repealing the training guarantee levy. I indicate that at the committee stage of the debate I will be moving amendments which, if passed, will effectively bring the scheme to an end on 1 July this year.

I note that whilst there is some little attempt to add more flexibility to the training guarantee levy, that little flexibility is so minute that, for example, in allowing firms to average their training from one year to another, all it simply does is say that, if firms have a training excess in one year, they may carry that forward for an additional year. One would have thought that if the government was seriously intent in bringing about some real flexibility in the system which it had introduced, it might allow averaging of training over a period of, say, three to five years. But we see nothing of that nature in this bill. That indicates that there is no serious intention of providing real flexibility in terms of the levy itself. For those reasons, as I said, I will be moving an amendment at the committee stage of this debate to introduce a sunset clause into this legislation, the effect of which would be that the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act would cease to have effect on 1 July this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mrs Silvia

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) made a statement during his discourse in the last 20-odd minutes that I would like to rectify for him. He stated that the CES was putting people on training programs regardless of their needs. I would like to inform the honourable member that this statement is absolutely and utterly irrelevant to the issue of the training guarantee.

PARA.TAB: The Training Guarantee Amendment Bill fixes the problems associated with the Training Guarantee Act. It honours this government's election commitment to do so. The Training Guarantee Act, which was enacted in July 1990, provides for employers to spend at least a minimum amount on training. The entire rationale behind this scheme is to make the Australian work force competitive on an international basis. We need a labour force which is so highly skilled that it can rapidly adapt to shifts in the international economy. The training guarantee scheme ensures that Australia is developing just such a work force. It means that, as the economy strengthens, a pool of skilled labour is available for the growing economy as and when it is required.

Some honourable members opposite view the training guarantee as having a negative impact on small businesses because of greater direct and administrative costs. The facts are that, prior to the training guarantee, little or no training was conducted by any small business. Let me give the House an actual example of how the training guarantee has specifically helped small business:

SPEECH.PARA: A chartered accountant in a New South Wales country town, sensing business opportunities for the accounting profession from training guarantee, completed the Train the Trainer course. His first task was a request from a company that traded as a contract weed exterminator on the cotton fields. His client sought advice as to what training they could provide to their workers. The problems were as follows: their work force was seasonal, not well educated and constantly changing; the work was mainly digging weeds from around cotton plants with a hoe or a large knife; the previous efforts at training had been unsuccessful and the client was thinking of sending the money to the Taxation Office.

The accountant spent time seeing just what took place on an average day and found: the workers suffered numerous injuries from their implements; they had little knowledge of occupational health and safety; up to a third of the cotton plants were damaged by the weeding process; the workers had little knowledge of how to treat different classes of weeds. The accountant then arranged to plan and conduct classes in: occupational health and safety, covering safety footwear, sun protection and first aid courses for the foremen. A course was then devised to allow the various classes of weeds and their eradication to be covered. Foremen were then to be designated first aid officers.
The accountant has since been contacted by his client who advised the following results:

Since training, staff stability has improved; accident claims have decreased, leading to a reduction in workers compensation premiums; the weeding process has improved to such an extent that the need for recalls because of unsatisfactory work has been eliminated; the client estimated that the savings to his firm were $30,000 for the first six months. The savings to their clients and the economy in general just from this example would be great.

This example shows the absolute and undeniable value of the training guarantee to Australian small businesses. Occupational and health and safety training is one of the major planks upon which the training guarantee is pinned. Many Australian employees do not pay as much attention to occupational health and safety as they ought. An article from yesterday's Age by industrial reporter Nicholas Johnson highlights the extreme importance of training in this area. He wrote:
Australian employers are endangering the lives of workers by failing to provide adequate training in the workplace, according to a new study.

PARA.TAB: The study, by the National Safety Council of Australia, found that a lack of proper induction training had contributed to more than 600 deaths and 500,000 injuries in workplaces last year.

The study, which examined 100 injuries caused by mechanical equipment, found that 56 per cent of employers did not provide employees with induction training and 70 per cent neglected refresher training.
The council's chief executive officer, Mr Jim Whiting, said up to half of the workplace injuries were suffered by workers in their first few hours or days in a job.
Young workers were particularly vulnerable, although older, more experienced employees who were assigned new tasks were also at risk.
Mr Whiting said workplace injuries cost Australia almost $2 billion a year in compensation payments. The cost, including lost production and working hours, was $10 billion.
He believed 90 per cent of large employers provided adequate training.
Mr Whiting said employers had a legal and moral responsibility to ensure that new workers were aware of all potential dangers, and to properly train them in standard work.
The chief executive of the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Mr David Edwards, agreed that employers could do more.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Malcolm Mackerras in a recent article in the Australian predicted that next Saturday's New South Wales by-election in North Shore would mark the beginning of the end for Independents in New South Wales. It is tempting to say that, given Mr Mackerras's record of predictions, this is good news for the Independents and perhaps the fact that Independents do not fit the famous Mackerras election pendulum tends to obscure Malcolm's professional judgment.

PARA.TAB: But seriously, there is a range of reasons why voting patterns have increasingly changed in the last decade. These reasons are long-term trends both nationally and internationally. In Australia since 1980 the non-major party vote has grown from four per cent to 18 per cent on average around Australia in state and federal elections. In between elections, polls routinely indicate up to a 20 per cent non-major party vote.

In 1992, 11 of the 15 Australian houses of parliament were not controlled by the executive governments. It is true that this has slipped back to six out of 15 and that the non-major party vote dropped to about 11 per cent at the highly polarised 1993 election. However, this was due primarily to the strident personalities of the leaders and the radical policies of the opposition and, in my view, is simply a bump in the graph.

The underlying reasons for the multiplicity of Independent candidates and minor parties remain in spite of the difficulties for them of funding and the `winner take all' single member electorate systems. These reasons are many: the changing electoral bases of political parties; the decline of rigid party identification; demographic shifts such as falling rural populations and growing coastal areas, immigration and general transience; labour market changes; reduced employment in manufacturing; the decline of unionism; the growth of women in the work force and their increased political activism; the spread of education; and, most of all, the growth of the ethic of participation since the 1960s and the consequent dissatisfaction with the basis of traditional representative government. This has led to the growth of well organised interest groups in Australia and around the world.

It was inevitable that the rate of change, both economic and social, and the deregulation of the 1980s would affect political systems and allegiances. The massive political reorganisations occurring throughout the world are evidence of this. The current moves here towards republicanism and constitutional reform are part of that change. The traditional political duopoly cannot stand aside from the forces of deregulation and competition.

The centralisation of power in both parties has led to a steadily declining membership and a paucity of candidates. The seemingly endless parade of both major and minor political corruption scandals revealed by increasing media scrutiny has forced many people to look for alternative representation. Frankly, unless the major parties make a concerted effort, the present public perception of them as self-serving institutions with endlessly expanding perks and lurks, existing mainly to distribute public funds to supporters and perpetuating themselves in office, will accelerate their disintegration.

The gradual adoption of proportional voting in upper houses has encouraged tactical voting and further weakened major party allegiance. Many of these features are evident in democracies around the world, as is the rise of interest groups, minor parties and Independents. Possibly the main reason why the Australian two-party rigidity has held up as long as it has is compulsory voting. This tends to reduce electoral volatility with its 30 per cent largely apathetic major party vote acting as a shock absorber at national elections and perhaps 50 per cent at state levels. It should be remembered that compulsory voting is a system traditionally used mainly by right wing dictatorships, communist countries and Australia.

In the North Shore by-election the fact that an Independent, Robyn Read, is even a serious contender is evidence of all of these trends. One major party, Labor, has given up. The Liberals are running a three-time loser as a candidate, the recipient of `jobs for the girls', who is now involved in another version of politicisation of the Public Service and a sports rorts controversy.

This is a commentary on a major party's ability to attract candidates. The reason the inner city areas of Sydney have seen the development of independent voting patterns is that they are the most extreme examples of all the deregulating characteristics. It is no accident that both serious candidates in the North Shore by-election are women, with women dominating the campaign organisation of the Independent, Robyn Read.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Singh, Mr Mangal: Arrival in Australia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of this adjournment debate to record a significant centenary which was celebrated on Sunday near Gordonvale in my electorate. I had the pleasure of attending the 100th anniversary of the arrival of Mr Mangal Singh in Australia. In doing so, I pay tribute to the Sikh community in Far North Queensland and in Australia generally.

PARA.TAB: Mr Mangal Singh arrived in Melbourne in 1894 and stayed several years before returning to India. He then travelled the world widely and returned to Australia in 1914. He tried to bring other members of the family from India to Australia. He was unsuccessful, no doubt due to our restrictive White Australia immigration policy. His son, Daleep Singh, came to Australia in 1925 and worked for farmers at Edmonton in my electorate and on the Atherton Tablelands.

Sikhs are hard workers. In 1948 Daleep Singh bought the first family canefarm. Family members are still canefarmers, as are many other Sikhs in the far northern community. Mangal Singh's grandson, Daleep Singh's son, Gian Singh and his family were our hosts at the celebration on Sunday. About 300 people attended and I am told that relatives travelled from Melbourne, Brisbane, Cardwell and the Atherton Tablelands for the occasion.

The celebration was evidence that the Sikh culture is alive and well in Far North Queensland. The music and food were testament to that. It is relevant to note that 100 years ago, when Mangal Singh came to Australia, if he had resided in Queensland, the Queensland Elections Act 1895 effectively would have prohibited his enrolment as a voter and the Queensland Aliens Act 1861 would almost certainly have excluded him from naturalisation and holding freehold title in Queensland.

In 1901 the notorious education test was introduced into the federal Immigration Restriction Act. This act obviously provided the difficulty that Mangal Singh had in trying to bring his family members to Australia early this century. There was certainly no family union provision then.

Those days are long gone and I am proud that the Labor government introduced the Australian Citizenship Act in 1973. It allowed non-whites to be eligible for assisted passage. In 1983, the Hawke government brought in a totally non-discriminatory immigration policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —And who abandoned the White Australia policy?

—I ignore the comments by the honourable member for Flinders. He obviously does not have much interest in multiculturalism or the Sikh community. I thank Gian Singh and his family for their hospitality and congratulate Anthony Singh on his Australia Day youth award by the Mulgrave Shire Council. I will quote from an article by Professor Sarva Daman Singh, which I also mentioned in a speech I made at the event on Sunday, and which I think is significant. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we live in a largely tolerant, compassionate society, which does not normally discriminate against its people on grounds of race or religion. Indeed, it is not respectable to do otherwise. Indians make significant contributions to the prosperity and quality of life in the country they now call home.
That certainly applies to the Australian descendants of Mangal Singh in Far North Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 September last year in this place, I supported a New South Wales pharmacist, Stuart Keen, in his bid to assert his customers' right to choose cheaper `benchmark' brands of drugs when having prescriptions dispensed. At that time, there was a deal of publicity on the subject, including several television excerpts in the ABC's 7.30 Report of 6 July, 25 August in Sydney and 26 August in Melbourne. These highlighted Mr Keen's courage in attempting to save his customers unnecessary expense, even though they and he were allegedly being harassed by officers of the Health Insurance Commission during their official investigation.

PARA.TAB: Even then, there was abundant evidence from this country as well as others, including the United States and Britain, that benchmark or lower priced drugs were being substituted widely to replace the more expensive premium brands, particularly in hospitals. It seemed evident that the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association were being ultra conservative in their opposition to dispensing benchmark drug brands. It also appeared that some members of the medical profession were resistant to change in this respect. However, at least partly due to Mr Keen's persistent efforts on behalf of his patients, there was a softening of attitude in favour of the cheaper benchmark brands and customers visiting a pharmacy were closer to being able to exercise their personal choice of drug type.

Unfortunately, since then I am sorry to say that the situation has taken a turn for the worse, which is my reason for speaking on this same topic tonight. On 21 December last year, Stuart Keen was issued with a summons relating to charges brought against him by Mr David Charles Stuart, Senior Investigating Officer with the Health Insurance Commission.

It is not for me to comment on these charges, being well aware of the concerns surrounding sub judice matters, but I can question the circumstances surrounding the summons. It seems curious that the summons, dated 12 November, was not issued until a few days before Christmas, even though the court appearance was set for 18 January. As most people would agree—keeping in mind the fact that many professional services, including those of the legal profession, are unavailable due to the season's festivities and holidays—the issuing of a summons immediately prior to Christmas for a court appearance on 18 January certainly imposed an unnecessary time limit on the defendant.

Even more disturbing is the fact that the summons was dated approximately five weeks earlier—that is, 12 November. One would have to ask why there should have been such a delay in issuing a summons for a mid-January court appearance. It is also necessary to question the timing of a fax received by Mr Keen's solicitor, Mr Paul Baker of Ebsworth and Ebsworth, at 5.09 p.m. on 17 January, which sought to amend the information deleting five of the original 33 charges and adding a further two, when the parties were due in court at 10 a.m. the next day.

It seems a pity that the Health Insurance Commission feels a need to be petty, vindictive and wasteful of the taxpayer's dollar in its efforts to make Stuart Keen the sacrificial lamb of the benchmark brand affair when he has done so much to alert the public and the pharmaceutical and medical establishments to the obvious advantage of choice in this particular matter. If, as seems likely, the law is changed to allow for the substitution of benchmark for premium drug brands where appropriate, those who will benefit most—the sick and the aged—will be able to thank Stuart Keen. As I said last September in talking on this subject in this place, I believe that Stuart Keen should be applauded, not persecuted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday 28 January, Australia lost one of its proudest sons when Frank Hardy died at his home in Melbourne. Frank died at his desk with the form guide in his hand, preparing for Saturday's races. He was a complex and a lovable character. Frank achieved notoriety in 1950 when he published Power Without Glory and when in 1951 he was charged, tried and acquitted of the archaic charge of criminal libel.

PARA.TAB: Frank was born in the year of the Russian Revolution at Southern Cross in Victoria. He left school at the age of 13 and worked in a number of unskilled jobs. He left school in 1930 in the pit of the Great Depression. Through 10 years of the 1930s, Frank Hardy experienced the excesses of a social and economic system which had broken down and the hardship, the deprivation and the misery associated with it. He said that it was those hungry years and the logic of his own experience which caused him in about 1940—he could never be sure of the exact time—to join the Communist Party. That was also the year of his marriage.

Frank remained a committed socialist. He realised that when he spoke out against the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia he would be treated as persona non grata by the Soviet government. It was some years after that that a visiting writer from the Soviet Union told Frank that they thought he must have died because all references to him suddenly disappeared from Soviet publications.

Frank Hardy joined the army in 1941 and served until 1946. He was a cartoonist before he was a writer and he founded and edited an army publication. His great storytelling caused his contemporaries to encourage him to write.

Too many people have forgotten the courageous stand of Frank Hardy when he fought for the wages and land rights of the Aborigines in the 1960s and 1970s. It was Frank who introduced his great mate, the late Fred Hollows, to the Gurindjis. It was Frank Hardy who was largely instrumental in assisting the Gurindjis to become the first Aborigines to win land rights in 1975.

Frank Hardy stood for the principles of socialism. He believed that a social system structured without class and based on the freedom of the individual would best contribute to the elevation of the human personality and the development of human capacities. But Frank was able to reconcile a profound philosophical and humanitarian commitment to his conception of an ideal social system with the down-to-earth personal qualities which led Malcolm Muggeridge to refer to him as `the most Australian Australian'.

Frank and Fred Hollows were great mates. It was almost exactly one year ago when Frank delivered the chief eulogy at the remembrance service in St Mary's Cathedral in Sydney. As I said in the condolence motion to Fred Hollows, it would have been the first and only time that the chief eulogy to an Australian communist was delivered by his communist mate at a state funeral in the Sydney cathedral of the Catholic Church.

Frank's life encompassed that remarkable period from the establishment of Soviet communism to its ultimate collapse and disintegration. In later years, Frank was embarrassed by his book `Journey into the Future', which he published in 1952 following his visit to the Soviet Union in 1951. He regretted his praise of Stalin and often wished that he had spoken out against Stalinism earlier. However, Frank was a visionary who sought for the people of the world a social order that would enhance and elevate the human character. He said on occasions that he did not know whether communism or Christianity was the superior system because neither of them had ever been tried. The Sydney Morning Herald, in its obituary for Frank Hardy, said that he was fast becoming our most treasured Red. I think Frank achieved that eminence.

I extend my personal sympathy to Frank's family—Frances, Alan and Shirley—and to Jennie, whom he described to me as his counsel, his confidante and his best friend. We are all the losers with Frank's passing. As he said when he delivered the eulogy for his mate Fred Hollows almost exactly a year ago:

SPEECH.PARA: We will never see the likes of him again.

We can say the same about Frank Hardy. Frank's public funeral services will be held in the Collingwood town hall this Friday at 1.30 p.m. Perhaps a number of us will be there, with his family, his friends, his admirers and supporters—including the Gurindjis, the Eritreans, Gough Whitlam and others—to say farewell to a great Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mrs Silvia

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent weeks there has been a great deal of scare-mongering, criticism and what I consider to be misinformation about the government's national child-care accreditation scheme, which was introduced by the Minister for Family Services, Senator Rosemary Crowley.

PARA.TAB: This scheme has the stated aim of improving the quality of care in our long day care centres. Centres that fail to meet specified standards could lose their fee relief, but surely the mothers of today want quality care provided for their children, just as I did when my children were young.

I would like to read an article written by Bronwen Hayes which appeared today in my local paper, the Examiner, and which speaks out very positively with regard to the accreditation scheme. It is headed `Rise in cost of child care "not likely in Tassie"'. It says:
Local child care centres have dismissed suggestions the Federal Government's planned accreditation scheme will lead to a rise in fees.
Independent reports obtained by child care associations in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland have found the new system could see fees increase by between $18 and $69 a week.
But Launceston child care centres have moved to allay fears that such a rise could occur here.
The director of the Bungawitta Child Care Centre, Ms Barbara Blest, said the accreditation scheme was `terrific' and `well overdue'.

SPEECH.PARA: "The only way it can put costs up is if quality care is not being provided," she said.

PARA.TAB: "It will only force up costs for those centres that are cutting corners and they have no right to do that when they are looking after children.
"No-one should be providing sub-standard care," she said.
Ms Sally Von Bertouch, director of the Dame Marjorie Parker Creche, said the accreditation scheme was `a positive step' which provided security for parents.
"We have been fighting for it for some time," she said.
Ms Von Bertouch said the licensing guidelines in Tasmania were already strict, easing the impact of the accreditation process.
"Costs have been built in over the years so I don't expect any increase," she said.
The director of the Pedder Patter Child Care Centre, Ms Patty Birchall, said the accreditation scheme was `the best thing that has happened to child care'.
"It should be seen as a positive step for families to know their children will be cared for in a quality environment," she said.
Ms Birchall said only those centres with sub-standard services would face additional costs as a result of the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a prime example why most honourable members on this side and the other side should consider working together to improve the situation of our children who are needing child care in this climate. I am pleased to advise the House that I do take some heart from the possibility that some people on the other side of the House look positively on some of the ideas that are coming from this side.

PARA.TAB: An honourable member on the opposite side whose name escapes me asked a question in question time regarding the situation of youth suicide and what the government is going to do about it. I have had discussions with several honourable members on the opposite side. We should all work towards ascertaining the reasons and finding a solution for youth suicide.

I was told last year that some 85 per cent of Australian families at some time in their lifetime will be affected by suicide, either of a family member or a friend. At that time I was very satisfied to say that I was one of the 15 per cent untouched by suicide. I cannot claim that any more. I buried my brother 10 days ago—a victim of suicide. It is an area that we must look into and I would like all honourable members on both sides of this House to look at this problem to see what we can do to stop it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to say a few words about the supposed closures of post offices throughout Australia. The ALP government of Queensland has alleged that the post offices in country areas will not close and that no-one will lose their jobs, but in the next minute it is skiting about how it will make those services pay. Clearly, those services will not pay. Clearly, hospitals do not make money in Australia. It is simply a matter of whether or not post offices want to make deliveries.

PARA.TAB: I saw recently a travelogue on Canada. A postman was delivering the mail to homes in the snow and in the tundra nearly 400 miles from the nearest town. It is with great pride that the Canadian government claims that every single person is a citizen of Canada and that therefore every citizen should get the mail delivered to them.

People living outside of towns in Australia will very shortly not have their mail delivered to them. The postal services to stations, to isolated mining camps, to isolated Aboriginal settlements and to people who live in the great outback of Australia from which this country secures its identity as a nation will cease to operate. People will no longer receive their mail as a result of the introduction of a user-pays system. Clearly, in those areas the user will not pay. What they know now as isolation will be nothing compared with what they will be looking forward to very shortly.

Once upon a time in this country we had security in our jobs. If we did not have security in our jobs in the private sector, at least we had security in our jobs in the government sector. It is now true that people in the government sector no longer have any security. Once upon a time I thought that would probably be a good thing, but having seen people live in terror I no longer feel that way. The previous speaker made reference to suicides. In the last seven or eight years we have achieved the highest juvenile suicide rate in the entire world. In the last 18 months, four of those suicides have been in the Charters Towers-Hughenden area. Suicides are very heartbreaking things to occur in one's area and they occur because people are sick with worry.

We have seen a number of our postmasters in North Queensland become alcoholics and die from stress. One of my friends died. The doctor said that his heart attack was occasioned by stress. It was clear to all of his friends in the local Lions Club that he was prominent in, that it was the stress that had been responsible for the death of this very great citizen of our town. Those stresses are being cold bloodedly created by people in this House. Those stresses are being created so that we can run this system at a profit. No-one believes in profit more than I do. I hardly gave a speech in the state house in which I did not say, `Profit is a dirty word to you people on the other side of the House'.

We have a user pays principle. The way that translates for we people who do not live in the big metropolitan areas is that we virtually lose our airports in most of our country towns while Brisbane gets nearly $700 million for an international airport to cater not for Australians but for very rich foreigners who are visiting Australia. That is what the user pays principle has become.

The user pays principle means that our backs are broken from the taxation that we have to pay on fuel. A shearer in my electorate travels an average of 40 miles a day over the worst roads that exist anywhere in the continent to do his daily work. This same person watches a fellow worker in Brisbane have his commuter transportation system subsidised so that he pays about $3.50 to get to his workplace during the week. This is not fairness. This is a dreadful injustice that is being foisted on the working people of Australia.

Not only does the closure of the postal services mean the reintroduction of the tyranny of distance in this country of ours, and not only does it mean the straw that broke the camel's back for many of our battlers in the country areas who are fighting to survive with an average debt in farming industries, for example, of $100,000 a piece, but it also means for the shearers, contractors, railway workers and some of our isolated Aboriginal settlements a burden which they can simply carry no longer. For our postal workers, it means no job security, and for our postal licensees it means bankruptcy. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must pay tribute to the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), one of the last great socialists in the House, reminiscent very much of Eddie Ward—a veritable rural Eddie Ward. I want to talk about what I see as intellectual corruption in this country. Nowhere is it more rampant than in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, and I want to bring a few examples to the attention of the House.

PARA.TAB: Last Wednesday I was listening to the radio and heard Andrew Olle from the ABC interviewing Father Larry Reitmeyer, the doyen of the Cambodian boat people incarcerated in Port Hedland in my electorate. He was waxing eloquent about the terrible conditions which Australia kept these people under and he was saying how disgraceful it was that some of these people have been in detention for five years. The reality is that these people are in detention because people like Reitmeyer and others are actively seeking to delay their departure. The delay has been caused almost entirely by lawyers for these Cambodian people seeking appeal after appeal and delaying bringing their cases to court.

He also spoke about the terrible treatment these people receive. He said, `I can tell you what Christmas dinner was; it was one chicken for a whole table'. He omitted to say that there was copious rice and as much salad as they wanted and that there were only four people to a table. I suggest it was better fare than they had in Cambodia. He also omitted to say that the Australian authorities allow these people to do their own cooking and make them choose their own diet. It was clearly a very one-sided interview.

I tried to get a correction on the ABC without success. I phoned the producer of the program in Perth, who said to me in his North American accent, `Well, after all, in Australia we do have the world's worst record in relation to refugees'. The reality is that we have the world's best record, acknowledged by the United Nations. It is an absolute scandal that this sort of thing is allowed to denigrate Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts and Minister for Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to a few comments made by the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter). First of all, I am absolutely staggered by his comments opposing the spending of funds by the federal government on the Brisbane international airport terminal. The honourable member appears to think that it is wrong for the government to use taxpayers' funds to invest in improving the services available to Australians and international visitors to Australia who might be thinking about using the Brisbane international airport terminal.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that a member who represents an electorate in Queensland would realise the contribution that international tourism has made to the Queensland economy. I am staggered that a National Party member from Queensland has made such an attack on an investment that is crucial to the future of the tourism industry in Queensland. I remind the honourable member for Kennedy that, last year, the tourism industry generated more than $8 billion in export earnings for Australia.
Mr Katter interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Kennedy!

—That is more than wheat and wool combined. It surprises me that the honourable member for Kennedy attacks the tourism industry in that way given the number of people whose jobs depend on the international visitors coming not only to his electorate but also to Cairns, to the Whitsundays to Brisbane and to the Gold Coast.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that the people in the honourable member's electorate who depend on the tourism industry are going to be very interested to read his comments tonight. The tourism industry more than any other is going to be responsible for a lot of investment and a lot of jobs, not only in the honourable member's electorate in Queensland but also throughout the country. It is a pity that we cannot count on all members of the opposition to provide support for the tourism industry.

Interestingly, the shadow minister for tourism and aviation, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), has campaigned quite strongly to encourage the government to spend this money on the airport terminal and in comes a member of the opposition who attacks the very investment that is going to help tourism in his own state. Perhaps the honourable member should sort out with the shadow minister for aviation whether or not it is a good thing that the government is spending money on the Brisbane international airport terminal.

The honourable member also went on to attack the government about the provision of postal services to Australians who live in rural and remote communities. He made a number of attacks on those of us on this side of the House. I remind the honourable member for Kennedy that, at question time today, I made it clear that those people who are suggesting that Australia Post is undertaking a program to shut down 500 post offices throughout the country are misleading the public and misleading the employees of Australia Post.
Mr Katter interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Kennedy has already been asked to restrain himself. I suggest that he does so.

—I suggest that those people who are concerned about the future of Australia Post and who want to see one of our most successful government business enterprises continue to improve will be endorsing its campaign to improve the retail post office network. Australia Post should ensure that it has better locations for post offices so that it can get a higher revenue turnover. We should be encouraging Australia Post to develop new retail post shops which again will provide new and better services to post office clients and at the same time attract more business clients. That is the way to ensure that we have a better postal network in this country.

PARA.TAB: I also remind honourable members that there is a program to convert some of the smaller, unprofitable official post offices to licensed post offices. That is a good thing. It is to ensure that the local residents in the community have access to the same range of services and that the conversion takes place only after consultation with the local community. That is what Australia Post is doing now; that is this government's commitment to the future of Australia Post.

The honourable member for Kennedy attacks us and says that he is concerned about the provision of services to citizens in his electorate. I remind the honourable member for Kennedy that today the shadow minister for communications, Senator Alston, put out a press release. He has a very different attitude to community service obligations. He does not think that Australia Post should be funding the community service obligations, as those of us on this side of the House believe. The opposition's policy is that CSOs should be funded out of the budget. So every year the CSOs are at risk of being cut back by the Minister for Finance or the Treasurer of the day.

The opposition's view is that the subsidies going to its constituents should not be provided by Australia Post but that they should be at risk every year. That is no way to provide guarantees to the constituents of opposition members. If I were the honourable member for Kennedy, and I had those concerns that he has raised in the House tonight, I would give Senator Alston a ring and let him know why I thought the opposition policy was wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 20 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has it been decided to establish a Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service (VVCS) in Lismore, NSW; if so, why.
(2) How many Vietnam veterans live in the (a) Northern Rivers region, NSW and (b) Gold Coast region, Qld.
(3) Has the Gold Coast been selected for the location of a VVCS office; if not, why not.
(4) Will a Veterans' Advice Network (VAN) office be established on the Gold Coast; if so, (a) when and (b) where.
(5) Will the VVCS continue to operate as a separate, independent entity.
(6) Is the VVCS office in Lismore to be co-located with the VAN office; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The establishment of a Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service centre in Lismore was announced in the Budget.

The establishment of the centre in Lismore was recommended by my National Advisory Committee on the VVCS. It had the strong support of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia (VVAA). This centre will service the needs of veterans and their families living in the Northern Rivers Region of New South Wales.
(2) (a) 298 Vietnam veterans and 294 dependants known to the Department of Veterans' Affairs live in the Northern Rivers region of New South Wales; and
(b) 500 Vietnam veterans and 423 dependants known to the Department of Veterans' Affairs live in the Gold Coast region of Queensland.
(3) At present the Gold Coast has not been selected for the location of a VVCS centre.

The Gold Coast is currently serviced by a VVCS counsellor visiting once a week from Brisbane and supported by 6 professional counsellors with practices on the Gold Coast who are contracted to the VVCS under the Country Outreach Program.
This area is also relatively close to Brisbane if a critical situation arises.
(4) The establishment of a Veterans' Advice Network (VAN) office on the Gold Coast was announced in the budget.

(a) The VAN will be established as soon as possible. However, the time frame will depend on the appropriate premises being found, certain staffing issues being resolved, and the recruitment of suitable people.

(b) The site of the VAN office will depend, in part, on finding suitable office space. Currently a number of sites are being examined on the northern end of the Gold Coast, as investigations indicate that the number of veterans is more concentrated in this region and most health and support services are located in this area.
(5) Yes. The VVCS will continue to operate as a separate, independent entity.

(6) The VVCS office in Lismore will be adjoining the VAN office, however the two offices will operate independently. The office space was chosen following the examination of a number of premises with representatives of the local veteran community and the State President of the VVAA. It was agreed that these premises would be the most effective and efficient means of delivering overall services to clients of both the VVCS and VAN.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 15 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that some patients are waiting up to six months for access to magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) units in public hospitals.
(2) Do some private hospitals have MRI units for which they charge between $500 and $900 per procedure.

(3) Was a Medicare rebate for MRI procedures withdrawn; if so, (a) when, (b) why, (c) upon whose advice, (d) has the Minister reconsidered the advice in the light of the resulting waiting lists, (e) can forcing patients, some of whom are critically ill, to incur costs of between $500 and $900 for MRI procedures or risk waiting for free procedures in public hospitals be justified and (f) have the relative merits of reintroducing the rebate to enable access to MRI units in private hospitals been assessed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Clinicians and hospitals are responsible for determining priority of access to publicly funded MRI services. There are waiting lists of varying lengths for routine investigations. However, specialists are able to make arrangements with the chief radiologist of the relevant funded unit for priority of access for patients who require urgent scans, especially for neurosurgical and neurological cases.

Waiting lists vary between the States with an average time for routine bookings of four weeks in Victoria. There is some anecdotal evidence that waiting lists in New South Wales are longer, but no comprehensive national data is currently available on average length of waiting lists.
The following factors are relevant to the issue of waiting lists for MRI services:

while the Commonwealth provides capital and recurrent funding for a fixed number of MRI units, the location of and admission procedures to these units is the responsibility of each State and the hospitals in which the units are located.

long waiting lists have mainly occurred in one State (NSW) where there has been a delay in installing units already funded by the Commonwealth at Westmead and Prince of Wales Hospitals. These units will be operating by March 1994 which will reduce pressure on waiting lists;
under the MRI program, States may use Commonwealth funds allocated to the program to purchase scans at privately owned MRI units where appropriate. However, this does not occur on a large scale.
(2) Yes. Reports indicate a wide range of charges for MRI scans at privately owned units. These units are not funded under the MRI program and the fees charged are outside the Government's control.
(3) Yes. The rebate was replaced by the Commonwealth MRI program, consisting of grants to the States.

The Government's MRI policy was based on the MRI assessment program established as a joint initiative between the Commonwealth and the States in order to achieve a planned and rational introduction of an unproven and expensive health care technology in Australia. The MRI assessment program was conducted over the period 1986 to 1990. The National Health Technology Advisory Panel (NHTAP), an independent panel of experts, provided advice to the Commonwealth and State Ministers.

During the period of the assessment, an MBS benefit was available for MRI scans. This was an interim measure only, pending the results of the assessment. Five machines were purchased by the Commonwealth and located at public hospitals for the purpose of the evaluation and the MBS rebate applied only to services provided by these designated units.
(a) July 1992

(b) The MRI grants program replaced the Medicare rebate in order to constrain proliferation of this expensive new technology. An open ended Medicare benefit may lead to waste of scarce resources through inappropriate use of the technology, reductions in quality and increased costs.
(c) The Government based the size of the grants program on the NHTAP assessment of the number of MRI units required to meet the needs for clinical cases where MRI is of proven benefit.

(d) The national target of 18 MRI units to serve both public and private (non-compensable) patients mainly for neurological and neurosurgical purposes was based on NHTAP's recommendation of an approximate ratio of one unit per one million people. All 18 units will be operating by late 1994. Although there is a lack of hard evidence to support claims made about problems with access to existing public units, there is plenty of anecdotal evidence that some additional machines are required. The Government is currently examining this question, particularly taking account of new uses for the technology. The Royal Australasian College of Radiologists has made a detailed submission on this matter which is currently being considered.

(e) As stated in the answer to (1), clinicians and hospitals are responsible for determining priority of access. Critically ill patients would normally be admitted to hospital and receive scans as required.

(f) The issues are being assessed. However, benefits of a grants program, i.e. to improve access to MRI while retaining control over proliferation, cost to the community and quality of care, remain valid.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 15 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: In assessing unrealised capital gains on pensioners' shares held in investment clubs operating as partnerships, has his Department required third parties such as accountants, and auditors to provide details of all shares owned by the clubs, including dates of purchase, involving searches of records over many years; if so,
(a) has his Department acknowledged that it has placed unreasonable demands on those third parties because the information required may take several hours to prepare and cannot be billed to anyone,
(b) what steps will be taken to minimise the costs incurred by third parties,
(c) has compensation to third parties to offset costs been considered,
(d) does his Department require the provision of the dates of purchase of shares purchased before the 12 month assessment period; if so, why and

(e) how many private individuals or companies with no direct connection with the affected pensioner has his Department contacted for information in relation to unrealised capital gains on the pensioner's shares since the initiative was introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: A pensioner involved in an investment club partnership will have the relevant proportion of listed shares acquired by the partnership after 18 August 1992 assessed under the new shares rules. The relevant proportion is determined by the size of the pensioner's contribution to the partnership.

All social security clients or new claimants for a pension or an allowance are required to provide documentary evidence to verify their circumstances, including those of the investments they own. For individual shareholders, documentary evidence for shares may include share scrip (or photocopies of share scrip), FAST statements or contract notes from brokers.

For pensioners who hold shares in investment club partnerships, it is recognised that this type of documentation may not be held by individual club members. In place of it, clients would be asked to supply a statement or list from the investment club of the club's current shareholdings.

In many cases the relevant documentation may already be in the client's possession. However, in cases where clients do not hold current documentation from the club showing its shareholdings, it would usually be necessary for the pensioner to approach the club and seek the documentation.
Some clients could indicate to the Department that they wish the Department to contact the club to obtain the documentation, and the Department would carry out such a request.

If, in the unlikely situation, this documentation was not available to the club, a third party such as an accountant (paid by the partnership to prepare financial statements of the club) may need to draw up a list of club shareholdings and their dates of acquisition.

(a) In most cases documentation relating to the shareholdings of the investment club would already be in existence and would be readily available. Consequently, any recourse to a third party acting on behalf of the club, and hence on the client's behalf, would be infrequent and not unreasonable.

(b) Existing arrangements do minimise costs to third parties, as the Department seeks information in the first instance from clients, and accepts any reasonable existing evidence in clients' possession of their investments and other income without attempting to verify that information with third parties.

(c) It is long standing practice that claimants and recipients of payments are responsible for providing evidence of their income. The vast majority are able to do so without cost or difficulty. Any cost associated with providing information for purposes such as income tax or social security payment assessment is a matter for clients and their financial advisers.

(d) The Department needs to be advised of whether or not shares were acquired before 19 August 1992. Documentation verifying this, whether supplied by the client or a third party, would only need to confirm whether or not the shares had been acquired before 19 August 1992.

(e) The Department does not have records of how many third parties with no direct connection to the pensioner it has contacted for documentation in relation to shares. However, as indicated in the answer to part(a), recourse to a third party acting on behalf of the club (and hence on behalf of the client) would be infrequent, as it would only be necessary where the documentation could not be obtained from either the client or the club.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 15 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is he responsible for the operation of the Australian Protective Service (APS).
(2) What are the roles of the APS.
(3) Does any role of the APS include intelligence gathering.

(4) Since 1 January 1990, has any function that the APS undertakes required or benefited from the use of bugging equipment or communications equipment capable of being used as bugging equipment; if so, (a) has the APS used, hired, borrowed, lent, purchased or disposed of such equipment, (b) which APS functions were involved, (c) what type and quantity of equipment was used and (d) what sums were spent on the equipment.

(5) Does the APS conduct any intelligence gathering activity of a type that falls within the responsibility or purview of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization, the Australian Security Intelligence Service or any other Commonwealth intelligence, security or like service; if so, (a) which activities, (b) which services and (c) why does the APS conduct the activities instead of the services.

(6) Are private security firms contracted to perform any functions with which the APS is charged; if so, (a) which firms, (b) which functions and (c) on each occasion a private firm was used, (i) what sum was spent, (ii) at which locations were the staff of the private firm deployed and (iii) when were they deployed.

(7) Has any APS officer or member of staff recommended or promoted any private security firm to any other APS officer or member of staff to be subcontracted by the APS or to be used in any other capacity.

(8) Is any APS officer or member of staff a proprietor or shareholder of, or consultant to, any private security firm; if so, in each case, (a) which officer or member of staff, (b) what position does he or she occupy and (c) with which firm is he or she involved.

(9) Has the APS, any part of it or any officer or member of staff been investigated by his Department or an agency for which he has portfolio responsibility concerning matters of fraud or impropriety; if so, what (a) stage has the investigation reached and (b) result has been achieved.
(10) Which public service legislation applies (a) wholly, (b) partially or (c) not at all to the APS.

(11) What procedures (a) has the APS instituted and (b) does it follow to investigate matters raised by APS officers or members of staff concerning allegations of inappropriate conduct by APS officers or members of staff including (i) conflict between private interests and public duty, (ii) nepotism and patronage and (iii) victimisation of other APS officers or staff members.
(12) Has the APS or any other Commonwealth agency investigated any matters described in part (11); if so, what are the details.
(13) How does the APS or his Department protect persons who raise such matters as referred to in part (16) from the persons against whom allegations have been made.

(14) Under what circumstances do APS officers, such as regional commanders, superintendents, inspectors and sergeants in the APS occupy the other positions of (a) superintendent or inspector, (b) regional commander, inspector or sergeant, (c) regional commander, superintendent or sergeant and (d) superintendent or inspector.
(15) When (a) temporary and (b) permanent positions become available, what internal or external advertising for the positions takes place.
(16) What selection processes are used to fill (a) temporary and (b) permanent vacancies.
(17) What steps to limit the use of firearms in the workplace are taken in posting or supervising an APS officer or member of staff who is subject to a restriction on the use of firearms.
(18) Does the APS follow counselling or disciplinary procedures to deal with officers or members of staff whose conduct is unsatisfactory, inappropriate or dangerous; if so, what procedures.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The Australian Protective Service (APS) is a sub-program within my Department, but on a day to day basis, it reports to the Minister for Justice.

(2) The roles of the APS are to provide guarding services to Commonwealth departments, authorities and bodies, custodial and escort services to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, a counter-terrorist first response role at certain security designated airports, diplomatic and consular security within Australia, advisory services to Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities on various aspects of guarding and custodial services and related physical security matters and the provision of security arrangements for the guarding of property including hazardous goods and cultural property such as art exhibitions indemnified by the Commonwealth.

(3) and (5) The APS role does not include intelligence gathering, nor does it engage in such activity. The APS does, however, frequently liaise with the Australian Security Intelligence Services in order to: obtain threat assessments; provide information on (and discuss the implications of) security incidents that have occurred at establishments protected by the APS; and to discuss the appropriate security response to potential incidents.

(4) No—however in 1991 a Regional Office of the APS purchased some equipment without authority. This action was investigated by an independent person and was brought to the attention of the Australian Federal Police. The investigation revealed no evidence that the equipment had been used for anything other than the purpose for which it was alleged to have been made, that is to demonstrate to clients how easy it would be for someone to bug their premises. The equipment was purchased for a sum of $545.00. The equipment was of a kind which was commercially available. It was disposed of immediately following the investigation.

(6) The APS is not "charged" to perform any functions, rather it is authorised by statute to do so. The work it actually performs is the result of contractual arrangements with its clients. It does, however, have limited arrangements with private firms as follows:

(a) The APS has an agreement with a small number of security firms for the provision of marketing and technical advice and occasionally will co-ordinate the purchase of commercial services on behalf of the client. Firms in this category include: Chubb, Bio-recognition Systems and Visions Systems Limited. The APS has contracted Securitron to perform repairs and maintenance on security systems at the Westbridge/ Villawood Immigration Detention Centre. Payments in the order of $20,000 are expected to be made for these services during the 1993/94 financial year.

(b) Private security firms are generally only contracted to provide and install security alarms and similar technology which is then monitored by the APS—the APS has never deployed private security personnel to undertake guarding or other functions performed by the APS. (The only exception occurred during the Gulf crisis when the APS contracted the Corps of Commissionaires in Victoria to undertake guarding which the APS would normally perform itself but which it was unable to do because it had to deploy limited resources elsewhere to cope with the emergency situation.)

(7) Because APS officers work in the security industry, they would have regular discussions amongst themselves and during those discussions they may recommend an arrangement with a private firm. Any actual use or dealings with a private security firm would, of course, be subject to proper Public Service processes. In the course of dealing with clients, most senior officers would at times "recommend", but not "promote", the use of private security firms. They normally do this in the context of advising a client how they might obtain and install alarms and other security technology.

(8) The APS has no record or information to suggest that any officer or member of staff is a proprietor or shareholder of, or consultant to any private security firm. Moreover, as public servants, APS staff members are required to seek permission to undertake outside work and are also expected to declare any potential conflict of interest.

(9) Cases of suspected impropriety are always investigated, and there have been two such cases in the last year. In neither case was there sufficient evidence to sustain a charge. There have been no cases of suspected fraud in the APS.
(10) Members of the APS are public servants and as such are subject to all Australian public service legislation.

(11) The APS is a division of a Department of State and follows the normal procedures applying to such a body with respect to the conduct of its members. Officers are required to disclose potential conflict between private interests and public duty, and applications to engage in outside employment are subject to scrutiny by the Secretary of the Department. Suspected instances of conflict or impropriety, patronage or victimisation are dealt with through normal public service disciplinary processes. Grievance avenues are open to officers and these are referred to the Secretary of the Department and/or the Merit Protection Review Agency and/or the Minister and/or the Ombudsman. Responsibility for conducting investigations lies outside the APS, although preliminary investigations may be undertaken internally if directed.
(12) Yes, but as indicated above, no disciplinary or other charges have been laid; accordingly it would not be proper to provide further details.

(13) Any member of the APS who raises a matter concerning actions by another member receives the normal protection provided to public servants in such cases. I am informed that the Director of the APS does not discourage such matters being raised and would immediately take disciplinary action against any member who threatens another under such (indeed, all) circumstances, provided there was sufficient evidence to support such action.

(14) APS members normally occupy positions and perform duties commensurate with the rank they hold. Occasionally, particularly when there are no suitable vacancies at an officer's substantive level, that officer may be placed in a lower position while still receiving the salary applicable to his or her substantive rank.

(15) When temporary positions become vacant, the normal practice is to notify them in the APS's internal newsletter, "UPDATE" which is issued weekly. When positions become vacant permanently, they are also notified in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and sometimes in the press as well, in the normal public service manner. In some cases, however, advertising is not appropriate and decisions to transfer are taken to provide career development opportunities.
(16) The normal APS procedures as set out in the Personnel Management Manual Vol VII (as updated by the Public Service Commission's "Streamlining" booklets).

(17) APS General Orders, supplemented by instructions from National Headquarters limit the use of firearms to very restricted circumstances. APS officers who are subject to a restriction of the use of firearms (for example a domestic violence order) or who fail to pass rigorous six monthly theoretical and practical tests, or who for any other reason it is suspected should not carry a firearm, are not permitted to do so and are deployed to an establishment which does not require the carriage of firearms.

(18) Yes. Where an officer's work performance is unsatisfactory, he or she is counselled—in the first instance by that officer's immediate supervisor. If there is no improvement the matter is referred up the line, with the final step being the institution of the formal Public Service inefficiency procedures. If an officer's conduct is such as to warrant some form of discipline, the matter is investigated by an officer authorised by the Secretary, who can lay a charge. The charge is then investigated by an Inquiry Officer appointed by the Secretary, who can impose penalties as prescribed under the Public Service Disciplinary Code. If an officer's conduct is actually or potentially dangerous to him or her or to others, the officer is removed from his or her duties and placed on other duties or to other locations or stood down.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Tourism, upon notice, on 17 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many cases of fraud did the Government uncover in the Department or any agency for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility in (a) 1991, (b) 1992 and (c) 1993.
(2) How many cases were successfully prosecuted.
(3) What sums were recovered in (a) 1991, (b) 1992 and (c) 1993 from fraud cases.
(4) What percentage of the total loss from fraud does the recovered sum comprise.
(5) How many persons in the Minister's Department or in agencies for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility have been removed from employment for involvement in fraud.
(6) Is the Minister able to say whether any person referred to in part (5) is still employed in the Australian Public Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: No cases of fraud were uncovered in the Department or any agency within the portfolio in (a) 1991, (b) 1992 and (c) 1993.
